himselfe doe freely confesse vnto since tasted care trauels attending imperiall dignitie haue repented thousand time euer vndertake bee accounted honour enioy empire consisteth farre greater paine labour order gouerne ought beside enuie doth hee expose himselfe multitude mislikes hath charge gouerning others hee iust hee branded cruelry mercifull hee contemned beautifull tearmed lauish prodigall hee hoorde vp money basely couetous inclined peace hee coward full courage proudly anbitious discreetly graue surly scornefull affably courteous silly simple affecting solitude dissembling hypocrite addicted mirth pleasure wantonly dissolute end te worthy emperour thus concluded although willingly accepted high office first yet sorrow hath since made mee shrinke vnder brdensom charge liue world came certaine age men wit waxed fine tirants sprang vp oppressed poore theeues robbed rich rebel robbed quiet murderer slew patient idle eate swet men browes thing considered vertuous entituled de viris illustribus pliny seuenth booke chapter doe greatly praise pirotas hee first found fire flint stone greatly commended protheus inuented barneyes highly extolled panthasuea inuented science practise warres ende learneth science learneth nought else others ought liue learneth warlike feat learneth none thing slay neighbour destroy others third thing equally accepted lawes admit men liued together common would subiect one another would contention arise amongst according saying plato greater token destruction worthy sentence plato commonweale many ruler chosen therein plinie seuenth booke chap sayth queene called cere first taught sowe field grinde milles paste bake ouens also shee first taught people liue according law meanes thing forefather called goddesse since time neuer haue seene heard read realme nation well strange barbarous whatsoeuer haue lawes whereby good fauoured also institution grieuous paine wherewith wicked punished although truely rather better good loue reason feare law speake leaue doe euill workes feare onely falling punishment appoynted euill doer although men approue present yet god condemaeth desire seneca epistle hee wrote vnto friende lucille saide wordes thou writest vnto mee lucille scicile haue carryed great quantitie corne spaine affrike forbidden romaine law therefore haue deserued grieuous punishment thou art vertuous thou mayest teache mee doe well olde teach thee say well amongst wise vertuous men enough say law commaundeth appoynteth suffereth thing much agreeing reason crowne good reason scourge wicked law fourth thing commonly worlde amongst men accepted barber let man take thing mockery doe reade plinie chapter seuenth booke shall finde trueth former time romaine rome yeares without eyther powling shauing h ire bearde anie man marcus varro said publius first brought barber scicilie rome admit otherwise yet notwithstanding great contention among romaine sayd thought rash thing man commit life vnto curtesie another dyonisius syracusian neuer trusted beard barbor daughter little clipped beard sisers became great hee would put trust trimme beard hee himselfe burne shale nuttes dyonisius set aside nothing world curiously written needeth correction say one say doe renounce glory good learning would giue mee like manner euill men shall want seeke defame wee writer smally esteeme labour yet would gladly know patiece suffer heart dissemble two three bee assembled together meate table otherwise one taketh booke aduenture handes another say diuersity men opinion long another say old friend pulio wisheth health thy person peace commonwealth temple vestall virgin letter thine presented vnto written long greatly desired best therof thou writing vnto briefly desirest write vnto thee large vndecent authority chiefe empire especiall one couetous prince greater infamy lauish word scant reward thou writest griefe thy leg thy wound great truly paine thereof troubleth heart right much fortune giueth doth raigne slacke alwayes bridle thought haue vaine hope thorow power inforce fortune bee fauourable vnto shall liue alwayes trouble life nothing shortneth life man vain hope idle thought thou beeing man thou art well willed beloued iustinian husband art demaunded romane people chosen senate receyued souldiers empire reioyce thy election thou oughtest little regard willes doe alwayes fauour one let thee vnderstand tiberius displease mee thou shouldest bee emperour rome sith iustinian deposed perceyued doe perceyue knowne doe know certaine neyther sayde wee woman little credite preuayleth v approue least say doth speake well selues sith fortune hath brought thee high estate beseech thee admonish thee aduise thee thou know keepe gouerne thy selfe therein arise honour sufficeth body sweate water maintaine necessary heart weepe bloud thou knowest right well commaund doe haue touching affayres prince oftentimes giuen thorow worldly care desert person god suffereth often end wee may see discend fall thorow infamy saw mount prosper pride thou art man woman thou hast wisdome knowledge haue large long experience thou knowest much haue seene world enough faith haue said tell thee men thy sort vndone pallace prince two wayes one thinke deserue much doe little haughty mind bring alwayes alteration heart one alone command emperour empire whereunto man come great trauell hee shall sustaine danger shall possesse short time impossible man much arrogancy fortune bee long faithfull though thou wise sage counsell thee alwayes profite another man counsell chiefly thing concerning gouernement estate know obey know commaund differ much know obey commeth nature know command commeth long experience take generall rule whereas thou seest thy prayer acceptable neuer take vpon thee commaundement commandement thou shalt bee feared prayer thou shalt beloued know thou tiberius thing content worst court prince doe little haue little little worth man without fauour heart halfe dead contrarie thing perilleth fauorites prince maketh loose theyr friendship bee great power great authoritie moreouer profite knowledge authoritie reason man cannot liue long friendship doth commonwealth haue spoken ende thou shouldest knowe greatly maruell thy prudence haue lesse wonder patience see treasours iustinian heaped together great trauell kept preserued great care thou wastest without respect thou doest wherefore doe maruell patience suffer see proper good wasted spent handes great care hath bene gathered together let thee know tiberius wee haue neyther money keepe giue others thing perillous pallaces prince haue great store treasurs occasioneth prince keep enemy feare necessary prince stoute also rich stoutnes may gouerne owne rich way represse theyr enemyes onely necessarie prince bee poore also requisite commonwealth rich people poore theyr enemyes nothing regarded commonwealth rich prince cannot greatly poore denie well done helpe poore succour needy yet say man ought giue treasour vnto one particular hath long kept store preseruation oftentimes prince liberall giuing owne afterwards necessitie compelled become tyrant take others let thee know tyberius thou shalt finde prince eyther prowd malignant vicious truth wantonnes libertie youth rich commonly cruell enemyes honestie notwithstanding say prince haue beene euill say according old prouerbe hath good god mercifull gift eyther good vertuous ought greatly honoured time ought called happy wherein vertuous prince doe raigne furthermore say thee tiberius prince become tyrant want rich doe become vicious aboundance treasure case vicious prince chastened vice auarice hath power ouer suffereth taste theyr owne delight againe let thee know tiberius many prince good nature yet becom tyrant nothing else oppressed pouertie truely noble heart resuseth danger seeing himselfe assaulted pouertie therefore demaund thee better otherwise two euils least prince bee poore tyrant rich therewith vicious mine opinion much better rich vicious tyrant poore end euill vice hee bee euill vnto man himselfe rich profite people poore tyrant hee doe great euill many pouerty hee could profit good man plato sayeth athenian would alwayes rather seeke profitable stout prince lacedemonians erre willing rather stoute prince profitable therefore see tiberius sure profitable common wealth prince haue treasure giue liberally among seruants bee poore enforced oppresse people tax subsidy prince oft time pouerty take occasion leuy great subsidy realmes seigniory chap xv answer tiberius vnto empresse sophia augusta wherein hee declareth noble prince need boarde vp great treasure hidden treasure good emperour found reuelation pallace remained tiberius heard patiently admonition empresse wherefore great reuerece hee aunswered sweet gentle word hee spake sort haue heard vnderstood tiberius answere haue tolde mee noble princesse sophia alwayes augusta doe receyue gentle admonition humbly thanking louing counsell principally giue high stile oftentimes sicke men abhorre meates meates good well dressed god pleasure would knew aswell doe thing know speake doe maruell though make hereof doubt wee greatly desire prayse vertuous workes put practise wee slow speaking therefore reuerence due vnto high lady euery one thinges excellency hath tolde mee aunswere one word reason sith haue spoken perceiue deedes speake gather wordes tell alexandrie thought bee gouernour empire iustinian thoght selfe worthy deserue yet looked come vnto answere though reason gouerned selfe time yet ought thinke deserue dignitie come high estate vertues deserue great dignity fewe sewer attaine vnto though deserue matter iudged according sensualitie tell truely dame augusta thought onely deserue also thought come vnto hereof maruell infallible rule least desert oftentimes presumption say esteemed mee wise man wisedome could ouercome difficult disordinate appetite answere knewe wisedome either mine owne busines else men affaire men affaire cost mee nought alwayes louer iustice man world euill doth desire bee without owne cost counted liberall iudge mee dame augusta mine owne businesse giue light credit know man iust cleare iudgement doth shewe himselfe fraile frailtie man matter touch owne interest say men haue thought high fortune base liue alwayes pensiue life truely say mine opinion member bodyes instrument minde necessary men haue quicke sharpe wittes negligent alexander pyrrhus iulius caesar scipio hanniball beene high minded neuer bene famous noble stoute prince let vnderstand noble princesse men esteemed lost hauing theyr thoughtes high yet hauing heart couragious neither hardie stout vndone beginne thing folly pursue without wisedome atchieue without discretion nobleman enterprising great thing ought employ theyr force noble heart willeth wisedome reason teacheth say maruell waste treasure without care iustinian gathered together great paine answere ought maruell treasours heaped together long time spent consumed one day ancient malediction rich hidden saying epimenides treasours buryed epimenides casteth saying word treasours hoorded vp couetous shall bee wasted prodigall say wast fewe dayes shall haue neither giue waste yet eate yeares ende answere gracious princesse beene ready relieue poore iustinian diligent robbe rich iustly haue complained worthily might well haue iust cause repent till wee haue seene rich haue made poore notwithstanding yet haue gotten enough builde hospitall poore say prince resist theyr enemyes neede great treasure euill vnpossible mee finde one doe mee good haue done well man shall able wrong empresse sophia long time hated narsetes som sayde eunuch thinke rich iudge hee greater authority empire shee wherefore chastised noble dame haue reproued mee word simple woman since haue liberty authority commaund mee know also haue selfe obey therefore take leaue goe weaue webbe perhappes selfe whilest liue shal pouerty haue thoghts low humble heart part greatly exalted fortune many oftentimes dreame lord men great estate awake finde themselues slaues men condition honour neuer read like therfore haue doe ought take good heed condition shee enquireth neuer saw runneth flyeth honoureth esteemeth demaundeth willeth giueth requireth trusteth knoweth finally honour hath custome forsake esteemeth remaine little regardeth curious trauellers aske place doe demand way must take leade place goe meane prince noble men ought directly cast eye vpon honour way vertue bringeth honour dayly wee see many remaine defamed onely seeking honour others also exalted esteemed flying miserable world thou knowest know thee well fickle estate worlde know thee thou art sepulchre dead prison liuing shoppe vice hangman honour way mockery meaning infamy dishonour vnto immortall god oftentimes troubled thought whose case lament eyther euill man aduanced without desert good man ouerthrowne without cause truely case pitifull man haue compassion euill liue hee sure fall good fal wee doubt whether euer hee shall rise againe falles alike would bee healed cured one salue fall foot side others stumble fall fall downe right giue hand meane fall estate lose substance others fall sorrow lose onely theyr good liues withall fall neyther lose liues good honour onely according discretion fortune haue still taketh thee good aduentures difference betweene good euill euill ill cannot say discendeth falleth good may onely say discendeth falleth end true honour doth consist perfection dignity man hath good life hee called vertuous worke onely vertuous acceptable god oh excellent prince doest thou know man wise neither sage erreth ignorance doth good wisdome dost thou know man iust wanteth much execute true iustice finally say vertue vertuous wanteth hath perfite wherfore iustice ought made perfit diuine iustice vertue lacke ought supplyed vnder great perfection wherewith god abound therefore amongst v romains haue law chiefe philosopher amongst mortall men mortall men mortall men thing perfite vnlesse bee god confirmed since men feeble frayle bee chosen commit many frailtyes case sage prince ought beare fraylties men commit excepted iniurious god possible vnwares ought punished prince called prince tyrant desirous reuenge owne iniurie chastening god sheweth himselfe negligent let thinke list difference betweene good prince tyrant complaine prince enlarge dominion giue occasion seruice god diminished man wil call king gouerneth tirant wee call tyrant spoyleth people sleeth men persecuteth innocent dishonoureth virgines robbeth realmes tell mee excellent prince lacketh hee tyrant plucketh downe church little esteemeth god token manifest prince tyrant hee taketh vpon thing distastfull way contrarie god hath small regard towardes men little feare god lycurgus famous king lacedemonians saith one ancient lawes word wee ordaine commaund lacedemonian presume receyue mercy fauour prince enforce himselfe serue god onely euill wicked excellent king glorious world fortunate realme wherein ancient would prince bee iust gift esteemed vnlesse liues honest thought value handes euil men giue thou hast done one thing dishonest noble prince write vnto thee ashamed enlarge thy new palace thou hast plucked old temple thing thou shouldest neyther haue done yet haue thought end though stone temple small importance yet god dedicated much value pardon excellent prince though et thee vnderstand fact hath beene done sort thereby amased rome also offended sacred senate thou hast greatly vexed iudge thee dissolute man men procure thou mayst extreamly punished hereof maruell rome beleeue prince dareth plucke downe hee violateth temple feareth god temple doth little feare god thou art noble prince olde friend mine haue trauelled bring thee fauour senate thou hast mean excuse thy errour committed doe determine forgiue thee fault see thee token amendment truth thinketh haue reason nothing troubleth poore men see rich theyr offence chastised punished sacred senate hath ordayned forthwith thou begin build temple new large hie beutifull richer euer thou take much thy pallace enlarge temple thou tookest temple beautifie thy pallace thou hast performed though thou thinke thy selfe halfe dishonoured thou wilt thinke thy selfe happy thou god god thee shall haue taken thy house make temple beleeue well great cost charge vnto thee thou hast finished temple wherefore send thee thousand sexterces helpe thy building end secret send thee secretary panuntius thou shalt giue credite send thee likewise coller gold one brought riuer nyle narrow mee suppose fit thee one hath brought moyles spaine whereof send thee two panuntius secretary bringeth good moyle hee esteemeth much man eyther buy borrow delight much desire thou cause eyther bought stollen sent vnto mee rome wife faustine saluteth thee excellent queene thy wife part mine much possible commendation popingeyes faustine presenteth vnto marcus romane emperour writeth thee owne hand chap xix gentile honoured deuout seruice god ancient romane historiographer agree beginning seuen kinges gouerned rome space yeares second whereof named pompilius amongst highly esteemed none cause hee great worshipper god sumptuous builder temple romane prince much beloued seruing god honoured vanquishing enemy sort allowed rome wholy god made house himselfe without city ancient law rome ancient man bee bolde dwell house consecrated god fift king romanes tarquinius priscus tarquinius superbus vicious abhorred people vertuous welbeloued god greatly praysed doings hee feared god continually visited temple contented finished built also high capitoll sacred temple iupiter prince could build house rome himselfe vnlesse first hee made temple god commonwealth temple great reuerence romanes honored iupiter god aboue god temple esteemed aboue temple warres betweene alisques carpenates two romane captaines vanquished one named dyed whereupon rose great among many flying warres came backe againe rome victorious hath alwayes priuiledge though bee fewe yet alwayes feared ouercome occasion ued romanes chuse new captaines truely like wise men oftentimes ha neth captaines warres fortune likewise chaungeth doings captaine elected war marcus purius camillus vow marcus camillus though stout hardy yet went war offered great sacrifice god made vow hee returned rome victorious hee would build solemne temple custome rome immediately romane captaine would enterprise doe notable thing make vow build temple camillus returned afterwards victorious hee onely build temple also furnished manner implement thereunto belonging got spoyle vanquishing enemy sith reprehended saying romane captaines offer theyr heart god diuide treasure among souldiers hee answered word like man aske god one triumph like god giue mee many therefore considering iust th promising large perso ing euen thanke gaue double respect demaunded likewise shall esteeme doe giue respect promised time cruell war betwixt rome city neye romanes kept besieged yeares together end policie tooke chaunceth sundrie time warre city short time policie great strength long time hath defended marcus furius dictator rome time captaine commanded proclamation throgh host incontinently city taken none hardy kill citizen found armed thing enemy vnderstanding vnarmed themselues escaped truly example worthy nothing captaines ought shew themselues fierce cruell duetie euery good captaine beginning victorie enemy shew themselues meeke pittifull brought rome amongst auncients law god vanquished come lot captaines conquerours therfore hee made mount auentino sumptuous temple wherein hee placed god together holy reliques hee wanne greater triumph roman ouer enemy much better handled god people vanquished also ought know romaine many victory determined make crowne golde great rich offer god apollo sith common treasure poor little siluer lesse golde make crowne romane matron defaced theyr iewels ouches golde siluer make crowne withall rome neuer wanted money demanded seruice god repayre temple redeeme captiues senate esteemed well willing heart woman sort graunted three thing say weare heades garland flower goe chariot common place goe reward well openly feast god auncient romanes honest neuer ware gold theyr heades neyther went time feast vncouered man ought maruell romanes granted priuiledges vnto ancient matrones rome vsed neuer bee obliuious benefite receyued rather gentle thanks reward recompence notable thing afterwards thirdly hee built againe city hierico commaundement god destroyed comanded vpon grieuous pain bee reedefied againe offence therein committed great inhabitant onely deserue lose liues also hierusalem sith king manasses hath beene bolde contemne mee himselfe alone commit offence chastice alone correction hee hath shewed vnto others word let prince note diuine vengeance extendeth offence truly euill done well ordained end sith man man thing hee eyther certaine assured sith god god vnpossible thing hee erre great benefite creator bee willing reforme correct word creature god would suffer v doe owne mindes wee bee quite contrary pleasure god without great mistery ordayne one family bee one father among one people one cittizen commaund one prouince one gouernour alone also one garamantia made vnto king alexander goodly lesson ambitious men custome king alexander amongst v garamantes speake seldome one another scarsely neuer speake stranger especially busie vnquiet men tongue euil man plaine demonstration enuious heart tolde v thy comming countrey immediately wee determined goe receyue thee prepare selues resist thee neyther lifte vp eye beholde thee open mouthes salute thee neyther moue hand trouble thee yee make warre offend thee greater hate beare rich honour thou louest loue thou hast destroy men subdue countreyes abhorre hath pleased thee shuld see thee desiring see thee wee haue obeied thee willing obey thee salute thee desirous salute thee wherewith wee contented vppon condition thou patient heare v say vnto thee shall tend vnto amendmet thy life disswade thee fro conquering countrey reason prince shal come hereafter doe know wee liuing little esteeme owne thou dying takest paine possesse another man alexander aske thee one thing doubt whether thou canst aunswer thereunto heart proud also commonly blinded tell whether thou goest whence thou commest thou meanest thou thinkest thou desirest thou seekest thou demandest thou searchest compendious reprehension thou procurest realm prouinces thy disordinate appetite extendeth without cause demand thee question thou demandest thou seekest think thou thy selfe knowest thou wouldest proud ambicious heart know satisfie sith thou art ambitious honor deceiueth thee sith thou art prodigall couetousnes beguyleth thee sith thou art yong ignorance abuseth thee sith thou art proude world laugheth thee scorne sort thou followest men reason thou followest thine owne opinion counsell thou embracest flatterer repulsest vertuous men prince noble men rather bee commended lye reproued truth cannot tell ende prince liue deceyued abused haue keepe pallaces flattrers iuglers fooles wise sage men prince pallace bee extolleth theyr doings ten thousand abhorre tyranny perceiue deed alexander god sooner end thy life wilt end thy war man brought vp debate discentions strife felicitie consisteth burning destroying bloud shedding see thee defended weapos see thee accopanied tirants see thee rob teples se thee without profit wast treasors see thee murder innocent trouble patient see thee euill willed beloued none greatest euill euils therefore possible thee endure great trauels vnlesse thou art foole else god hath appointed chastice thee god suffer oftentimes men quiet haue weighty affayres honoured present end punished past tell mee pray thee peraduenture great folly empouerish many make thy selfe alone rich peraduenture folly one commaund tyranny rest lose possession seigniory folly perchance loue damnation soules many memory world body folly perchance god approue thy disordinate appetite alone condemne opinion world beside peraduenture folly winne tear poore comfortlesse widdowes great bloudy victory peraduenture folly willingly wet earth bloud innocent onely haue vaine glorie world thou thinkest folly peraduenture god hauing diuided world many people thou shouldest vsurpe thee alone alexander alexander truly workes proceede creature nourished among men earth rather one hath beene brought vp among infernall fury hell wee bound iudge men wee ought iudge men good nature haue good euill work man cursed hee haue cursed hee shalbe cursed liueth preiudice others world present onely counted couragious stoute hardie time come god seldome suffered enioy quietly peace haue gotten vniustly warres would aske thee insolencie moued thee reuolte lord k darius whose death thou hast sought conquer world thus thou doest king inhertitor tyrant oppressor properly cal tirant without iustice reason taketh another man eyther thou searchest iustic thou searchest peace else thou searchest rich honor thou searchest rest el thou searchest fauour thy frends thou searchest vengeance propertie tyrant thine enemy sweare vnto thee alex thou shalt find thing thou seekest meanes thou hast begun sweet sugar nature bitter gumbe shall wee belieue thou searchest iustice sith reason iustice tiranny thou rulest al earth shal belieue thou searchest peace sith thou causest pay tribute receiue thee resist thee thou handlest like enemy belieue thou searchest rest sith thou troublest world wee belieue thou searchest gentile sith thou art scourge sword humaine frailnes belieue thou searchest rich sith thine owne treasure suffiseth thee neyther thee vaquished cometh thy hand conque rors offer thee shall belieue thou searchest profit thy frieds sith thy old friend thou hast made new enemy let thee vnderstand alex greatest ought teache least least obey greatst friendship onely amongst equalls thou sith thou sufferest none world bee equall like vnto thee looke thou haue friend world prince oftentimes ingratitude loose faithfull friend ambition winne mortall enemy shall belieue thou searchest reuege thine enemy sith thou takest vengeance thy selfe beeing aliue thine enemyes would take thee tooke thee prisoner though perchance time past vsed thy father philip euill haue disobeyed thee sonne farre better counsel thee make thy friend gentlenes confirme enemyes crueltie noble pitifull hart reuenged make themselues butcherie wee cannot truth say thy trauells well employde winne honor sith thy conuersation life vnconstant truely honour consisteth flatterer say lord doe great familiaritie wicked causeth life suspected honour gotten liberall giuing treasours death spending well life sufficient true honor consisteth profe man esteemeth renowme doth little regard money apparant token man little esteemeth money greatly regardeth renowme man winneth honor murdering innocent destroying tyrant harmony good gouernment prince chastising prince must winne honour euil rewarding good honour wonne taking snatching good giuing spending owne nothing beautifieth maiestie prince shew noblenes extending mercie fauour vnto subiects giuing gift reward vertuous conclude let thee know hee winneth true honour life also perpetuall memorie death hee leadeth life warres hee taketh death peace alexander see thou art young thou desirst honour wherefore let thee vnderstand man farther true honor hee greedily procureth desireth ambitious men obtaining desire remaine alwaies defamed winning getting search true honour notwithstanding follow belieue mee one thing alexander truest honor ought worthie deedes bee deserued meanes bee procured honour tyrannie wonne ende infamy lost sorrie thee alexander true honour wonne see thou wantest iustice since thou louest tyrannie see thou lackest peace thou louest warre see thou art rich thou hast made world poore see thou lackest rest thou seekest contention debate see thou hast honour thou winnest infamie see thou wantest friend thou hast made thine enemy finally see thou doest reuenge thy selfe thine enemyes thou art wold scourge thy selfe since art thou aliue world sith thou lackest vertues life ought desired truely man without owne profite dammage leadeth life iustice ought forthwith lose breath nothing sooner destroyeth weale publike permit vnprofitable men therein liue therefore speaking truth lord prince poore beleeue thou conquerest world thou knowest thy superiour therein besides thou wilt take life many end death thou mayest win renowne cruell warlike prince thou art inherite liues slay augment prolong liues doe inherite good maintaine pride although vnmeete warre tollerable profiteth seruant lose life day master death bee differred vntill propertie wise man morrow alexander desirous commaund much hauing respite liue little mee thinketh great folly lacke wisdome presumptuous ambitious men measure work dayes haue liue arogant haughty thought haue command leade life trauell take death sorrow remedy hereof wise man cannot obtaine hee would hee content himselfe hee may let thee know alexander perfection men see much heare much knowe much procure much come much trauell much possesse much bee able much bee fauour god finally tell thee man perfect owne opinion deserueth hee hath opinion another deserueth much hee possesseth wee opinion amongst v hee vnworthy haue honour hardy euill man hath lost fame oh would god good desire much power doe good work euill hath strength affection exercise wicked deedes vertuous man findeth one hand helpe vertue worke yet hee hath wrought hee shall haue thousand euill tongue honest doings speake would reade writing would call memory word among euill men chiefest euill haue forgotten themselus men exiled truth reason might goe truth vertue word good deed tongs though bee euill bee euill man yet worse suffer bee good aboue thing bee abhorred bee suffered let know assure prince noble men working vertuous deed shall want slaunderous tongue though bee stout yet must bee patient breake theyr malice noble heart feeleth enuie another hee doth labour owne body prince dismayed neither ought maruell though bee tolde murmuring good work end men liue men cannot escape misery men neuer prince world yet high hee hath beene subiect malitious tongue enuse enemie vertue truly man ought take great pitty prince whether bee good euill bee euill good hate bee good euill immediately murmureth emperour octauian vertuous yet greatly persecuted enuious tongue time demaunded since good vnto al men suffered murmur hee answere sodenly euery question liberty vndiscreet men haue demaund selfe priuiledge hath wise answere though demaund proceed ignorance yet answere ought proceede wisedome truly wise men well ease pulio lightnesse common people see vaine thing runne heare excellency vertues one goe philosopher aeschylus written many bookes specially tragedy afterward trauelled many country realmes last hee ended residue life neare isle adioyning vnto lake meatts diuine plato saveth auncient philosopher young studied came men trauelled old retyred home mine opinion philosopher wise lesse shall men dayes bee imitate father wisdome science experience consisteth true knowledge man last returneth home trouble world tell friend pulio pray thee dooth profite hath learned much hath heatd much hath knowne much hath seene much hath beene farre hath bought much hath suffered much hath proued much much great trauell doth retire repose himselfe little truly hee cannot counted wise foole willingly offereth himselfe trauell hath wit procure himselfe rest mine opinion life without rest long death chance ancient philosopher sleeping lake meatis hunter hare cage woode take hare whereon eagle seazed tooke vnpossible anacharsis thou shouldest bee scithian borne man eloquence cannot bee barbarous nation whome anacharsis answered thou hast sayde well herein assent thy wordes howbeit doe allow thy intention reason thou mayest disprayse mee bee barbarous country commend mee good life may iustly accuse thee wicked life prayse thee good country herein bee thou iudge v two shall haue praise world truly whether faire foule nothing better beloued god neither thereby hated men blindnesse world life neuer liueth death neuer shall end know man accident beauty durst take vpon vaine glory presumption haue beauty also shall haue end day tomorrow man faire well proportioned therefore nothing vertuous deformed euil shapen nothing therfore vicious vertue dependeth shape body neither yet vice proceedeth deformity face dayly wee see deformity body beautified vertues vertue mind beautifieth whole body minde vertues minde defaced vice body work truely vsage life hath botch imperfection worse hath foure botch shoulder also say though man great yet true therefore strong generall rule big body hath alwayes valiat couragious heart man little person vile false heart see experience greatest men coward least personage stout hardy heart holy scipture speaketh king dauid red countenance big body meane stature yet notwithstanding mighty giant goliah campe dauid killed goliah sling owne sword cut lyon recoured lambes wolues throtes besides one day battle owne hand slue number men though wee cannot finde like time may wel imagine slew least noble linage rich good faire countenance high stature shorter albeit yong face riuelled colour somewhat yellow aboue went somewhat crooked girdle half vndone men good wit imploy themselues setting body iulius caesar vnhandsome body battle pharsalique neighbour rome said vnto great orator tullius tell tullius hast thou followd partiality pompeius since thou art wise knowest thou iulius caesar ought lord monarch al world tullius answered tell thee true friend seeing iulius caesar youth euill vnseemely girded iudged neuer haue seene seene neuer greatly regard old sylla knew better seeing iulius caesar vncomly slouenly apparrelled youth youth esteemed beauty learning emperour vncle wrote letter letter marcus aurelius greeke sayd thus marcus aurelius romaine emperour first tribune people bishop wisheth thee epesipus nephew scholler health doctrine third calends december came thy cousin annius verus whose comming parentage reioyced much hee brought v newes grecia truely heart hath absence loueth minute houre without suspition thy cousen annius verus spoken generally bringing newes friend child talked together gaue letter thine contrary written mee greece thou writest mee send thee mony continue thee studie also write vnto thence thou art youthfull giuen pleasure world becommeth thee thou art blood thou art nephew thou wert scholler thou shalt bee sonne thou art good god wil neuer thou nephew shall call thee sonne time thou shalt yong fond light frayle good man haue parentage vitious cannot deny loue thee bottome stomacke likewikewise thy vnthriftinesse greeueth heart read letter thy folly content selfe sage wise men though willes heare thing past yet pleaseth redresse thing may come heareafter know well thou canst call minde though perhaps thou hast thy vnlucky mother sister annia melena died yong enough eighteene yeares age thou haddest foure houres thou wert borne morning shee dyed iust noonetide wicked childe possessed life good mother tasted death tell thee thou hast lost mother haue lost sister beleeue better rome sage honest faire thing seldome seene dayes much thy mother sister brought vp marryed read rethorike rhodes pouertie extreame thing reading rethorike get newes came vnto death thy mother sister annia milena al comfort laid side sorrow oppressed heart wise member trembled bone shiuered eye without rest lament heauy sighes ouercame euery minute heart vanished away bottome heart inwardly lamented bewayled thy vertuous mother deare sister finally sorrow executing priuiledge mee ioyfull company greeued onely louely care quieted selfe know cannot expresse vnto thee sort tooke death sister annia milena thy mother sleeping dreamed dreaming saw awake shee represented selfe remembring liued sorry remember death life grieuous vnto would haue reioyced haue beene put graue truly hee feeleth assuredly death another alway sorrowfull lamenting owne life remembring therefore great loue sister milena bare vnto life thinking wherein might requite death imagined could meanes doe thing acceptable bring thee vp thou art childe left orphane yong trauells woman chiefest leaue behinde child bring vp sister dead first thing came rome sent thee capua brought vp place hard nose gaue thee sucke two yeares thou knowest right well mony reading rethorike gate scarcely satisfied thy dayly feeding night reade extraordinare lecture payed milke thou suckedst dugge thy bringing vp depended vpon labour life thou wert weined brought teate sent thee bietro friend kinsman mine named lucius valerius thou remainedst vntill fiue yeares fully accomplished found thee thing necessary great pouertie great blabber tongue sort troubled offence come much talke men angred much truely man willingly giue mony cause silent talkatiue giue wise man heare speake fiue yeares accomplished sent thee toringue citie campaignia maister taught child called emilius torquates end hee teach thee reade write three yeares tooke sonne hee gaue mee reade greeke foure yeares thou couldest haue profite thee without increase great trauell augmenting paine heart thou wert seuen yeares old thou couldest reade write wel sent thee study famous city tareth kept thee foure yeares paying master great summe money dayes euill fortune none teach without great stipend without lamenting doe tell thee time cincinos death quintus cincinatus vntill cyna catulus phylosopher maisters sacred senate payde none ceased study lacke money dayes would apply themselues vertue science common treasure maintained father learning well regarin ancient time well ordered thing deuide office order onely also order payed vniuersitie selfe heart taketh great pleasure know condition liues world well done desire procure know liues euill amend owne well done procure know liues good follow shall doe since day euill doe desire know liues euill couer keepe secret doe desire know liues good follow let thee know king cresus phylosophers greece felt much paine vertuous felt defending vitious man behold vertue immediatly suffereth taken euill good man doe vnto neuer suffers themselues vanquished beleeue well tyrannie realm great talke neither oughtest thou likewise beleeue vertuous report mine opinion declare newes strange country poore weare garment al patched peeced wherof peeces sowne new quantitie cloth old first made beware king cresus bee barbarous prince vse good word couer infamy cruel deed maruel though phylosophers reader schooles desire liue prince gouernors realm euil prince none intent seeke company wise men onely would excuse fault thou doest right vulgar people thinke counsel wise man let thee vnderstand king cresus prince desireth gouerne people well ought content haue one onely sage pallace meete gouernement many consist aduise one alone ambassadour hath sayde word selfe thy letter testifieth thou art certified counted sage throughout greece presupposed wold come thee gouerne thy commonwealth contrary thou thus thou doest condemnest mee idiot thou thinking would take thy gold nothing else raile vpon foole chiefe point wherein true philosophy knowne despiseth thing world neuer agreeth together libertie soule care good life king cresus let thee vnderstand hee knoweth wherein consisteth true phylosophy cause element called sage least knoweth vice world true phylosopher profiteth knowing euill learning good let thee vnderstand threescore seuen yeares old yet neuer time reigned ire thy ambassage presented saw layde feete treasure rich vpon deed gather either wisedome lacketh thee great couetousnes aboundeth doe send thee thy gold againe thou sendest rhy ambassadour shall declare witnesse sight greatly hath slandered greece neuer seene heard wise suffer gold enter vniuersitie little phylosophers desire rich athens onely bee dishonour phylosophers greece haue rich also would turne great infamie desire king cresus thou knowest reason thou know schooles greece wee learne command obey speake silent resist humble selues get much content v little reuenge offence pardon iniuries take others giue owne honored trauaile vertuous finally learne despise men loue loue men despise pouertie thou thoughtest would accept thy gold else would thou thoughtest would haue taken thou haddest reason haue receiued afterwards thy palace great infamie couetous man shuld acceptable prince thou thoughtst wold none thou wert wise take pain send prince ought neuer take vpon thing wherein thinke subiects lose honestie receiuing seeking cresus behold diligence litle auayleth search physition afterwards doe nothing ordained meane shall profit rather shall harme come thy commonwealth afterwards thou wilt shall ordaine therein great danger ensue alter humor siropes vnlesse take afterwards purgation purge away redresse thy barbarous realme satisfie thy good desire determined condiscend vnto thy request accomplish thy commandement vpon condition thou shalt ensure mee thing following laborer ought sow seede ground plowed tilled first thou shalt sake euill certaine point required performed physopher custome ye barbarous king dovse say heape vp treasure spend euery prince couetous treasure scarcely capacitie receiue good counsell second thou shalt onely banish thy palace also thy court al flatterer prince friend flatterer necessitie must enemie truth thou shalt end war thou present doest maintaine people corinth euery prince loueth forraine warres must need hate peace commonwealth fourth thou shalt banish thy house iuglers comediants ministrels prince occupieth himselfe heare vaine trifling thing time necessitie shall apply himselfe bee weight importance fiftly thou shalt prouide loyterers vacabonds bee expulsed thy person banished thy palace iidlenesse negligence cruell enemy wisedome sixtly thou shalt banish thy court palace liers seditious men liers suffered palace prince signe king realme falleth vtter destruction seuenth thou shalt promise dayes thy life thou shalt presse receiue thing thee day thou shalt corrupt gift preiudice another euery man seeke owne priuate commoditie manie vaine men raise discentions quarrel amongst people thinking troubled water augment estate short space doe onely lose hope sought also put possessed onely reasonable also iust experience feele blinde malice suffer know much good people gouernours bee vnfortunate nature happy luckie prince fortune giueth many thing euen demand yea giueth better locke prince ought doe noble valiant prince see themselues prince present great act ought shew freenes heart greatnesse realme preheminence person loue commonwealth aboue discipline court grauitie counsell pallace sage curious men behold prince apparrell hee weareth men hath counsell sage men couetous doe employ force heape vp treasure ought remember heart employ themselues spende money well sith fortune mistresse thing doe impute good euill workes hee alone may called princely man contrariety fortune ouercome truly man stout courage whose heart vanquished force fortune though prayse one valiant sword wee therefore prayse excellent penne although hee bee excellent penne hee therefore excellent tongue though haue good tongue hee therefore well learned though hee learned hee hath therfore good renowm thogh hee hath good renowme therefore good life wee bound receiue doctrine many write bound follow liues doe leade worse office amongst men take charge punish vice another therefore man ought fly pestilence correcting vice hatred sure corrector amendment life offender hath possesseth much hath good friend many aide friend would haue holpe could true loue wearyed loue ceaseth profite though sage men haue lost much ought therfore dispaire shall come againe time ende time doth cease doe accustomed alteration perfect friend cease doe ought proud disdainfull man part alwayes falleth euill chaunce therefore commendable medecine time perseecuted aduersitie maketh wise man liue safely walke lesse daunger much wee doe excuse comitteth fault neither offender offence deserueth paine one committeth faulte sudden anger euill hee commit deliberation much worse desire doe thing reason good likewise lay order good harde temperate men haue respect compassing doings weight cast inconueniences scarcely euer determine goe man hath gouernement two thing dangerous say soone late two worst soone determining late man looseth might haue gotten determining soone lost gained man might haue gained men hasty chance daylie manie euills daungers saith old prouerbe hasty man neuer wanteth woe man vnpacient hauing vnderstanding two thing requisite euery man high afterwards come quarrel brawlings displeasure variety also vanity loseth good putteth person danger sith naturally desire bee happie hee alone amongst others may called happie may adulterer greatly much true christian case warie circumspect gentile feared nothing onely infamy true christian ought feare infamie also paine since necessitie man seede must increase wee see men suffer themselues bee ouercome flesh much better maintaine good houshold liue vprightly wife waste theyr good burden theyr conscience concubine oftentimes seene gentleman consumeth abrode vpon harlot shame would keepe wife child home honestie third commoditie marryage third co modity marriage laudable louing companie ought bee betweene matryed anciet philophers defining man saide hee creature nature sociable communicable reasonable wherof followeth man beeing solitarie close condition cannot bee stomacke enuious men loue good inclination doe also commend beast sedicious man resty horse eate wee thinke euill spent sad man sole man man shut solitary profite hee doe people euery man locked vp house commonwealth forthwith perish intention speake vacabonds without taking vpon craft facultie passe age fortie fiftie yeares would marrie yet would vicious day life great shame conscience many men neuer determine themselues take vpon estate neyther bee marryed chaste secular ecclesiasticall corke vpon water swimme whether sensualitie leadeth one laudable holy companyes life companie man woman especiallie woman bee vertuous noble vertuous wife withdraweth sorowes heart husband accomplisheth desire whereby liueth rest wife vertuous husband wise wee ought belieue betweene two true loue one suspect hauing childre midst vnpossible liue concord haue read seene would say wife doe liue quietly together man may cal good maried folk also holy person speake truth yoke matrimony great cannot accomplished without much merite contrarie ought may said euill marryed inconenience loueth maryed feare lord call companie saintes rather companie diuells wise hath euill husband may say shee hath diuell house husband hath euill wife let make account hee hath hell selfe house euill wiues worse infernall fury hell none tormented euill onely euill woman tormenteth good euill concluding therefore matter say also affirme betwixt husband wife wel married true loue onely others may called perfit perpetuall friend parent friendes loue praise v presence hate despise v absence giue v faire word beare v euill heart finallie loue v prosperitie forsake v aduersitie amongst noble vertuous married person loue within without house prosperity aduersitie pouertie rich absence presence seeing themselues merrie perceyuing themselues sad doe truely ought doe husband troubled foote wife ought grieued heart fourth commoditie marriage men woman marryed fourth commodity belonging mariage haue authoritie grauitie others lawes made olde time fauour marriage manie diuers capharoneus lawes hee gaue egyptian comanded ordained vpon grieuous paine man maryed haue office gouernment commonwealth saide hee hath learned gouern house euil gouerne commonwealth according lawes hee gaue athenian hee perswaded commonwealth marry themselues voluntarily head captaines gouerne affaire warre hee commaunded marrie necessitie saying men lecherous god seldome giueth victoryes lycurgus renowmed gouernor giuer lawes lacedemonians commaunded captaines armyes priestes temple bee marryed saying sacrifice marryed men acceptable god worthie saying lycurgus plinie saith epistle hee sent falconius friend rebuking hee marryed declareth romaine olde time law dictatour pretor censour questour knight necessity marryed man hath wife child legitimate house cannot haue hold great authoritie commonwealth plutarche booke made praise marriage saith priest romaine agree vnmarryed come sit downe temple youngmaydens prayed without church dore young men prayed theyr knee temple onely marryed men permitted sit stand plynie epistle hee wrote fabarus father law saith emperor augustus custom neuer suffered yong man presence sitte permitted man marryed tell tale prayse marriage foote plutarch booke hee made praise woman saieth since realme corinth peopled batchelours marryed men ordayned amongst man woman bene marryed also kept child house liued certaine age theyr death buryed goddesse diana manner thee dian whose endles raigne doth stretch aboue bondes heauenly rout eke whose ayde royall hand retch chiefe god proclaimed sweare vnspotted faith protest though till haue reserude breth intent thus distrest wailfull end wreke sinatus death p minde thus decreed whereto pensiue day haue spent longer dole forepassed deed whose oft record newe sorrowes still hath bent oh sinee kindled spite hath slaine tender loue haue waide deere since fate rest fortune raine whose decay dreadlesse perish since onely life led wretched hand gaping earth haue ought wish liue sted closde together graue bright dian since senslesse see makeles remaine alone since graude greedy wormes bee suruiue surmounted fone since prest lumpes wretched soyle thus chargde flame frozen care thou knowst dian hard restles toyle hote abhoring minde life spare vnquiet brest reserue fainting breth striues draw last since euen dying heart starue dead phere swallowing earth cast first blacke day husband sleptin graue cruell sworde life thought spend since thousand time thought haue stretched cord sorrowes wrath end till waste pining dayes haue deferde slaughter hand loe fitter cause raise whereon sharpe reuenge might iustly stand since may full suffising wise redeeme breath wayward would let deepe offence reuenge might rise sinoris erst guiltles bloud get thee therefore mighty ioue iiustly craue eke thy daughter chast thankfull sort loe offering selfe ye haue ye vouchsafe heauenly fort since sinatus soone enflamed eye amongst acaian route chiefly viewed eke amidst prease greekes likewise chose phere sweetly sewed since froth wasting wealth gladsome minde trayned spend since youth slippeth loe stealth waite freely commend since heapes lingring harmes waste aye content wanton youthfull breath fade passe fast glut thirst thus blould spill though great duetie owe vnto graued ghost cindred mould yet loe seemes duety well shew performing feeble power could since vntwined threed guiltlesse life ought purchase breath reason doome conclude ought dreed decay clime step death wretched earth father graued lie deare mother hath runne race life pride loue daunt mine eye wasted good shrunke fortune strife honour soone ecclipsed fate young delight loe done chaunce broken life passed hap hate grieued heart aduaunce remaynes duetie phere refuse loe irksome life willing minde followed eke drere resigne fitteth wife thou sinoris iunos yoke doest craue presse corp feede thy liking lust rout homer god thee grant haue stead royall feates throne dust change costly robe death wife serue husband life seemeth ofttimes proceede feare loue honour graue proceedeth loue princess great lady ought many woman comon people say seeke drinkes inuent shamefull sorcery beloued husband albeit great burden conscience lacke shame like manner vse superstition yet thing vniust slaunderous beloued husband procure hated god truely loue serue content god hurtful woman bee better beloued husband yet god hath suffered doth permit oftimes woman feeble deformed poore negligent bee better beloued husband diligent fayre rich seruices doe husband good intention haue serue loue god defend frailtie woman sayd woman hath body man hath soule man shee hath reason man dyeth man necessary generation man liueth man therefore thought meete shee bee subiect man man reason nature hath made free lawes man made bond said furthermore god created creature augment generation mankinde case woman necessarie man man engendereth without paine trauaile woman deliuered perill danger paine trauaile nourisheth vp childe wherefore seemeth great vnkindnesse crueltie great danger woman sustaine woman deliuered perill danger liues bring vp child labour toyle body bee vsed husband slaues sayd men curse moue sedition make warres maintaine enmitie weare weapon shed man bloud commit sundry mischiefes woman stead killing men shedding bloud notorious euils men imploy themselues encrease men since woman rather men ought haue dominion command commonwealth woman increase comonwealth men diminish neyther diuine humane law commaundeth foolish man bee free gouerne wise woman bee bond serue achaia affirmed opinion groundeth themselues vpon custome achaian reason obserued custome husband obey wiues commaund plutarch sayth booke consolation husband swept made cleane house made bed washed buck couered table dressed dinner went water contrary part wife gouerned good answered affayres kept money shee angry shee gaue onely foule word also oftimes laid hand reuenge anger heereof came ancient prouerb many read vnderstood say vita achaiae life achaian rome husband suffered ruled commanded wife neighbour would say vnto manner reproach vita achaia much man would say goe goe thou art since thou liuest law achaia men haue little discretion suffer themselues bee gouerned bee well euill wiues euery woman commandeth husband plinie epistle hee wrote reprooued greatly friend fabatus hee kept house wife doings ruled commanded wherein hee told hee durst doe nothing without commaundement make matter seeme heynous latter ende epistle sayd word valde poenitet quod tu solus rome polles vita achaia grieueth mee much thou alone rome shouldest leade life one achaia iulius capitolinus saith anthonius caracalla loue faire lady persia seeing could enioy obtayne desire promised marrie according law achaia truly shee shewed selfe wise answere hee demand telling shee would might marry shee promised selfe goddesse vesta rather seruant god mistresse men parthes law parthian law contrary likewise thrace little esteemed woman husband vsed none otherwise like seruants case men great liberty say better lightnesse woman borne brought foorth twelue child child remained house husband sold wiues would giue else changed others young child agreed selling owne mother intent father might refresh himselfe another young olde barren woman eyther buried quicke else serue slaue dionisius halicarnaseus saith lides law numiaians like manner woman law lideans command thing without house man prouide within according poore iudgement cannot tell law kept could fulfill reason wife goe house little therefore think ought command thing abroad husband enter man house commaund licurgus lawes hee gaue lacedemonians saith husband prouide abroad see thing necessary house wiues keepe dispose within good philosopher deuided trauaile betweene man woman yet notwithstanding hee reserued rule authoritie man say truth monstrons thing wife command husband house vnder christian religion neyther diuine humaine lawes preferre man aboue thinges though philosopher would dispute contrary many men would haue followed yet mee thinkes man praise commend opinion bee nothing vaine light man law giue authoritie woman nature denyed see experience woman woman weake nature nature weake fraile fearefull tender finally matter weight wise matter gouernment require onely science experience also strength courage enterprise doubtfull thing wisedome know force execute diligence follow patience suffer meanes endure aboue great strength hope compasse take man gouernment thing abound giue woman whome thing doe want end speake thinges require counsell admonish perswade princcsses great lady thinke spoken happy marriage end obedient husband speaking truth house wife commaundeth husband may call masculine woman feminine man many woman deceiued thinking commanding husband liue honourably better esteemed truely see perceiue accounteth woman vaine man like manner foolish foolish opinion woman know tell right well husband excessiue spending wanton liuing onely good wiues rule also chastise end say notwithstanding better tollerable good lost betweene malice hate discention rise woman child dye shee may bring foorth others lose good may get agayne seruants goe shee may finde others see selfe sad god may comfort sicke may healed shee bee debate husband cannot tell shall doe wife forsaketh friendshippe husband giueth men occasion speake folly sith woman naturally iealous iealousie proceedeth suspition counsell husband commit fault doe anger chafe gage haue heart woman shall haue body hee would abstaine conscience restraine shame oftentimes husband come home chafed troubled wrathfull angry vexed woman ought take heede ouerthwart doe cannot bee otherwise shall haue eyther euill word tongue else suffer sore blowes fist truely meete neither case profitable princess great dame ouerthwart husband froward word vse striue rather wise case obedient louing husband may happen daily doth chance begin argue iest afterward ende earnest woman sage wise vertuous ought weigh selfe eyther husband hath occasion taunte else peraduenture hee doeth say case hee haue occasion shee ought suffer endure doth ought dissemble otherwise might take head shee would burden many euill wordes hee beginning debate remaine excused shee without fault beginning might end condemned nothing wherein woman sheweth wisdome endure rashe husband woman nothing sheweth sagenes dissemble foolish husband honestie nothing bee shewed suffering wanton husband shee shewe worthinesse nothing much bearing vnworthie husband meane though shee vnderstood husband hath little knoweth little worth little yet shee make men belieue hath much knoweth enough propertie wise discreete husband much honour shall giue husband shall wholly againe redounde selfe euill thing mee thinketh woman bolde speake husband cannot speake euill must witnesse dishonour themselues husband drunkard say shee drunkard wife foole wife foole husband shall come amend moderate himselfe woman ende shalbe blamed burden euill wordes hee acquiteth sharpe stripe shee toucheth honour may chaunce taketh away life perhaps husband commaund wife vniust thing would opinion obey resist raging furie past choller qualilified shee might say vnto rash command wise obey shee quicke tongue answere euery worde hee shall speake without doubt wil liue one day co cord reading therefore haue read hearing haue hearde hauing seene also haue seene would counsell woman presume commaund good counsell woman husband would admonish husband would suffer wiues rule contrarie none otherwise eate feete trauel hand go finger feede themselues toe minde heere speake wome princess great lady patrimonie heritage possesse manie townes citties wil take away seruices due vnto subiects doe perswade obedience ought beare theyr husbandes maruell though woman meane estate haue sometimes quarrelled husband haue small rich loose lesse honour aduenture princess great dame haue since aduenture commaund manie wil humble themselues obey one speaking due reuerece aboundance follie want wisedome woman haue presumption gouerne whole realm hath grace obey one husband seneca tragedie saieth thus time warre mithridates chanced rome consulls sent olde knightes commanded readinesse go silla saying consull warres happened came one house rome publish edict warne bee ready found husband wife made answere sayd husband ought could goe warres though hee would hee neither would see giue licence hee old ancient knight therefore hee ought exempted warres answer heard greatly abashed whole senate lesse offended wherefore commaunded husband bee banished rome wife bee carryed prison mamortine excused himselfe going warres commanded husband suffered whervnto inclined much propertie good woman hee merrie shee ought reioyce sad shee must temper herselfe couetous shee keepe hee prodigall spend vnpatient dissemble woman wise sage shee cannot would opinion owne conceit thinke haue counsell enough others others seemeth want follie man themselues right may called foole condemneth others fooles aduaunceth himselfe wise euery man ought let neighbour liue peace though doe esteeme himselfe wise yet hee ought thinke neighbour foole none wise may occupie neuer yet saw man wise himselfe hee needed counsel want olde truely much young whose flesh drie woman carefull fruite increase christian congregation woman brought forth child borne though earth yet bee none people god created thing serue creature created creature serue creator let vvomen childe take example chessenuts walnut sort defend fruite theyr blossom depriued chessenuttree defendeth fruit rough hard huske wallnut keepeth fruite thicke shale like maner water cannot wet winde shake since tree good warning woman childe haue vegetatiue life beast sensitiue life take heede themselues feele ready bring forth fruite much woman child ought take heede themselues since haue reason vnderstanding lest theyr negligence creature perish let euery man iudge little loseth loseth nuttes chessenuts contrarie let euery men iudge church looseth woman child bring forth fruit light baptisme mother holy church bewaileth vine frozen soules lost ende man may see fruitfull blessing hee desireth woman child may see selfe well deliuered husband ought beware hee enforceth much labour woman likewise ought circumspect shee take much idlenes woman child generall rule much trauell causeth theyr time deliuer much idlenesse putteth daunger man cruell haue wife trauell take much paine shee big would another time childe man clothed runne swifte hee naked aristotle sixt booke de animalibus saith lyonnesse bigge whelp lyon doth hunt himselfe also night day wandreth cotinually watch meane princess great aristotle de animalibus ladyes childe bee theyr husband tended serued man cannot woman great pleasure lying doth bringeth forth sonne considering daunger woman abideth deliueraunce beholding paine husband taketh seruice without comparison greater suffereth hee endureth woman deliuereth doth power husband though hee serueth well doeth lesse duetie gentle louing husband ought one moment forsake wife specially hee seeth shee great law good husband written hee set eye beholde handes serue shold spend good cherish giue heart propertie good husband content let men thinke paine serue wiues childe labour consisteth strength trauell wiues entrails pitiful sorrowfull woman discharge burden earth often time bring theselues vnto graue meane woman plebians ought lesse reproued child would exempted businesse house neyther themselues ought desire yet husband suffer idlenesse onely occasion deserue heauen also cause whereby woman oft time haue ill successe trauaile considering daintie lady childe hath pleasure doth little side poore man wife moderately laboureth shall see great ladyes pleasure abideth danger doth labour husband ought keepe wife taking much paynes ought doe wife likewise ought flee much pleasure behoueth meane trauell occasion safe deliuerie woman childe also ought take heede themselues especially noble great lady greedy hasty eating woman child ought sober woman great eater great pain shal liue chaste woman child oft time doe disorder themselues eating licorous meat vnder colour feeding themselues infant take excessiuely onely vnholsome childe also dishonour mother truely excesse mother child commeth many disease infant whe liueth husband also ought neyther displease grieue wiues especially see great childe truth oftentimes deliuereth daunger reason offence men doe vnto aboundance meates doe eate though woman shee childe thing doth offend husband yet hee like wise man ought forbeare hauing respect childe wherewith great iniuries hath committed end reasonable creature may take example vnreasonable mother cannot bee great offender child much innocent proofe needeth book read onely eye see brute beast part female bigge touch yet female suffer touched meane noble high estate ought absent theselues wiues carnally great childe hee case shall shewe himselfe temperate shall men deemed vertuous doe speake ende binde man offence vse companie wife vnto men vertuous giue counsell custome among mauritanian thing ought bee done necessitie others ought eschued honestie dyodorus siculus saieth realme mauritania men many woman euery man fiue wiues law among man marrie vnder three wiues furthermore wonderfull foolish custome husband died one woman shuld cast herselfe quicke graue buried within moneth dyed iustice shee openly put death saying honestie bee companie husband graue alone house isle baleares contrary seene increase many men woman one woman seuen men custome especially amongst poore one woman bee marryed fiue men rich men sent seeke woman strange realmes wherfore merchant came heauie loaden woman doe marchandize sell vpon occasion custome isle much woman woman childe drew neere seuen monethes seperated husband shutte carthage carthage great priuileges sanctuary haue safegard misdoers time past offender could enter house woman lay childbed haue beene free correction iustice fronto saith booke veneration god gallois maintaine good defend euill warres begin throughout world tell mee pisto thing ought father keepe child sayd opinion parent ought nothing watch much keepe vicious father ought rather haue sonne dye well liue euill tell pisto shall man hee brought extremitie speake truth hee condemneth himselfe hee make lye saueth himselfe vertuous man said ought rather choose ouercome truth ouercome lye vnpossible man lyer continue long prosperity tell pisto shall men obtaine rest answered thinke man cannot haue rest vnlesse forsake worldly affayres men occupied weightie affaire cannot without great care alwaies accompanied great trouble tell pisto wherein man sheweth himselfe wise answered greater proofe know wise man patient suffer ignorant suffering iniurie heart holpen wisedome knowledge tell wherevnto emilius answered seneca canst thou tell haue employed good building house haue led thee see haue told thee mine yet dost thou aske againe whose lucius seneca answered thou hast shewed v house stranger house sleues house woman house horse house thou hast shewed one little part thy selfe another man doth enter thou hast interest therein haue best thereof possession account thee wise man doe account thee man vnderstanding allso know thy heart thou art friend since haue beene bidden day reason reward thou hast done doe seruice vnto thee shall giue vnto thee good counsell stranger vse pay feast money vaine men telling lye babbler counting vaine tale child flattery vertuous men ought pay giuing good counsel house hath cost thee much paine great griefes much money cost thee much reason thou enioy take therefore three counsel may thou wilt find thy selfe better contented money stranger many haue wherewithall build house haue vnderstanding gouerne first counsell though lucius seneca counsell thou loue thy friend well thy wife well yet thou neuer discouer secret thy heart neither thy friend thy wife thou alwaies reserue particular vnto thy selfe plato saith whome man committeth secret also hee giueth libertie second counsel neither priuate businesse publike affaire thou occupy thy selfe much least thou dost reserue three houres day thine owne rest third counsell hidest book thy study thou hast giuen thy tender heart flesh thou denyest mee hard key iron must need thinke thy loue fayned thy word double thy thought others seemed otherwise vnpossible thou faustine one thing speake heare say continually haue prooued husband condiscendeth wife desireth causeth wife nothing husband commaundeth nothing keepeth woman vnder obedience husband ofte time denyeth sharpe word vnlawfull request opinion much crueltie barbarous keepe doe theyr wiues like slaues much follie romaine keepe doe like lady flesh ought bee leane eating drie yet fatte leane would participate fatte leane intent might giue nourishment meane man vnderstanding ought keepe wife short shee seeme seruant yet giue much libertie becometh mistresse husband suffereth wife commaund shee ought cause hee himselfe afterwardes esteemed behold faustine woman thing extreame little fauour waxe proude little displeasure become great enemy woman willingly woman endure haue superiours suffer haue superiour yet scarcely endure haue equall see loue highest desire loued lowest louers bee equall loue cannot perfect knowe well faustine thou doest vnderstand mee therefore harken doe tell thee thou thinkest thou wouldest many woman haue seene rome thogh two thousand pound rent head yet three thousand follyes head worst oft time husband dyeth looseth rent yet ceaseth follie listen faustine wil tell thee woman speake others silent wil commaund commanded captiues gouerne gouerned finally one thing agree wil cherish loue reuenge hate said may gathered make fooles slaues young vaine men followe persecute wise men enemy flye ende loue v moste loue may bee measured hate v least hate exceedeth reason annales pompeius remember haue read note one thing worthie knowledge annales pompeyus pompeius great passed first asia chaunce hee came mountaines rypheos found place barbarous nation liued sharpe mountain wild beast doe maruell call beastly liue mountaines sheepe cowes feede fine grasse haue wooll softe fine men brought vp sharp wilde mountain vse themselues rude behauiour barbarous therefore law among euery neighbor mountaines two caues sharpnes hill permitted law among barbarian shold haue house therfore one caue husband sonnes seruants wife daughter handmaid abode eate together twice weeke slept together twice weeke residue time separate one great pompeyus asked cause liued sith world neuer seene read extreame law straunge custome historie saith place auncient man aunswered saying beholde pompeius god haue giuen short life vnto v bee present respect hee gaue father past since liue fortie fiftie yeares vttermost wee desire enioy dayes peace life short trouble long haue smal time reioyce peace returne warres true amongst romaine enioy pleasure rich life seemeth shorte vnto v haue toyle pouertie life seemeth long throughout yeare wee neuer keepe solemne feast one passeth life consider pompeius men liued many yeares shold time laugh weepe bee good euill poore rich merrie sad liue peace warre wil men seek contention life since short keeping v doe owne wiues liuing wee die night passe hearing complaint dayes suffering brawlings keeping doe see heauie countenance wee heare cry child wee heare grieuous complaintes listen vnto sorrowfull word neyther wee troubled importunate suite yet child nourished peace father followeth warres well better aunswer old man gaue request great pompeius truely faustine say though wee call messagetes barbarous case know latines free brawling woman hath escaped small pestilence aske thee faustine since barbarous could agree would haue wiues sharpe mountain shall agree please liue pleasure rome one thing tell thee faustine beseech god thou maiest vnderstand beastly motion flesh notforce men also desire woman doubt whether woman world beloued suffered though nature giueth gift worthie beloued yet smal discretion cause themselues bee hated god made loue voluntarie made naturall might haue loued wee would left againe pleasure man ought worthily haue beene punished loue woman would put life daunger god haue kept great secret vnto themselues misery gaue vnto men great since vnto weake flesh hee gaue strong heart doth procure doth v harme followeth ought abhorre secret men know offend see man seeketh amendment heare complaine flesh yet see like butcher followe flesh least good greedie enuie god liuing men dead saue two thing first enuie god liue without feare malicious secondarily enuie dead liue without neede woman woman corrupt corrupt mortall plague flesh heart brought ende faustine loue flesh natural flesh body flyeth sport wee leaue heart engaged earnest thogh reason reason putteth desire fleight yet flesh flesh yeeldeth selfe prisoner chap xxvi p emperour following matter admonisheth men great daungers ensue vnto excessiue haunting company woman reciteth certaine rule marryed men obserue may cause liue peace wiues remember youth flesh trembled seare flesh minde neuer returne againe confesse ofte time reuolued heart many holie chaste meditation yet notwithstanding gaue bodie immediately sundry filthie vice naturall thing man hath committed vice forthwith repenteth deede frailty man againe new repentance turneth olde vice time wee liue fraile flesh sensualitie beareth great rule shee suffer reason enter gate man rome man doth aske wil maruelto declare tongue fraile flesh somwhat blame much foolish light woman faulte men certaine woman chast shamefast solitary would dispose heart bodyes bende theyr bowes shoote butte would consume time folow loose good thought seruices pleasure may content woman let know know woman neuer contented woman neuer contented though man doth hee maid ought husband though taketh painesfor sake aboue force though sweat yeares haue bin married mee thinketh haue passed vj hundreth yeares life nothing bee called torment euil man doth suffer euill married assure thee one thing faustine knowne knowe felt feele though god comanded emperour adrian lorde desired mee chaunged pouerty thy rich neither rest thy empire since fallen thine mine euill fortune contented speake little suffer much haue much dissembled thee betweene two brother haue diligently read holy prophane writing many tyrant haue caused owne mother bee killed bare could neuer find haue done discourtesie disobedience nurse gaue milke cruell tyrant haue gouernment house child shall kept obedience might abuse themselues young men youth feele trauailes life know yet meaneth make prouision household stomacke full cloyed eating meates seeme vnsauory noysome may well bee since child nourished house know seruants loue parent come neere brother talke sister ignorant father doe disobey mother wherefore since little feare doth abound good fayle one day commit mischieuous offence wherby doe lose life worthily father lose rich likewise honour deseruedly intent father alwaies dutie required betweene parent childe keepe proper child vnder obedience better meane bring vp owne house mother giue sucke father teach mother desireth thing childe shee shew belly whence hee came dugges hee sucke asked v milke sucke truely heart hard deny historiographer hee deuoureth one paste others doe one day case antipater greece nero rome determined kill owne mother historiographer say nero commanded mother killed sent aske would put death whereunto answered hee child get immortall infamy nothing wieked detestable child kill mother beare paine nourish loue notwithstanding doe read euer kill dishonour yet disobey nurse gaue milke iunius rusticus fift booke nurse gaue sucke nurse hee gaue girdle gold owne mother gaue iewell siluer thing mother ashamed considering son done asked hee giuen nurse gold giue suck giuen girdle gold well iewell siluer since shee born brought world whereunto answered manner maruell thereat mother doe thing thou didst beare nine moneths thy wombe shee hath giuen mee sucke nourished mee three yeeres owne proper pappes thou diddest cast mee thee thy sight shee receiued mee nourished mee proper armes fifthly woman ought enforce themselues nourish child reason may moue woman giue child sucke end may keepe better cradle woman giuing childre suck danger may come health person woman bring forth child doe liue healthfull beare none doe nourish haue health doe nourish although bringing vp child troublesome woman yet profitable health ashamed tell shame ladyes see plaisters put theyr breast drie vp milke hereof commeth iust iudgements god place ofte time seeke stoppe milke selfe place themselues pocure theyr profite phylosophers say wolfe one beast denoureth greedyest therefore hee feared shepheards aristotle third booke de animalibus saith whe wolfe doeth feele selfe great young life shee neuer aristot de animalib suffereth herselfe bee coupled wolfe againe otherwise wolfe shold yearely bring forth vij viij whelp commonly doth sheepe one lambe would short space wolues sheepe beside wolfe hath propertie although beast deuouring greedie yet hath whelped feedeth temperately ende nourish whelp haue good milke besides doth eate day dogwolfe doth prouide bitch whelp truly monstrous thing see giuen keepe wherefore consull heereof aduertised notwithstanding gaue daughter suck commanded knight shold immediatly beheaded louer sabina forthwith cast wel day execution came party suffer wherfore wofull sabina sent beseech consull would please death giue audience one sole worde shee would speake vnto beeing come presence shee said vnto gneus fuluius know thou call thee ende thou shouldest graunt life would die seene thy face though thou thy selfe shouldest remember frayle speech sabina woman fell sinne thee capua might fall haue done another rome wee woman fraile case time miserable life none keepe herselfe sure assaultes weake flesh consull gneus fuluius word answered god immortall know sabina griefe wofull hart secret offence answer consull fuluius open scourge greater honestie men hyde frailnesse openly punish offence wilt thou doe case considering offence thou hast committed immortall god sweare vnto thee sweare rather thou shouldest secretly haue procured death man openly wise thou shouldst haue slaunderd house thou knowest true meaning common prouerbe rome better die honour liue infamie think sabina condemne thee die thou forgotest thy faith vnto person thou gauest thy selfe vnto kept thee since thou wert wife liberty thou haddest come capua rome selfesame thou hadst goe another rome capua euill thing vicious e reprooue vice others wherein themselues faulty cause condemn thee dye onely remembrance old law commandeth nurse woman giuing sucke paine death begotten childe truly law iust honest woman suffer giuing child sucke breast shold hide another
