hedgehog ende child might fierce cruell caligula hee contented kill man onely also hee sucked bloud remained sworde licked tongue excellent poet homer meaning speake plainely crueltyes pyrrus saide odisse wordes pyrrus borne greece nourished archadie brought vp tygers milke cruell beast plainely saide pyrrus borne greece sage hee brought vp archadie strong couragious haue sucked tygars milke proud cruell hereof may gathered great grecian pyrrus wanting good milke ouercome euill condition selfe hystorian dyon saith life tiberius hee great drunkard cause hereof nurse onely drinke wine also weyned childe soppes dipped wine required nurse bringing vp child without doubt cursed woman done lesse euill stead milke giuen child poyson without teaching drinke wine wherefore afterwardes lost renowne truely romane empire lost little tiberius dyed childe wonne much neuer knowne drinking wine meant haue declared mentioned intent princess great ladyes might aduertised since nourishing child shew themselues cruel yet least prouiding good nurse shold shew themselues pittifull child oft time follow condition milke sucke condition mother brought forth father begot therefore ought vse much circumspection herein consisteth fame wiues honour husband wealth child chap xxii disputation alexander great concerning time sucking babe ovintus curtins saith great alexander last king macedonian first emperour greekes ouercome king darius saw himselfe onely lord asia went rest babylon among men warre custome beene long warres euery one retire owne house king philip father king alexander alwayes counselled sonne leade warres required good captaine valiant captaines conquere world realmes dominion hee take chuse wisest men best experimented gouerne empire hee reason wise counsell sonne counsell sage kept maintained strength valiant men gotten wonne alexander great therefore babylon hee conquered countrey since citie vicious armie long without warres owne men began robbe one another others play force woman others make banquet feast wee drunk others raysed quarrel strife discentions man could tell whether greater rust armour corruption customes propertie man malice gate open idlenesse infinite vice enter house alexander great seeing dissolution armie losse might ensue heereof vnto great empire commanded straightly make shew iust thorow babylon alexander gouerned armie end glory vertues feared hell dye turney commandement alexander iust armie defaced vice waste himselfe got perpetuall memory also cause much suertie commonweale good prince contented exercise army ordayned daily presence philosopher dispute question wherein dispute alexander himselfe would propound whereof followed great alexander made certaine wherein hee doubted wisedome men exercised craft doth weepe two houres profiteth onely health body also prolong life furthermore philosopher sixt asked many twigges like rosemary bed side whereunto indian aunswered know thou india olde plague wee shipping hauen ostia read letter thine neyther haue seen yet man thy house yea moreouer could tell mee whether thou wert aliue dead wherefore thy friend imagine mishap befallen thee thy ship else misliking country thou shouldest returne againe men doe sayle thou goe alwayes dangar drowned tempest doe escape despayre strange countrey tolitarinesse saw fronton thy seruant ioyfull much vnderstood thou wert aliue thy great trauell truely receiued great pleasure thou writest thy letter thou art contented countrey mee strange thing man beeing nourished delitiousnesse rome finde himselfe contented strange realme nation rome rome italy named great greece thither came sort people nation learne vertues noblenesse rome flourished others giue themselues vice pleasure titus liuins deceyue mee rome spent treasure asia asia employed vice delicatenes rome thou writest mee thy letter many thinges fronton thy seruant hath tolde mee many newes land immortall god sweare vnto thee cannot tell write vnto thee aunswere thy seruant straunge newes doe please eares hearing much doe seeme bee vncredible noble stout personage though would bee esteemed iudged true saying hauing seene many wonder eye yet come count ought bee moderate tongue shame honest circumspect man ought bee speake truth man declare thing wherein may bee doubt whether bee true briefly answere al thing thy letter answere shall bee according thy desire according perceyue thee world beginne beseech thee penne shall erre writing thy heart pardon mee thy yeares yet doe let thee know world white hayres hoarie beard doth giue mee authority aduertise thee come condemne thee past thou sayest sea thou hast past many peril danger lighten shippe thou diddest cast much thy good sea case thinketh thou oughtest greatly thanke tempestuous waues hauing power drowne thee contented themselues thy marchandize sayle vpon foming sea ought regarde much good loose life saue thou sayest sea thou werte greatly accompanyed passenger thou hast tarryed longer thy voiage thou thoghtest diddest desire say vnto thee friend dedalus though dayes manie thou diddest stay yet notwithstanding griefes thou receyuedst vnpossible men sayle much troubled marriners also feare tempest aunswere thee thou wert loaden companyons lesse thy money weighed general rule iourney long companie great purse necessitie must needes wexe thinne thou sayest moysture sea soone thou wert landed thou diddest feele thy selfe taken goute answere thee thou hast gout thy foot else thy property belongeth goute hand thou hast thy feete shall occasion thou shalt keepe thy house thou hast thy hand shall bee occasion thou shalt play table thou werte wont doe also thou shalt waste thou hast done thy owne money thou hast changed thy codition thou haddest assured onely encrease thy good thou wilt thinke thy goute welcome thou sayest countrey thou hast found many soueraigne expert physitians remedy thy disease answere plato sayeth countrey many physitians many vice many vicious man excessiue delicatenes commeth sicknesse meane trauell hee healed long auncient father without physitians rome foure hundred yeares long shewed selues sober eating drinking euen temperance health proceedeth physicke proceedeth gluttonie thou sayest country verie fertile amongst thing much wood lacke rome answer thou hast much wood thou hast little bread ancient prouerbe fire great barnes thou sayst thou art content wood country let thee know discontented bread italy ende man shall sooner finde wood heate euen corne carrie ill truly good thing haue woode winter better haue corne winter summer call hunger wood lacked aged bread wanteth young thou sayest country many water water verie cleare cold aboundance thereof euery house hath fountain answere thee water doe abound wanteth health continually doe maruell thereat moyste dankish place alwayes daungerous vnhealthfull noysome beene time golden world men know wine meant dranke water without comparison countrey would haue beene better drunkennes wine infamous sweeter profitable water thou knowest well fountaine haue gardaine streete salaria occasion one time seuen house dyed together made conduit voyde standing water thinke made ende mee family wherfore pray thee haue respect vnto health thy person rather enioy freshnes water part thinke onely happie hath bodie healthfull heart ease prayse much land enioy thou freshnes thereof much thou canst fill thee fresh cold water write vnto thy friend plentie end sweare vnto thee deare friende dedalus money shall issue rome buye wine candia butte immediatly thou put away thy house suffer wicked woman eate bread one day euery creature nourished sorcery charmes shal eyther haue life short else fortune shall contrarie vnto let thee know friend sicke euill humor healthful god wil take life case disease proceed euill humour let aske physitions naturall medicine disease come god god onely physitian prouoked let father appease god sacrifice end vnpossible disease heart healed meanes medicine bodie doe maruell friend dedalus haue spoken article others say perswade thee much keepe thy child witch otherwise cursed woman doe harme good milke shal profite haue beene moued prouoked write thus much vnto thee great loue beare thee also calling minde thou sacred senate oft time toldest thou diddest desire sonne since thou hast thy petition would thou shouldst prouoke god wrath sorcery faith good man doe sweare vnto thee father fauour god needeth sorcery vnto child manie thing write vnto thee comunicate thy seruant fronton rather send letter maruel letter perillous man wise hee wil write close letter would declare openly rome pardon friend dedalus though indeede write vnto thee thy appetite would yet desireth thou hast need know many thing haue leaue letter put thee trust therewith cannot tell write vnto thee alwayes goute doth take worst growe yeares health diminisheth old course man frailtie wee thinke goe surest haue let mutabilitie man life popinjay thou didst send soone receyued wife seaze truely maruellous pleasure heare thinges doth speak end woman power wil impose silence liuing cause graues dead men speake speaking one word let bee little esteemed lightly passed ouer worldly malice condition man may easily speake foure houres another man shal haue patience heare one minute antonius sobellicus declareth time amilcares affrican philosopher named afronio flourished great carthage yeares dyed first yeere war punica demaunded philosopher knew answered knew nothing speake well demaunded againe hee learned answered hee learne nothing speake well another time demaunded hee taught hee answered taught nothing speake well thinketh good philosopher fourescore yeares one said learned nothing speake well hee knew nothing speake well taught nothing speake well truely hee reason thing adorneth man life sweet pleasant tongue speake well see two men one counsell one talking one hath euill grace propounding excellent speaking hearing talke three houres wee would neyther troubled wearied contrary part others tedious rude speech soone men perceiue beginne speake auoyde place therefore mine opinion greater trouble hearken one quarter houre rude man speake contrary greater pleasure heare discreete man though whole weeke diuine plato booke lawes sayde nothing whereby man known word speaketh opinio plato wordes heare speake iudge intention eyther bee good euil laertius life phylosopher saieth young childe borne athens brought vnto socrates great phylosopher athens ende receyue companie teach schoole yong childe strange shamefast durste speake maister wherefore phylosopher socrates sayd vnto speake friend thou wilt know thee sentence socrates profound pray shall reade writing pause thereat socrates man known gesture hath good euill wordes speaketh though eloquence speaking well euery man cause augmenting honour diminisher good yet without comparison shineth much necessary pallaces princess great lord men haue common office ought necessity hearken naturall countrimen also speake stranger speaking therefore plainely say prince ought trauell onely haue eloquence honour person also behoueth commonwealth prince one serued vnpossible hee haue much satisfie content therefore necessary hee requite money hee content others good word noble heart loueth better gentle worde reward gift pleasure see v remaine victorious end daungers inconueniences cruell warres great euill danger certain vanquished profite doubtfull haue ouercommed would gladly yee yee would haue willed sooner yee require demaund yee required demanded shall doe since ordayned wofull destiny hee lose battell wee losse take profite rule vnfallible god haue ordayned worldly wight auoyde humane power resist yee demaund warre may leaue cease wee take truce three monethes duriyg time peace concord may concluded wee make answere senate athens hath accustomed grant peace afterward returne warre amongst v athenian wee haue ancient law freely wee doe accept cruell warre liberally doe graunt perpetuall peace schooles vniuersities trauell haue sage time peace help v counsel time warre doe counsell v wee neuer take vpon v truce vpon suspect condition indeed counsell v well fayned dissembled peace much perillous manifest warre philosopher heuxinus ambassadour hath spoken v highly eloquently senate seemed v vniust wee deny gainesay hee requireth v much honesty grant peace sweet pleasant word doth demaund force sharpe sword doth require let case therefore senate people sage athens haue ordained warre doe cease lacedemonians discordes contention dissentions debate doe end perpetual peace bee granted vnto thing done end world know athens courage hardie friend sage knoweth punish foolish captaines suffereth bee commanded gouerned sage phylosophers yee know right well warre hath onely possession city limit riuer milina wherefore letter wee declare vnto immortall god wee sweare wee doe renounce vnto al right condition leaue v heuxinus ambassadour philosopher great athens desireth rather philosopher schooles whole prouince realmes lacedemonians thinke wee athens doe light foolish say wee desire rather one man rule haue whole prouince whereby wee may commaund many philosopher shall teach v liue well land gaue v occasion dye euill sith wee old enemy become true friendes onely giue perpetuall peace also counsell keepe medicine preserueth health greater excellency purgation healeth disease let counsell therefore bee yee young men doe exercise themselues weapon yee doe watch see child time doe learne good letter euen warre cruell sword followed likewise pleasant word peace obtained thinke yee lacedemonians without cause perswade put child learne yet young tender yee doe suffer runne vice one part wise men shall want counsell fooles shall abound make debate atbenians like manner yee lacedemonians doe thinke wee bee friend bablers father socrates ordained first lesson desire see parent rome maruell loue naturall country doth giue strange country cannot take away come party doe bring v certaine newes multitude die slaine affricke therefore since send v news thence looke send like hence death hath authority killeth armed warres slayeth quiet peace let know licia sister dead drusio vnckle dead torquatus neighbour dead wise cosen daughter dead fabius great friend wormes meat full low vnder earth death also doth summon vnto graue child consider vncertainety man life shall become hereafter truely thinke better weepe thousand yeares dead laugh one houre aliue remembring bare yee great paine haue nourished great trauel yee came proper entrailes would haue child comfort consolation paine end beholding prowess past bindeth heires content suffer long absece enuy enuy vicious neyther desire bee among vice truly vice condition bring much pleasure leaue sorrow behind true delight pleasure suddenly vanisheth truth euer remaineth thanke god thing first made wise foolish woman smal matter called fraile indeed bee foolish second thank god time trouble haue giuen patience endure man onely life may called vnhappie god trouble giueth patiece thanke god year haue liued neuer hitherto defamed woman reason complaine fortune none trouble shee hath lost honour fourth thanke god fortie yeares haue liued rome remained widow neuer man woman contended mee since woman little profite commonwealth reason shee euill demeanor hath passed life iustice receiue death fifth giue god thankes gaue child better contented suffer trauells affrike enioy pleasure rome doe count child vnlouing mother would haue alwaies mine eye considering many good men child haue lost onely brought vp excessiue pleasure rome doe content selfe absence man desireth perpetuall renon though hee bee banished hee ought absent himselfe natiue countrey deare childre earnestly desire alwayes accompanie selues good auncients graue expert counsell haue seene world doe vnderstand world haue seene countreys ripe councell proceedeth man hath trauelled many countreys hath selt himselfe many daungers since nature countrey child doth knocke hamer heart man feare come see friend parent shall alwayes line care pensiuenes pensiue shall alwayes liue euill contented shall becometh romane knight valiaunt knight enemyes shall alwayes reioyce ouer desire shal neuer take effect men carefull heauy proceedeth alwaies seruices vnworthie desire heartily present letter counsell wise seeke come rome haue saide shall know know eyther dead banished poor sick aged come nought sad euill contented sithence able remedie griefes best come hither see trouble man cometh rome weepe liuing sigh dead truly child know pleasure rome shold cause good man come hither forsake affrike haue enemy shal want friend haue sword pierceth body haue togue destroyeth renowme vexed thieues affrike wee wounded traytours flatterer lyars italie lacke rest haue much commendation warlike men trouble finally seeing vertuous men may knowe much profiteth bring vppe child trauels bring vp pleasure imagine shall reade prayse well written also trust giue childre much owne wils men reade much worke little belle doe found call others themselues neuer enter church father esteeme seruice doe vnto god owne honour profite owne child yet preserue disease ought bring vp vertue withdraw vice truly child haue beene brought vp daintily shall alwayes diseased sickly thing see sonne labourer coate without point shirt tattered torne foot bare head without cap body without girdle summer without hat winter without commendation labouring man cloke day plowing night driuing heard eating bread rye otes lying earth else straw trauell see yong man holy vertuous euery man desireth wisheth hee sonne contrary commeth noble men sonnes wee see nourished brought vp betweene two fine holland sheetes layed costly cradell made new fashion giue nurse desire perchance child sicke change nurse else appoint dyet father mother sleepe neyther night day house watcheth let eate nothing broth chicken keepe diligently hee fall stayres child asketh nothing giuen immediately finally spend time seruing wast rich giuing delight occupy eye behold employ heart loue sweare father wise doe spend rich pamper shall one day water eye bewaile see waste vaine man maketh bringing vp childe specially hee man somewhat aged desire hath childe borne spendeth much good bringing vp wantonly while young oft time wanteth marrie hee commeth age worst hee spendeth employeth thinketh well bestowed thinketh much hee giueth god sake though father large spending mother curious nurse full pleasaunt seruaunts diligent attentiue yet followeth child shold hole others attended diseased eate weake reioyce worse prosper waste spend another certainely doth cannot erre none owne counsell aboundeth much hee needeth counsel opinion another though prince great lord see eye haue chose good master tutor teach child yet ought therefore deceyued king cebalus thinke thou ouercamest emperor thou hadst ouercome romanes romulus founded rome god ordained though emperour dyed battell yet notwithstanding bee thought empire ouercome marcus aurelius emperour one day going senate house sayde vnto maruell thee excellent prince thou doest dishenherite thy sonne speech senator emperour eldest make thine heyre youngest knowing thy sonnes god haue giuen thee good father bound chasten child haue licence dishenherite emperour marcus aurelius answered thou wert greeke philosopher thou ort romane citizen thou knowest tke father emperours answere loue towards child thou wouldest take pitty sonne vndoeth empire thou shouldest haue compassion father doth dishenherite child scarcely knoweth hee looseth father doe bewayle dammage doe vnto end world cruell father sonne bee hurt pomell sword hand father would feele incontinently dent blade heart case sweare vnto thee immortall god would doe take would take anthonius lord father law gaue mee empire cause hee neuer found mee lye occasion doe depriue sonne neuer found truth meete empire beeing giuen vnto true bee left heritage lyer ende better sonne doe loose heritage father much giuen play tennis vice hee onely admonished secretly also forbidden openly cicero sayeth booke lawes emperour noted open vice might boldly reproue open senate octauian vice reproued senate sayde others rude men profession though good stile cannot declare would vtter yet notwithstanding wee ignorant ought allowed good ought bee condemned euill would say therefore case euill tyranie haue gathered many day god shall take one howre contrariwise good shall loose manie yeares god restore one minute speaking truth euill prosper rich god doe suffer though houre wee complaine dissembling wee suffer much time shall come pay beleeue mee one thing romanes doubt therein vnlawfull gaines father followeth iust vndoing child many oftentimes doe maruell countrey cause god doe take wicked winne immediately soone winne thinke reason hereof dissembling little little gather together diuers thing afterwardes thinke least thereon taken iust iudgement god since without reason haue done euill others others reason come like manner doe euill vnto vpossible valiant sage man deed presumeth bee wise take taste man good hee hee would neuer content himselfe thing sith hee hath conscience euil gotten know romanes whether vnderstand shall vnderstand mee better say maruell rather wonder man keeping another man good sleepe rest one houre sith hee knoweth hee hath done iniury god slaundered neighbour pleased enemy lost friend endamaged hee robbed worst hee hath put person perill say hee hath put person perill day man determineth take good hee also day hee taketh away another man good putteth life also peril hee take life odious thing god slaunderous among men men haue much fleshly desire vertue bound reine euill work much liberty another man misery seemeth rich rich seemeth himselfe pouerty care whether greeke barbarian romaine present absent say affirme shall bee cursed god hated men without consideration chaunge good fame shame iustice wrong right tyranny truth lye certaine doubtfull hating owne proper sighing men hee hath chiefe intention gather goodes child seeketh good name among renowmed iust one doe loose good hee hath gathered also without good name hee remaine shamefull among wicked since romaine naturally proude pride doth blinde thinke selues happy hauing much haue others therfore bee honoured truly presently open eye confesse owne error shall see wheras auant selues lord strange country shall find yourselus made slaues proper good gather much let doe doe commaund yet thinke little auaileth haue plebeian house good contrariwise heart bee possessed couetousnesse rich gotten couetousnesse kept auarice take away good name possessor nothing auaile maintaine life cannot bee suffered many dayes much lesse hidde many yeares one man counted rich among rich honoured among honorable vnpossible hee great louer temporall good friend good name couetous men owne honour greedy good another desirous sweare vnto immortall god little worme moth couetousnes would gnaw rest life canker infamie destroy good name death hearken yee romanes hearken wil say beseech god may vnderstand wise loose labour yee others take fruit wordes see world hateth pride yet none follow humanity euery man euery man giuen one sinne condemneth adultery yet see man liueth chaste euerie man curseth excesse see man liue temperately euery man prayseth patience see man suffer euery man blameth sloth see man idle euery man blameth auarice yet euery man robbeth one thing say without teares senate openly declare tongue euery man prayseth vertue yet themselues al lims seruants vnto vice doe thinke say onely romanes bee illyria senator see senate romanes deuises armes haue word romanorum est debellare superbos et parcere subiectos truely better haue sayde romanorum est spoliare innocentes et reddere subiectos romanes destroyer people bee peaceable robber swette labour stranger chap iiii villaine argueth romaine without cause reason conquered countrey proued manifestly thorow offending god vanquished romanes aske ye romanes occasion yee villain continueth oration wherein hee layeth open tyranny oppression romanes germanes haue brought vp nigh riuer tiber v liue peace nigh riuer danuby peraduenture haue seene v friend foe else wee haue shewed selues enemy peraduenture haue heard say forsaking owne land wee goe conquere forraine realmes peraduenture haue beene aduertised wee rebelling lord shold become obedient cruell barbarian peraduenture yee haue sent v ambassadour desire v friend else came v rome defie enemy peraduenture king dyed realme testament made heyres vnto realme whereby clayme title seeke make v subiects peraduenture ancient law custome yee haue found noble worthy germany necessity subiect proude people rome peraduenture wee haue destroyed army wee haue wasted field sacked city spoyled subiects fauoured enemy reuenge iniuries yee destroy land wee bin neighbour maruell though one haue destroyed chaunceth oftentimes controuersie little peece ground tedious warres betweene people arise truth none thinges haue named hath chaunced betweene ye romains v germains germany wee felte tyranny soone wee heard renowne yee bee grieued haue sayde pray bee offended say name romanes cruelty tyrant arriued together one day vpon people say know romanes litle care god doe take great audacitie men haue see hee possesseth much doth oppresse hath little hath little wayeth hath much disordered couetousnesse striueth secret malice secret malice giueth place open theft open robbery man resisteth thereof commeth couetousnesse malitious man accomplished preiudice whole state hearken yee romanes hearken immortall god doe coniure giue care say consider well haue done good wordes bee vaine else men must haue end world time must needes fall else world shall world fortune must need make sure pinne wheele else shall bee seene neuer seene eight yeares ye haue wonne yee shall within eight dayes lose nothing bee iust since yee force haue made selues tyrant god iustice make slaues doe thinke romanes though haue subdued germany bee lord thereof warlike industry ye warlike couragious hardy ne yet valiant wee germaines since offence wee haue prouoked god wrath punishment disordinate vice ordained ye cruel plague scourge person take selues strong neither repute v bee weake god time fauoured one part much might perchance haue happened yee haue enioyed spoyle say truth yee wanne victory force weapon brought rome infinite vice yee found germany therefore since wee ouercome coward neyther weake yet beeing fearefull onely wicked hauing god fauourable vnto v hope yee romanes become beeing vicious hauing god angrie doe thinke romanes victorious ye assemble great army yee abound treasure neither haue greater god ayd yee build greater temple yet yee offer great sacrifice let know doe know man fauour god peace vertue triumphes conquerours consisteth nothing else subtill wittes politique captain valiant souldiers great army without doubt would little auayle carry warre since afterwardes wee see experience man may giue battell god must giue victorie men doe giue battels god themselues must giue victory deceyued thinke offence haue sufficiently satisfied god wrath truely beleeue cruelty yee haue done vnto v vnthankfulnesse haue shewed god though yet yee haue payed yet yee shall pay hereafter may chance presently yee count v slaues time come yee shall acknowledge v lord since trauelling way haue seene high mountaines diuers prouinces sundry nation country sauage people barbarous many mile germany distant rome muse fond toye came romanes head send conquer germany couetousnesse treasure caused sure spent money conquer present doe spende keepe whole reuenues germany amounteth may amount many yeares perchaunce may lose recouer spent conquer yee say vnto romanes germany conquered rome euer onely rome haue glory mistresse germany also say vanitie folly little auayleth haue fort castle people heart inhabitant absent yee say therefore yee conquered germany amplifie enlarge limit bound rome also mee thinketh foolish enterprise point wise valiaunt men enlarge dominion diminish honour ye say ye sent conquere v end wee barbarous liue like tyrant would wee liue good lawes customes bee well content possible yee giue lawes straungers yee breake lawes owne predecessours great shame ought haue take vpon correct others haue neede bee corrected themselues blinde man ought take vpon leade lame true presently reason occasion prowde rome take conquer innocent germanes let v go therfore robbe kill conquer spoyle since see world corrupt farre loue god euery man may perceyue taketh killeth hee worste neyther gouerne remedie manie euills committed neyther offended dare complaine ye chiefe iudges day harde intreated yee take little iniury done wher iustice neglected regard vnto poore oppressed thinke quiet remaine trouble home come put vp complaintes rome cause hereof theyr countrey haue one pursueth heere senate euill willed hee complaineth poor complained rich therefore since fortune would fatall destiny permit proud rome mistresse germanie reason ye keepe v iustice maintaine v peace doe rather come thither doe take v good yee heere doe robbe v good name saying since people without law without reason without king vnknowne barbarous yee may take v slaues case ye romaine greatly deceyued thinketh reason ye cannot call v without reason since wee god created v remaine proper countreys without desiring seeke invade forreine realmes reason wee might say yee men without reason contented sweet fertile italie shedding bloud desire conquer earth yee say wee deserue slaues haue prince command v senate gouerne v armey defende v answere since wee enemy needed armeys sith euery man contented lotte fortune wee necessitie proude senate gouerne v equall neede apologie viilaine wee consent haue prince amongst v office prince suppresse tyrant maintaine people peace yee say wee haue countrey commonwealth pollicie wee liue beast mountaines also haue small reason countrey suffer lyers neyther rebells seditious person men broght v strange countreys apparell vicious sith apparell honest meate temperate wee needed better behauiour though countrey merchaunts carthage oyles mauritania marchants tyre steele cantabria odour asia gold spaine siluer britaine amber sidonie silke damasco corne scicill wine candie purple arabia yet brutish neyther cease haue commonwealth like thing giue occasion stirre vp many vice vertuous men liue according vnto others though yee heare oppression yet thereby lose pastime wee others neuer drye teares eye ceale bewayle infinit misfortune chap v villaine concludeth oration iudges minister iustice declareth romanes germanes heart doe ye know haue done ye romains yee haue caused v miserable realme sweare neither dwell wiues sley owne child rather leaue handes wicked cruell tirants yee desperate men haue determined suffer endure beastly motios flesh time haue liue ende wee get wiues child rather liue chast yeares leaue childre perpetuall slaues true child must endure miserable father doe suffer onely good sley also bee better agree shold borne ye ought doe romanes lad taken force ought better bee gouerned intent miserable captiues seing iustice duly administred presently thereby forget tyrannie reforme euil custome whole commonwealth already vndone tell thing therof thintent may know reforme come right poore man demaund iustice hauing money giue wine present oyle promise friend helpe calidanus citizen extream poore truly great perill see experience rich officer much subiect pleasure poore officer much giuen auarice hee said case thinketh iudges yee ought chuse bee extreame poore want wherewith care neither rich surmount superfluity giue themselus much pleasurs men great aboundance become vitious great scarcitie become couetous censor cato beeing authoritie reason wee giue credite word since hee gouerned romane empire long space though deed poore bee couetous rich vitious yet hee spake intent roman noted two vice poore desire scrape scratch rich enioy keepe two sortes men prince chuse cannot dare rashly determine therefore doe counsell eyther despise poore cato aduise choosing officer chuse rich giue authoritie iustice know bee good conscience subiect couetousnesse iudge whose conscience corrupted vnpossible hee minister equall iustice man may giue shrewde guesse suspition iudge whether hee bee brittle conscience hee see procure office iustice himselfe man willingly procureth charge conscience another commonly little regardeth burthen owne chap vii letter emperour marcus aurelius wrote antigonus friend answering another hee sent scicile wherein hee aduertised cruelty romane iudges letter diuided v chapter marcus aurelius companion empire tribune people presently letter marcus aurelius friend antigonus sicke wisheth vnto thee antigonus health comfort banishment flye extreame heate rome reade bookes brought mee realme palestine come hither capua haste made ride great iourneyes ague hath ouertaken troublesome perillous taketh cold plucketh appetite day ianuary receyued thy second letter hapned thy letter feuer tooke mee one instant feuer grieeued wise could long endure reade thy letter mee thinketh wee haue stay meane thou beeing briefe long long letter hath taken thy grieuous sorrow mee thy short letter could take feuer mind beating thy trauell desire haue remedy enflamed would tel thee one thing succor thee som counsel find consolation thou wantest cannot giue thee giue thee thou needest letter shall written first herein trauell best answer thee wil occupie self comfort thee course disease haue neyther write ne yet fauour pleasant thing perhaps letter bee sauoury compendious neither comfortable wot write vnto thee attribute blame vnto good desireth serue thee sicknes giueth place thereunto sufficeth sicke contented medicine without satisfying theyr friendes thy comfort consisted writing many letter offering thee many word truely would sticke doe feuer neither profiteth thee satisfieth mee since haue little proffer thee much talking matter doe remember ancient lawes rhodians sayd word desire admonish men visite captiues pilgrimes comfortlesse ancient lawes obserued among rhodians ordaine commaund none common wealth hardy giue counsell vnlesse therewith hee giue remedy troubled heart word comforteth little remedy truth law rhodians good romane shall obserue much better assure thy self desirous see thee also know thou wouldest gladly speake vnto recount mee thy griefes truely doe maruell wounded heart quieteth himselfe declaring owne griefes hearing another man consolation thou writest vnto sudry thing thy letter effect whereof thou certifiest iudges officer realme bee rigorous extreame therefore cicilians greatly displeased senate hitherto thou hast neuer tolde mee lye moueth beleeue thou writest thy letter wherefore take thing true forasmuch cicill malitious enuious giue iudges fitte occasion bee cruell generall rule men order minister iustice ought bee rigorous though realm chaunced beleeued true realme whereof ancient prouerbe sayth inhabite isle euill cicilians worst day wicked mighty malice good much diminished vertues iustice bridle wicked would surmount al world good vanish immediately returning matter say considering many euils wee enuironed many misery wee subiect doe maruell vanity men commit ashamed cruelty iudges execute wee may rather call tyrant kill violence iudges minister iustice one thing greatly astonied almost past sense iustice right pertayneth god onely true udge god offended bee called pittifull wee others borrow iustice beeing offended doe glorifie selues called cruell know man hurt another since wee see god forgiuing proper iniuries haue obtained renowne mercifull wee others punishing iniuries done vnto another doe remaine name tirants punishment god seuere sinnes filthy measure v measure desert one offence sufficient take life v reason hee cannot called man amongst men sauage amongst sauages forgetting feeble flesh tormenteth flesh brother man helde himselfe toppe toe shall finde one thing moue cruelty may moue one man bee mercifull another shall see many instrument exercise mercy hee hath eye wherewith hee ought behold needy indigent hee hath feete goe church setmons hath hand helpe hee hath tongue fauour orphanes hath heart loue god conclude hee hath vndersta ding know euill discretion follow good men prince prince follow good eschew euill shall say therefore since time warres prince cannot reforme vice correct vicious oh prince noble men knew damage doe countreyes day take vppon warre thinke also prince seeke peace keepe peace without doubt haue wrong heard loued credited counsellour light ocasion counselleth prince beginne warre say vnto eyther choler surmounteth else good conscience wanteth chaunceth often time prince vexed troubled one certifieth prouince rebelled prince hath inuaded countrey matter requireth councell assembled rashe counsellours immediately iudge peace bee broken lightly others doe desire warres neuer beginne prince case asketh counsell ought forthwith aunswere suddenly thing concerning warres ought great wisedome first considered much aduisement determined king dauid neuer tooke warre hand though wise first hee counselled god good iudas machabeus neuer entred battell first hee made k dauid patterne prince stain warre prayer vnto almightie god greekes romanes durst neuer make warre enemy first would sacrifice god consulte also oracle matter iustice recreation person reward good punishment euill diuiding reward prince may communicate priuate man matter warre hee ought first counsell god prince shall neuer haue perfect victorie ouer enemyes vnlesse hee first committe quarrell thereof vnto god counsell prince whether matter warre affaire peace ought alwaies remember sentence giue counsells alwayes hee alone chamber would doe saw poynt death sicke instant man dare speake flattery burden conscience bryberie entreate warre moue ought first consider came well passe blame imputed counsell substaunce bee presently able recompence losse let assure himselfe soule shall suffer paine men ought much loue peace much abhorre warre belieue preparation priest hath conscience god hee presume receiue holy communion euen ought counsellour haue vnto prince hee giueth counsell concerning warre since prince men maruell though feele iniuties men desire howmuch euery ought preferre peace warre reuenge men therefore cause ought haue wise men counsell whereby mittigate asswage theyr griefes trouble counsellours prince ought neuer counsell thing beeing angrie wherwith may iustly displeased pacified following matter counting good lost loosing peace euils increase winning warres say amongst thing greatest euill time warre locke vp closely person good lucke euil fortune within fifteene dayes came warre asia whereof haue triumphed rome remembring time past thou wert companion trauell sent immediately certifie thee triumphes noble heart might excuse lightes contrarie see tenne whereby may condemne folly solon phylosopher lawes said athenian young offended hee gently admonished difference solon lycurgus opinion grieuously punished strong olde erre hee bee lightly punished sharply admonished sith hee weake feeble lycurgus lawes lacedemonians sayd contrarie young offend hee lightly punished grieuously admonished since ignorance erre olde man euill bee lightly admonished sharply punished since thorough malice hee offend two phylosophers beeing haue bin authority worlde past considering lawes sentence weight bee much rashnes admitting one receiuing one rereprouing mee thinketh great excuse young ignorance great condemnation aged experience againe returne say pardon friend ought greatly weigh thogh somewhat sharpe condemnation since others dissolute liues blacke life penne doth take inke remember wel haue heard thee claude thou hast beene lusty couragious thy youth thy strength enuyed beauty claudine men desired write vnto letter friend neighbour nether reduce memory thou claude hast employed thy force seruice comonwealth thou claudine hast much honor thy beauty sundry time cha ced men many goodly giftes noted grieuous offence striued thee dead thou desirest deade serued thee claudine dead thee claudine sighed dead thee dyed dead since deade theyr lightnesse doe others thinke die folly also doe demand thy youth one thing thy beauty another thing receiue pastims good entertainements aboundances great contentations pleasure world vanitie past hope carry narrow graue simple simple ignoraunt person life consumeth wee perceiue wee liue therein felicitie enioy short long life know employ eyther well euill child earth disciple vanitie know time flyeth without mouing wing life goeth without lifting vp feete world dispatcheth v telling v cause men doe beguile v mouing lippes flesh consumeth v vnawares heart dyeth hauing remedie finally glorie decaieth neuer beene death oppresseth v without knocking dore though man neuer simple foole yet hee cannot deny impossible make fire bottome sea make way ayre thinne bloud make rough sinewes soft veines make hard bone meane vnpossible greene flower youth one day withered age chap xx emperour followeth letter perswadeth claudius claudinus olde giue credite world deceitfull flatteryes haue continuation emperours letter friend spoken tendeth aduertise young teach olde others haue passed prime time childhood summer youth haruest adolescency winter age seemeth vncomely thing hoary haires bee accompanied vaine folly sithens young men know haue end youth maruell follow world olde men see themselues fall guile runne vice againe world thou art world smal force great debilitie thou willing resisting thou dost swallow v vp perillous gulfe thornes sharpe thou dost pricke v priuiest wayes thou leadest v stony way thou carriest v meane thou bringest v highest fauours end afterwards push thy pike thou mightest ouerthrow v world wherein worldly two fifty yeeares haue passed since thee first borne vanity world vncertainety thereof time thou neuer toldest mee one truth haue taken thee ten thousand lye neuer demanded thing thou diddest promise yet nothing euer thou diddest perform neuer put trust thee euer thou beguiledst neuer came thee thou diddest vndoo finally neuer saw ought thee wherby thou deseruest loue alwayes hatred presupposed know thee world worldling want thou hatest v cannot hate thee thou doest v iniury dissemble thou spurne v thy foot wee wil suffer thou beatest v staffe wee wil hold peace also though thou persecutest v complain though thou take wee demand thee though thou dost beguile v call ourselues beguiled worst thou doest chase v thy house yet depart thence know meaneth know whence commeth know ought prayse wee couet follow world wil none v hate god loue v oft time make account yeares past somtimes also turne tosse booke see haue read another time desire friend giue mee good counsell end doe attaine haue spoken know say reading rethorike rhodes adrian lord maintaining knowing two thirty year age hapned spring time found selfe solitarily soluarinesse liberty smelled world smelling knew knowit followed following attained attayning vnto therunto ioyned selfe ioyning selfe therewith proued prouing tasted tasting mee thought bitter finding bitter hated hating left leauing returned returned receyued againe finally world inuiting mee resisting two fiftie yeares wee eate bread together one house wee haue alwayes remayned wilt thou know sort world doe liue one house together better say one heart remayne harken one word tell thee saw world braue serued hee saw sad hee flattered mee saw wealthy asked hee saw mee merry hee begulled mee desired thing hee holpe attaine afterwards best enioyed hee tooke hee saw pleased visited hee saw mee forgot saw mee ouerthrowne hee gaue mee hand releeue mee saw exalted hee tripped againe ouerthrow finally thinke haue somewhat world finde haue burthen haue spoken world bee thing great deale yet selfe say without doubt folly greater malice since beguiled oft yet alwayes follow deceyuer world world thou hast mood fashion thy proceeding thou leadest v perdition one thing maruell much whereof cannot bee satisfied since may go vpon bridge yet without gaine wee doe wade water shallow sure wee seeke runne gulfe way drie wee goe plash wee may eate wholesome meates nourish life wee receyue poyson hasten death seeke destroy selues whereas wee may bee without danger finally say without profite wee commit fault though wee see warie euery man ought eye paine follow wise men ought circumspectly see examine speake proue take hand beware whose company vse aboue know trust iudgement corrupt beguile v one inough make v bee deceyued tenne thousand would suffice haue great care v doe meane world guile v flesh flatter v high way narrow pathway daungerous full prickes iourney long life short body neuer loden vice heart full sorrow care haue wondered diuers thing world astonieth mee good make beleeue euill euill wee perswade others beleeue good wee shoote white vertues hit butte vice confesse one thing beeing disclosed know infamy follow mee peraduenture vertuous man maruell two fifty yeeres life haue proued al vice world entent proue bee thing man malice might satisfied afterwards well considered examined proued finde eate dye hunger drinke greater thirst haue rest broken sleepe drousier haue couet desire tormented procure lesse attaine finally neuer greate paine want afterwards trouble excesse man euer contented estate world great folly thinke long man liueth flesh satisfie flesh last cast shee may take v life wee others cannot take disordinate couetousnesse men speake god god conuersant men first thing would aske bee haue appointed end wofull dayes giue v end wicked desire cruell god doe doe suffer v certaine wee shall passe one good day life onely tasting life consumeth intollerable life man wherein malice wee ought beware peril fall also many thing consider shee wee doe ende know selues houre death approcheth let know know world taketh wee others like ignorants cannot deny afterwardes hauing power doth constraine v wee would many time wee would doe vertuous workes wee put world hand wee dare world vseth another subtilty v end striue prayseth euery man ought flye vain intisements world time past wee liue according time present world sayeth wee others employ force vice giueth v licence wee haue good desire vertue would god dayes might see care worlde hath preserue v thirty yeares sithence thou askedst place theater olde man tell pray thee also coniure thee oyntment hast thou annoynted thy selfe water hast thou washed thy selfe become young claude thou hadst found medicine discouered herbe wherwith thou couldest take white haires men heades woman wrinccles face sweare vnto thee also doe assure thee thou shouldest visited serued rome god apollo temple ephesus thou shouldest well remember annius priscus old man neighbour somewhat kinne thee tolde could filled good word behold auncient white haires said vnto oh sonne marke appeareth well thou hast bin aged thou talkest young man white haires honour person greatly hurt hart houre see v aged stranger doe hate v loue v told let thee know sonne marke many time wife talking yeares another particularly shee beholdeth mee seeme vnto aged say vnto sweare yet young white hayres came vnto mee great trauells age sicknes doe remember also annius priscus senatour one yeare would seem aged desired men shold iudge young shaued beard head accustomed among senatours censor rome day among senator entred high capitoll one saide vnto thus question demaunded senatour rome tell man whence comest thou wilt thou commest thou hither durst thou senatour enter senate hee answered annius priscus aged chaunceth haue knowne replyed vnto thou wert annius priscus thou wouldest come hither thus shauen sacred senate none enter gouerne commonwealth vnlesse person endued vertues head white hayres therefore thou art banished depriued thy office olde liue young ought bee punished thou knowest well claude claudine haue foot goe haue palsey speake haue gowte hand play finally like worldly vicious men haue employed force young desirous proue al vice old grieueth extreamly canot acomplish desire amongst faultes olde men myne opinion chiefest since haue proued thing still remaine theyr obstinate follie parte haue trauelled villanie haue essayed fortune haue proued good haue persecuted euill hath chanced vnto wickednes haue attepted vnhappie men olde experience know feele many daungers sort haue spent youth haue ende theyr combes cut infirmity disease yet much grieued vice doe abound hinder vertues mee thinketh trouble sufficient one goeth bed thinketh hee bee killed bedde sleeping coffer rifled time riseth hee alwayes tormented feare lose hath wonne carefull augment little much diuine plato first booke commonwealth sayde word men made rich neuer learned bee rich continually truly become rich first ought abhorre couetousnesse begin occupie himselfe locke vppe good man setteth bond desire shall alwayes haue little though hee see himselfe lord world sentence stoyckes doth satisfie mind much whereof aristotle politikes maketh mention sayth vnto great affayres alwayes required great rich extreame pouertie hath beene great aboundance worthie saying aristotle c thereof ensueth vnto prince great lordes haue much want much vnto men haue little want little wee admonish worldling vicious alwayes haue excuse excuse themselues declaring haue vicious vice auarice excepted whome haue excuse one vaine reason ready excuse two thousand condemne let v put example principall vice wee shall see onely auarice remaineth condemned excused reason noble prince great lord hautie proude aunswere hee hath great occasion naturall disposition men rather desire commaund trauell serue quyetnes rest reproue man furious giuen anger hee aunswere v maruell since maruell proude enemy hath authority trouble man take reuenge blame fleshly vicious answer v hee cannot abstaine sinne man eschew actes fighteth continually vncleane thought wee say anie man negligent hee answere v deserueth blamed vilenes nature trauell immediately wearie rest immediately reioyceth wee rebuke man glutton hee answere v without eating drinking wee cannot liue world diuine word hath forbidden man eate mouth vncleane thought come heart vice haue declared may wee excuse residue vice couetousnesse none giue reasonable excuse money put coffer soule cannot profite bodie reioyce boetius booke consolation said money good wee haue possession wee want true saying boetius deede sentence boetius profound man spendeth money attaineth hauing profiteth nothing wee may say rich couetous men heape keepe say deere drye yeares relieue theyr parent friend may aunswer doe heape vp remedie poore like necessityes rather bring commonwealth greater pouerty sell thing deere put money great vsurie couetous man doth harme doth lend drie yeare doth hath taken fro noble vertuous men ought cease doe well feare dry yeares ende one deare yeare come maketh al deere time case onely may called happie free liberall almes shall reioyce table costly let couetous men beware keeping much good giue diuell theyr soules may bee deare yeare commeth sel corne bodyes shalbe layd graue oh good doeth god noble giuing liberal hart ill lucke haue couetous men hauing haue hart hard laced couetous men taste sweet necessarie thing giue could keepe little themselues sithens miserable couetous men haue heart giue friendes depart parent succour poore lend neighbour sustaine orphanes bee thought spend themselues truly say men miserable hard haue thinke euill spent among themselues spend one robbeth good description miserable couetous man couetous miserable wretch giue garment naked man dare make himselfe coate hee giue eate poore familiar poore slaue eateth bread branne selleth flower meale shal pilgrim lodge house pure misery dare enter doth visite hospitall releeue sicke oft time hazardeth owne health life hee giue one penny physition shall hee succour secretly poore needy maketh owne child goe barefoote naked hee helpe marry poore maides orphanes suffereth owne daughter waxe olde house hee giue good poore captiues pay owne men wage giue eate child poore gentleman alwayes grudgeth owne spend wee beleeue hee wil apparrell widdow giue owne wife hoode doth hee daily giue almes goeth church sunday hee offer one penny shall couetous man reioyce heart sith spending one penny oft time hee goeth supperlesse bed finally say hee neuer giue v proper good weepeth alwayes good another chap xxiiii author followeth matter great reason discommendeth vice couetous men one thinges poverty far better rich couetousnes wherein diuine prouidence sheweth vnderstand maner gouernement see shee giueth vnderstanding man know rich shee giueth force seeke subtilly gather vertue sustaine courage defend also long life possesse shee giueth licence enioy rather suffereth without reason hee hath made himselfe lord man right hee bee made slaue owne thereby man may know greater excellency vertuous pouerty outragious couetousnesse much poore god doth giue contentation little hee hath rich man taketh contentation great deale hee possesseth couetous man wee see trouble encrease howerly gaine commeth vnto monethly let v compare rich couetous man poore potter wee shall see shall profite eyther potter pot maketh earth else couetous money hath earth though make answere yet answer herein hath already made one much better ease earth good potter getteth liuing selling pot couetous man loseth soule keeping rich humbly require high prince also beseech great lordes admonish noble plebeian alwayes haue word memory say affirme strongly man keepeth locketh treasure desire couetous men neuer satisfied strongly priuily kept hee put two keyes keepe treasure putteth seuen heart spend let noble valiant men beware giue mindes heape vp treasure heart bee kindled couetousnes feare spending halfe penny dayly suffer themselues fall thousand misery plebeian rich may say haue heaped vp much treasure sithence cannot behold hundred two hundred duccats answere estate considered ten duccates doe much harme treasurer others ten thousand fault consisteth keeping hiding much litle rich forsomuch keeping cease doe many good workes mee strange matter niggardlinesse hath greater force couetous conscience hath others many notwithstanding conscience profite good others couetous hauing misery conscience cannot yet profite owne much care lesse diligence couetous men doe prouide miller rob meale beast make wasts hunter run corne wine perish owe thing doe go make themselues bankroutes wynets eate corne theeues rob good end watch none well themselues others earely late haue alwayes oportunitie robbe somewhat couetous hath neuer heart change duccate men ought take great pitty couetous man description couetous man necessity weareth gowne torne shooes point without agglets euill fauouted girdle coate rent hat olde hose seame rent cap greasie shirt lousie finally say diuers miser faine haue great summe pay thing wearing good garment couetous doe keeping penny purse hee go two moneths trimme beard sithence true pinchpenies doe behaue person euill ye thinke haue house thing better furnished say shal see chamber full cobweb dores hinge windowes riuen glass broken planches loose couertures house without gutter stooles broken bed wormeeaten chimnies ready fall harbour friend kinsman constrayned lodge theyr neighbour house else sende borrow want passing ouer garment weare housen wherein dwell let v see table keepe garden eate fruite falleth tree theyr vine rotten grape sheep sickest corne wettest wine hath taken winde lard yeallow milke turned finally say felicitie glutton haue eating selfe haue keeping oh vnhappie glutton much couetous tast one consisteth throate felicitie consisteth comparison glutton vsurer may locke vp chest wee haue seene couetous weare simple apparell keepe poore table dwell filthie house yet lesse regard thing touch honor eares open heare haue heart bent eache houre gather heape vp heare called mysers vsurers niggard pinchpennies oppressor cruell vnthankefull vnfortunate finally say comonwealth hated men rather lay hads vpon bodyes kill tongue renowme defame couetous man vnlucky fall strife shal find one friend come visit house shal haue hundred thieues wil rob good reuenge couetous enemy man neede desire nought else liue long hee tormented life owne couetousnes otherwise pennance rich men would say vnto doe reioice haue faire house sithes haue neither curious apparell since may weare daintie meates sithens may eate doe couetous good christian iust thing reason would pen cease sorry little esteem thing touching honour much lesse matter touching conscience auaritious say hee keepeth good almes doe beleeue dayly see poor man aske alms hee answereth immediatly god helpe hee hath neither purse money couetous almes couetous man giue vseth neuer giueth almes house fat meat restie bacon rotten cheese hoary bread seemeth rather make cleane house giue almes poore couetous man would tell v haue discharge debt predecessor wherewith burdened say vaine excuse sithens wee see willes father mother grandfather yet performed neyther thinke performe seemeth true since houre layde father graue neuer thought deade father hee pure couetousnesse misery suffereth himselfe dye hunger colde thinke hee hath small deuotion giue almes much lesse doe man good couetous man say vnto v hee keepeth none cause build sumptuous chappell leaue memory answere one doeth owne proper swette maketh restitution euill hath done shall sanctified good men commended couetous wil many liue great pouerty onely make rich tombe god doth command neyther dooth church admit sacrifice done god cry others acceptable couetous tell v thogh heape treasure death distribute vnto poore brought honestly ground say commend purpose entent bee accordingly performed sorry couetous man thinke hereby merite hee thus discharge wickednesse life distribution little money death would thinke sure prince great lord spend good marry poore maydens orphan life commaund money bee dealt death oft time heyres executor body interred doe little performe testator much lesse obserue legacy bequeathed though vtter vndoing poore orphanes guerdon commendation deserueth iustly truely dischargeth legacy dead surplus owne releeue orphanes marry poore maydens keeping vice worlde suppose couetous man chanceth traffique medine spaine lion france lisbone himselfe good might thereby bee free offence well ala wicked child liue triumphing earth good miserable father goeth weeping hell sinnes chap xxv letter emperor marcus aurelius wrote friend cincinnatus beeing romane knight became marchant capua wherein hee toucheth gentleme take vpon trade marchanaize vocation diuided three chapter marke emperour brother annius verus felow empire wisheth thee cincinnatus emperour sheweth abuse leaue calling capua health thy person grace thy euill fortune feast mother berecinthe haue seene neyther seruat thy house read letter thy hand maketh suspect greatly thy health danger thou mistrustest friendshipp earnest friendship requireth dayly communication visitation pray thee carelesse henceforth doe forget v wise meane thou wilt come see v least thou wilt write vnto v often letter faithfull friend though vtterly doe take v desire presence yet least make v hope meeting know thou mayest answere mee common wealth capua thou art busied impossible thou shouldest write vnto mee hereto answere thee affayres thou canst occupied bee lawfull let communicate write vnto thy friend may well call time wee liue bee well employed spent seruice god conuersation friend residue waste talking trauelling sleeping eating resting wee ought write booke life register death albeit se blable work body refreshed yet therewith heart cannot comforted sweare vnto thee therefore friend impossible man take contentation worldly thing heart rest comfort sinewes bone body liuely power soule long sithence haue knowne together long time likewise loued thee thou sith wee true olde friend reason good work wee doe renue friendship falsly vsurpe name friendshippe conuersant one stranger man speaketh writeth mee seeth visiteth giueth whome giue would hee enemy little auaileth mee hee cal mee friend particular friendship consisteth abundance friend open hart talke person peraduenture thou wilt say great distance rome country hath occasion diminish friendshippe noble heart fire presence loue haue great pain absence desire answere farther delicious wine sent place grow greater strength haue meane herein true wherein true friendship consisteth friend knowne person surthest seuered will conioyned tell mee pray thee cincinnatus sithence alwayes thou hast found mee diligent friend thy seruice doest thou mistrust faithfull good greene leaues outwardly doe shew tree inwardly drie meane good workes outwardly doe declare feruentnes heart inwardly thou cincinnatus presumest bee true friend thy friend thou know rule friendship perfect loue wanteth alway faithfull seruice contrary perfectly loueth assuredly shall serued haue beene thine therfore thou shalt doe great iniurie thou art mine chap xxvi emperour proceedeth letter declareth vertues men ought vse vice ought eschew time past beeing yong thou olde succour thee money emperour sheweth vertues men ought vse vice ought eschew thou good counsell world otherwise changed thy white hayres doe iudge thee old thy work doe cause thee yong therefore necessity compelleth mee change stile succour thee counsell though thou giue money therefore count thy couetousnesse bee good counsell counsellours rome thou wilt vouchsafe giue one quatrine capua good wish thee owe law friendshippe presently giue thee counsell whereby thou maiest know good man ought doe bee beloued god feared loued men thou wilt quietly leade thy life miserable world retaine well memory write vnto thee first good deed thou hast receyued shalt thou remember wrong thou hast sustained shalt thou forget secondarily esteeme much thy owne little weigh much thirdly company good alwaies couet conuersation euill dayly flye fourthly great shew thy selfe graue small conuersant fiftly present alwaies good work absent alwaies speake good word sixtly weigh little losse fortune esteeme much thing honour seuenth winne one thing neuer aduenture thou manie many thing doubtful aduenture one thing certaine finally lastly pray thee aduertise thee thou haue enemie thou keepe one friend among good bee counted good none thing hee ought want know well thou wilt haue great pleasure see counsel well written ensure thee shal haue greater pleasure see thy decdes well obserued writing giue good counsell easie workes follow maruellous hard faithfull friendship thee plighted thy great ability considered caused mee alwayes thee rome procure honourable office sute thou hast beene edite tribune master horse wherein thou behauedst thy selfe wisedome senate therefore yeelded mee hearty thanks procuring thee thou thy selfe winning perpetuall renowme one thing thee vnderstand good would haue knowne much lesse thing thee haue bin committed say thou leauing thy office pretorship ware lande hast taken vpon thee traffique marchaunt sea rome knew thee knight doe see thee capua marchaunt pen indyting letter time stood suspence cause onely see thing thee first might best blame either noble office thou didst forsake vile base estate thou hast chosen though thou much bereaued thy sences yet call minde thy auncient predecessours died warres onely leaue theyr child nephew armed knight thou presently seekest loose thy libertie throgh thy couetousnes wan valiantnes thinke deceyued thy predecessor reuiued ambicious honour would bee greedy eate thee morsel sinues bone childre vniustly take honour father reason ought loose liues castle townes house mountaines wood beastes iewells siluer predecessor haue left v end long continuance perish causeth v haue perpetuall memorie good renowme theyr life therefore bee true great shame parentes haue child whome renowme predecessours doth end flourishing time cicero orator counsel whole commonwealth gouerned hee power knowledge money salust saide vnto inuectiue hee base dead griefe see presently child vicious vnthrifts remaineth much memory infamy ther doth others honesty thou makest ashamed thou hast forsaken conquere enemyes romane knight thou arte become marchant poore plebeian thou makest mee muse little friende cincinnatus thou wilt harme thy familiar suffer straungers liue peace thou seekest procure death giue v life deliuer death take life rebells thou giuest rest peacemaker thou giuest anoyance take v owne thou wilt giue giueth v thou wilt take thou condemnest innocent condemned thou wilt deliuer defender thy countrey thou wilt bee tyraunt thy commonwealth thing aduentureth leaueth weapon falleth marchandise self oft time haue mused occasion mooue thee forsake chiualrie wherein thou hadst honour take hand marchaundise followeth famie say much shame thee haue gone warres honor born office commonwealth friend cincinnatus end tendeth condemne marchaundise marchaunts speake euill trafficke trade buying selling without valiant knight warres cannot bee atchieued likewise without diligent marchants commonwealth cannot maintained cannot imagine cause thou shouldest forsake warres trafficque marchandise vnlesse thou old wantest force assault men openly straytes shouldst ease sitting thy chayre robbe secretly marketplace poore cincinnatus sithens thou buiest cheap sellest deare promisest much performest little thou buiest one measure sellest another thou watchest none deceyue thee playest therein marchants accustome conclude sweare measure wherewith god shall measure thy life shall bee much iuster thy merites thou hast taken thee office wherewith companion many day haue robbed thou one houre deceit dost get afterwards time shall come good thou hast gotten truth falshood shall bee lost onely houre long moment short whether wee giue much haue much may much liue much yet end god iust euill co mit shall punished good wee worke shall rewarded god oftentimes permit one alone shall scourge many afterwards long time mariner drowned thou wouldest haue shedde one teare romane marchants weepe rather ten crownes lost cannot recouer ten men dying tenne crownes would haue saued mee thinketh neyther iust honest thou doe thou seest ship vntill time cast marchandise ouer boord could sayle safely yet thou doest lode thy selfe rich goe thy graue grieuous cursed rich neyther deepe sea neither yet maine land person safeguarde knowing thy property would rather bind selfe seeke thy leade tinne thy heart wounded ende rich neuer letteth man quiet thy leade together place bottome sea thy couetousnesse seattered whole earth perhaps thou shouldst dye surgions sharpe rasours open thy stomacke sweare vnto thee mother berecynthia mother god rome rather finde thy heart drowned lead life thy bodie thou canst sicke feuer tertain heat within thy body pain thy head would cause thee haue double quartaine disease thou canst bee healed thy bed ship land sea phisitions pirats physitions would carry away money pirats would shew thee thy leade fell trouble thy selfe much mercury though thou hast thy lead thee land hath thee sea thou oughtst inough comfort thy selfe whereas thou hadst thy coffer thou hast presently thy colde pearseth mee men much euill rule youth come grieuous disease age oh mortall men olde could time worke god become young againe sweare vnto thee faith good man would behaue themselues well world againe deceyue since men haue vicious youth maruell thogh full disease old loue health hateth vertue haue spoken end may knowe belieue sicke cannot write vnto thee long would thou desirest hereof followeth shall bewayle thy paine thou shalt grieued gowt vnderstod feast god ianus running horse great strife raised betweene thee thy neighbor patricius brute haue confiscated thy good battered thy house banished thy child depriued thee senate tenne yeares banished thee capua euer haue put thy fellow prison mamortine reason domitius banished little furie thou hast cause lamet al dayes thy life al come thence tell v thou art woefull thy heart chaunged thy person thou doest forget thy heauie chaunces receiuest consolation thy faithfull friend thinke speake thou shouldest offended according often chaunges fortune hath shewed mee long since knew sorrow meant truly man sorowful sigheth day watcheth night delyteth companie onely care hee resteth light hateth darknes loueth bitter teares hee watereth earth heauy sigh pierceth heauens infinit sorrowes remembreth past foreseeth nothing come displeased doeth comfort hee taketh rest expresse sorrowes finally vnfortunate man contented nothing himselfe continually hee doeth chafe beleeue mee domitius haue wel touched condition sorrowfull man cause euill fortune hath made taste hereof commeth well discribe end thing touch sorrowes spirite trouble body great difference hath read fro hath felt thou diddest feele doe feele sufficient giue thee thy friendes great dolour thinke small trifle thou shouldst vndoe thee al thy parentage speaking truth sorry see thee cast away much grieueth see thee drow ned little water men noble keepe heart high ought take enemy agreeable estate meane noble man shall aduenture hazard person good ought matter greate importance end defamed hee ouercommeth labourer ouercome knight variable fortune short space doth happen euil fortune speake doe condemne selfe accuse thee complaine god reclaime dead call liuing end may see eye wee suffer griefes know hand wee touch perceyue wee goe ouer see sound eares wee heare dayly doe admonish v wee doe beleeue finally feele perill remedy griefe experience doth letter widowes vnpossible receiue speake dead hauing power mee thinkes thou referre god giue much better wee aske ladie lauinia desire thee earnestly friend counsell admonish thee heart require thee thou esteeme well done god haue done thou conforme thy selfe god thou nought else god onely knowe erre wherfore haue assaulted thy husband sudden death vnto thee wife haue lent long life god beeing mighty sage hee iudge profound iudgements god knowe right well serue offend loue hate praise blaspheme yeelde thanks vnthankefull tell thee oftentimes god serued buryed graues goe weeping temple wilt thou enter account god thou oughtst note consider haue left thee child comfort thy selfe haue left thee good wherewith thou mayest auoyde pouertie haue left thee friend whome thou shalt fauoured haue left thee parent thou art beloued haue left thee good name esteemed health wherewith thou mayest liue finally say small god take v respect leaue v one sort ought behaue selues men another wee ought serue god men sometimes requisite shew countenance humble god necessary lye flat grounde thy stomacke honour dutie euery christian eth god oracle apollo doe deceyue v god sooner humilitie wherewith wee worship appeased presumptuous sacrifice wee offer vnto contented since thou art widdow lady lauinia art wise vertuous woman beseech god preserue thy child defend thy renowme seuer thy friendes thee thou scatter thy good preserue thy person health aboue bee theyr fauour thou canst winne loose much thy life god giue take thee one houre would god widow knew little shee winneth among men much loseth among god shee pacient aduersitie impatience oftentimes prouoketh god wrath see man bodie experience sundrie disease cured wordes spoken hearbs therevnto applyed disease contrary seene cured costly medicine comfortable wordes ende comparison tendeth effect afflicted hart know somtimes hart comforted one benefite doe hundred word speake time sorrowfull hart lightned one worde friendes mouth seruice others worlde oh wretch one destitute want considering thy greatnes weyghing little knowledge see selfe vnable comfort thee want science helpe thee want rich cease haue great sorrow sorrow payment may receyued person doe neyther paper iuke requite man word comforteth effect able remedy declareth himselfe haue beene fayned friend time past sheweth man ought take faithfull friend time come romaine custome vsed romains visiting widdowes widdowes rome haue accustomed doe presently doe rhee lady lauinia say thy husband dead goe visite widdow comfort widdow within dayes wofull widdow haue neede smal fauor senate withdraw themselues together neuer knowne husband seene renowme romaine widdowes dayntie honestie dishonestie dependeth good renowme person honour parent credite childre memory dead therfore healthfull counsell wise men speake word widowes doe infinite good work auaileth wofull widowes haue cofers filled letter promise eares stuffed word flattery hitherto thou hast taken mee thy neighbour parent thy husband beseech thee henceforth thou take mee husband loue father counsell brother seruice aduocate senate truly shall accomplished hope thou wilt say many haue lost marcus aurelius alone haue found know well thou doost like maner heart sorrowes ouerwhelmed spirit vexed troubled memory dulled flesh doth tremble spirit doth change reason withdrawne since presently sorrow care thy house doe remaine let god forsake abandon thee let forget mee remember thee claudine remained thine wholly till houre death marcus aurelius euermore thine life since loue thee entirely thou trustest faithfully thou sorrowes art replenished heart care oppressed let v admit thou lady lauinia hast aucthority command thy affaire licence counsell aduertise thee thing touching thy honour person oftentimes widowes haue neede meane remedy good counsell earnestly desire thee leaue lamentation custome vsed among romane widowes romane widowes know shut gate teare haires end thou maiest reade al isle thou shalt immediatelie dispatch ship end carry prouisions men warre illyria peace bee thee lambert health good fortune mee marke senate saluteth thee send thee propagation gouernement next yeare calends ianuary thou shalt say gaude foelix wife faustine commendeth thee sendeth thee thy daughter rich girdle payment thy seruices send thee two rich iewels two light horse one laden sexterces marcus mount celio owne hand writeth vnto thee chap xlviii prince noble men ought remember mortall must dye wherein sundry notable consolation feare death cleobolus biton sonnes renowmed woman nunne goddesse iuno day solemne feast celebrated child prepared chariot wherein mother goe temple greekes custome day priestes went offer sacrifice eyther carried men armes two child deserued great reward recompenced truly sayde iustly deserued deserued much praysed example shewed child reuerence parent carrying mother chariot temple feast ended mother knowing require hast demaunded hast demaunded wee haue giuen thee goddesse thou art seruant therefore god haue giuen thy child thing count dear death greatest reuenge among god wee take enemy let liue long best thing bee giuen vnto man vnto profite saying miserable men haue power eschew euill wisedome chuse good god apollo answered contented pay seruice done death best gift giuen mortall men grant demaunded reason whereof triphon agamendo hauing dined suddenly gate temple fel dead reward trauel plucke miserie reason declare two example ende mortall men may knowe nothing good worlde haue ende life though lose sauour yet least profite wee would reproue traueller great foolishnes sweating way would sing iourneyes ende hee beginne weepe hee simple sorry hee come hauen hee simple giueth battell fighteth hee hath got victorie stubborne little ought esteeme death great distresse angry succoured therefore foolish simple stubborn hee trauelleth dye loath meete death death true refuge perfect health sure hauen whole victorie flesh without bone fish without scale corne without slrawe finally death wee haue nothing bewayle much lesse desire time adrian emperour phylosopher called secundus meruellously death scourge euill chiefe reward good truely phylosopher spake well hee doe euill profoundly would consider hee spoken seneca epistle declareth phylosopher whose name bessus demanded euill man haue death since men feare much hee aunswered damage feare dyeth feare death vice dyeth wee may agree phylosopher saide euen deafe cannot iudge harmony blind colour likewise cannot say euill death especially neuer tasted dead none returned complaine death fewe liue complaine life dead returned hither speak vvith liuing comfort feare death haue proued vvould tell v harme secrete death reason haue feare death though man neuer saw heard felt tasted death doeth speake euill death wee therefore feare death ought haue done euill life doe feare speake euill death last houre streight iudgement good shalbe known euill discouered prince knight rich poore whole sicke lucky vnluckie see vocation contented saue onely dead theyr graues peace rest neither couetous proud negligent vain ambicious dissolute state dead ought bee best since wee see none therein bee euill contented since therefore poore oe seek meanes wherwith endch themselues sad rio seeke wherby reioyce sicke seeke healed haue feare death doe seeke remedie feare case would say feare die let vse well liue guyltles taketh away feare death diuine plato demaunded socrates hee behaued himselfe life would behaue himselfe death answered let thee know question plato demaunded socrates youth haue trauelled liue well age haue studyed die well sith life hath honest hope death shall ioyfull although haue sorrow liue sure shall haue paine dye truely wordes worthie man men stout hart suffer maruellously swear theyr trauell rewarded faithful reward aunswereth nothing true seruice good seruices friend become vnthankefull worthy honour preferre honorable room office noble valiant hart doe esteeme loose rewarde labour thinke much vnkindenesse man doeth acknowledge theyr trauells oh happie dye without inconuenience without paine euery man graue tribunall iustice equally obserued place wee haue deserued life place merited death neuer neuer shall iudge iust iustice vpright giueth reward weight paine measure somtimes
