truth day wee born come inthis worlde beginning death last day cease liue death bee ending life reason perswadeth v thinke infancie dyeth childhood dyeth manhoode dyeth age shall dye wherof may consequently coclude dye euery yeare euery day euery houre euery moment thinking leade sure life taste new death know men feare much dye since time birth seeke none thing death time neuer wanteth man dye neyther knew man euer fayled way seneca epistle declareth romaine woman lamented death childe phylosopher saide vnto woman worthie sentence seneca bewaylest thou thy childe aunswered weepe hee hath liued xxv yeares would haue liued till fiftie amongst v mother wee loue child hartily neuer cease behold yet ende bewaile phylosopher said tell pray thee woman doest thou complame god created thy sonne manie yeares borne well thou complavnest haue let liue fiftie yeares thou weepest hee deade soone thou dost lament borne late tell thee true woman thou doest lament one thou oughrest bee sorrie without determination god cannot shorten death much lesse lengthen life plinie saide epistle chiefest law god haue sentence plinie giuen vnto humane nature none shold haue perpactual life disordinate desire liue long wee reioyce goe paine two phylosophers disputing great emperor theodose one saide good procure death likewise sayde necessary thing hate life good theodose taking hand sayd wee mortalles extreame hating louing vnder colour loue hate life wee leade euill life suffer many trauells preserue sometimes worthie speech emp theodose much better loose hee sayde diuers vaine men come great follyes feare death procure hasten death hauiwg consideration seemeth wee ought greatly loue life desperation seeke death strong valiant men ought hate life long lasteth bee displeased death hee commeth commended emperour theodose spake paulus dyacon saith life let euery man speake let phylosophers counsell lift poore iudgment hee alone shall receyue death without paine long prepared receyue sudden death onely bitter vnto tasteth also seareth hateth lactantius saide sorte man ought liue hence houre dye men haue death eye vnpossible giue place vaine thought opinion also aduise apuleius much follie flie cannot auoyd desire wee attaine spoken would flye voyage death necessarie desire come againe vnpossible trauell long wayes want thing borrow companie haue forgotten ought returne oppressed good emp aur although desired forthwith haue dyed yet hee remained dayes night without hee would see light speak vnto man heat much rest small sighes continuall thyrst great meate little sage knewe counsell giue partely sorrowful could refraine heauie teares louing true friendes life ought bee beloued theyr death bewailed great compassion ought men haue dye see dye none telleth ought doe noble prince great lord greater perill dye plebeyans counseller dare tell vnto lorde houre death hee knoweth much lesse tell ought die thing hee ought discharge while hee aliue manie goe visite sicke would god went cause heereof see sicke man eye hollowe flesh dryed armes without flesh colour enflamed ague continuall paine great tongue swollen nature consumed besides house destroyed yet say vnto sicke man good cheere warrant shall liue young men naturallie desire liue death olde men dreadfull though see themselues distresse yet refuse men ought prouide cleare conscience depart life c medecines though great hope life therof ensueth oftentimes miserable creature depart worlde without confessing vnto god making restitution vnto men oh doe knewe euill doe take away good trouble person blernish good name slaunder parentage reproue life work cruell enemy bee occasion lose soule work diuell hell certainly hee diuell deceyueth sicke flatteryes steed helpe dye well putteth vainhope long life herein hee sayeth winneth little beleeueth aduentureth much mortall men meete giue counselles reform conscience truth hazard house lye friend wee ashamelesse life also bashfull death ought ought father dead wee daylie see present die mee thinketh shame also feare say sicke hee alone die since thou knowest well knoweth well thou doe trauell perillous iourney shame hast thou say vnto thy friend hee last point dead reuiue would complain friend good counsell feare death cause would giue good counsell death sicke man bee friend see peraduenture dye shall counsell prepare himselfe dye certainly oftentimes see experience prepared ready dye doe escape thinke liue doe perish doe goe visite sicke perswade make testament confesse sinnes discharge conscience receyue communion reconcile themselues theselues death owne ought die say see themselues pang death haue conscience ready prepared count foole wil passe sea without ship truely count wise taketh death without preparation losest wisest man haue well ordained aduenuenture honour man death reconcile himselfe enemy hath borne hate malice loseth credite life time restoreth death command render wherein may man shew himselfe bee wise willingly hee hath discharged afterwards processe take many prince great lord onely spending one day testament haue caused child heires dayes life bee trauerse law supposing haue left child wealthy haue left atturneyes counsellers law true vnfained christian ought euery morning dispose good correct life shold dye night night like manner ought commit himselfe god hoped life vntill morning say truth sustaine life infinite trauels meete death one way credite wordes would cousell man estate liue thing worlde vndoe himselfe riche poore great smal gentleman plebeyans death terrible men say affaire empire passed secretarie saw lord master sicke almost houre death none parent friend durst speake vnto plainly determined doe dutie wherein hee shewed verie well profound knowledge hee power open heart doth faint spirit troubled occasion see wholesome counsel thou giuest others ether thou canst take thy selfe see thee die lord die cannot remedy thee god would haue granted request lengthning thy life one day would giue willingly whole life whither sorrow bee true fayned needeth declare vnto thee wordes since thou mayest manifestly discerne countenance mine eye teares wet heart sighes heauie feele much want thy companie feele much dammage thy death whole commonwealth shall ensue feele much thy sorrowe thy pallace shall remaine feele much rome day vndone aboue thing doth torment heart haue seene thee liue wise see thee dye simple tell pray thee lord men learne greeke tongue trauell vnderstand hebrew sweate reason men studie learne liue well latine chaunge many maisters turne many bookes studie consume much money many yeares knowe passe life honor take death patience end men ought studie learne liue well truer science man know order life well profiteth know much thereby take profite profiteth know straunge language refrain tongue men matter profiteth studie many bookes studie begyule friendes profiteth know influence starres course element cannot keepe selfe vice finally say little auayleth bee master sage secretly hee bee reported bee follower fooles chiefe phylosophie consisteth serue god offend men aske thee noble prince auaileth pilot know arte sayling tempest negligence perish auaileth valiaunt captaine talke much warres afterwards knoweth giue battell auayleth guyde tell nearest way afterwards middest loose himselfe haue spoken saide thee lord auayleth thou beeing health shouldest sigh death since hee doeth approche thou weepest thou wouldest leaue life one thing wherein wise man sheweth wisdome know stedfastnes minde commendable loue hate great lightnes rather say follie day loue whome yesterday hated morrowe slaunder day wee honoured prince high plebeyan base hath world shall euer hath little thou regarded life highly commended death thing haue written beeing thy secretarie mine owne hand diuers prouinces world thou speakest much good death sometimes thou madest mee hate life see letter thou wrotest vnto noble romaine claudinaes widdowe comforting death husband dyed warres wherein shee aunswered thought trouble comfort deserue thou shouldst write letter pittifull sundry letter hast thou written antigonus death thy childe verissimus thy sonne much desired whose death thou tookest thou exceedest limit phylosophie ende thy princely vertues thou didst qualifie thy woful sorows sentence profound wordes well couched didst thou write booke intituled remedy sorrowfull thou didst send warre asia senatours rome comfort sore plague much profite hath thy doctrine done since new kinde consolation hast thou comforted helius fabatus sensour son drowned riuer remember entred house found weeping wee went thence wee lest laughing doe remember thou wentst visite gneus rusticus last disease thou didst speake effectuously vehemency thy word thou madest teares runne downe cheekes demanding occasion lamentation said emperor word wise man workes strange effect lord hath told much euils haue much good haue lost weepe weepe life short death long man aboue thou hast loued torquatus thou didst obey thy father seruedst thy master thy faithfull friend readie die desiring yet liue thou sendest offer sacrifice god graunt himselfe hasten death herewith astonied thy noblenesse satisfie ignorance sayd vnto mee secret wordes maruell panutius see offer sacrifice hasten friend death prolong life nothing faithfull friend ought much desire true friend see ridde trauels earth enioy pleasure heauen thinkest thou noble prince reduce thing thy memory demaund thee possible haue heard thee speake well death doe presently see thee vnwilling leaue life since god commaund thy age willeth thy disease doth cause thy feeble nature doth permit sinfull rome doth deserue sickle fortune agreeth great miserie thou shouldest die therefore sighest loath great men die thou much die trauels necessitie must needes come stout heart ought receiued cowardly heart falleth hee beaten downe stout valiant stomacke greatest perill recouereth strength thou art one man two thou owest one death god two wilt thou therefore one pay two one onely life take two death meane thou endest life thou diest pure sorrow thou hast sayled sayling thou hast passed perill god doe render thee safe hauen againe thou wilt runne raging sea thou scapest victorie life thou dyest ambushments death threescore two yeeres hast thou fought field neuer turned thy backe fearest thou beeing enclosed graue hast thou passed pykes bryers wherein thou hast beene enclosed thou tremblest sure way thou knowest dammage long liue thou doubtest profit death ensueth many yeeres since death thou haue beene defyance mortall enemy lay thy hand thy weapon thou flyest turnest thy backe threescore two yeeres past since thou wert bent fortune thou closest thy eye thou oughtest ouer triumph haue told thee meane since wee doe see thee take death willingly present suspect thy life hath time past beene good man hath desire appeare god token loaden vice meanest thou noble prince weepest thou infant complainest man despaire thou weepest thou dyest answer thee thou laughest much thou liuedst much laughing life proceedeth much wayling death hath alwaies heritage much merriment life breedeth woe death appropriated place common wealth vnconstancy minde shall bee hardy make steadie meane dead die shall die among wilt thou alone liue wilt thou obtaine god maketh god say make thee immortall selues wilt thou alone haue priuiledge god haue nature youth demandeth thy age thing best say better lesse euill die well liue euill doubt man may attaine meanes liue well according continuall variable trouble vexation daily haue accustomed carrie betweene hand alwayes suffering hunger cold thirst care displeasure temptation persecution euill fortune ouerthrowes disease cannot called life long death reason wee call life death since thousand time hate life ancient man make shew life time come intrailes mother vntill time hee entreth bowel earth body would declare al sorrowes hath passed heart discouer ouerthrows fortune hath suffered imagine god would maruell men would wonder body hath endured custome grecian romains much heart hath greatly dissembled take greek wise weepe child bee borne laugh aged dye romanes sing child borne weepe olde men die wee haue much reason laugh olde men die since dy laugh great reason wee ought weepe child borne since borne weepe chap li panutius secretarie continueth exhortation admonishing men willingly accept death vtterly forsake world vanity since life condemned euill remaineth nought else approoue death good oh pleased immortall god oftentimes haue heard disputation matter thou couldest therewith profite sorry sage wise man counsell sometimes part wanteth none ought cleaue much owne opinion sometimes follow counsell third person man thing follow owne aduise ought well assured part hee shall erre lord marke sith thou art sage liuely spirit great experience ancient didst thou thinke thou hadst buried many likewise burie thee imagination thine thinke seeing ende dayes others see end thy yeares since thou diest rich honorably accompanied olde aboue seeing thou diest seruice commonwealth fearest thou enter thy graue thou hast alwaies beene friend much know thing past hid kept secret since thou hast prooued honour dishonour deserue rich pouertie prosperitie aduersitie ioy sorrow loue fear vice pleasure mee seemeth nothing remaineth know necessarie know death also sweare vnto thee noble lord thou shalt learne one houre death hundred yeares life meaneth since thou art good presumest good hast liued good better thou die goe many good thou scape liue amongst many euill thou feelest death maruell nothing thou art man doe maruell thou dissemblest since thou art discreet many thing doe sage men feele wise men outwardly dissemble inward griefes inwardly doe oppresse heart outwardly dissemble honour poyson sorrowfull heart wrapped small peeces feeble flesh scattered wals would suffice rubbbe neither nayles scratch v thing death trap doore wherewith shut shop wherein miserie wofull life vendible wrong preiudice doe god vnto v call v old decayd house change v new builded pallace thing graue strong fort wherin shut selues assault life broyles fortune truely wee ought bee desirous wee finde death wee haue life helia fabricia thy wife doe greeue thee thou leauest yong doe care shee presently hath little care perill wherein thy custoe many widowes life dependeth end shall know thy death shee nothing greeued trouble thy selfe left widdow yong woman shee married olde men thou husband die haue eye robbe heart desire marrie speaking due respect eye outwardly seeme bewayle heart inwardly doe reioyce deceiue thy selfe thinkeing empresse thy wife yong shall finde none emperor may marrie like change cloth gold gownes skinnes meane would rather young shepheard field olde emperour royall pallace thov takest sorrow child thou leauest know thou shouldst truely greeue thee thou diest displeased thou liuest sonne desireth death father may counted onely phenix world father bee poore wisheth dead maintained hee rich desireth death enherite sooner since therefore true indeed seemeth wisedome sing thou weepe greeue thee leaue goodly pallaces sumptuous building deceiue thy selfe therein god iupiter sweare vnto thee since death doth finish thee end threescore two yeeres time shall consume sumptuous building lesse greeue thee forsake company thy friend neighbor also take little thought since thee take amongst compassion ought haue dead true scarcely buried friend neighbour forgotten thou takest greatest thought thou wilt die emperours rome dead seemeth thou oughtest also cast sorrow thee thou knowest right well rome hath accustomed bee vnthankefull serue great scipio also would buried therein greeue thee die leaue great seignory leaue empire cannot thinke vanity thy head temperate reposed men escape semblable office doe thinke lose honour free trouble charge therefore none thing moue thee desire life let thee throgh thy gate enter death greeueth men dy one two thing grieue men death two thing either loue leaue behinde feare hope since therefore nothing life worthy loue thing death feare doe men feare die according heauy fighes thou fetchest bitter teares thou sheddest according also great paine thou shewest part thinke thing thy thought forgotten god commaund thee pay debt admit thinke life shall end yet man thinketh death wil come soon men think neuer die neuer begin fault amend life fault haue end graue together knowest thou noble prince long night commeth middest morning doest thou know moist morning cometh cleare sun knowest thou cleare sun commeth cloudy element doest thou know darke myst commeth extreme heate heate commeth horrible thunder thunder sodaine lightning perilious lightning commeth terrible haile finally say tempestuous troublesome time commonly commeth cleare faire weather order time hath make order time keepeth man ought follow himselfe cruell gentle selfe ought men haue liue die infancy commeth childhood childhood commeth youth youth commeth age age commeth feareful death finally feareful death commeth sure life oftentimes haue read thee seldome heard god onely beginning shall haue also ending therefore mee thinketh noble prince sage men ought desire liue long formen desire liue much either haue felt trauels past haue bene fooles desire time giue themselues vice thou mightest complaine since haue cut thee flower herbe taken thee greene tree cut thee spring tide much lesse eate thee eager thou wert ripe haue spoken meane death called thee thy life sweetest though thou hadst reason haue complayned yet thou mightest haue desired haue altered greater griefe say vnto yong man must die forsake world lord wall decaied ready fall flower hered grape doth rot teeth loose gowne worne lance blunt knife dull dost thou desire returne world thou hadst neuer knowne world threescore two yeeres thou hast liued proportion body wilt thou yron fetter haue rot thy legges desire yet lengthen thy day wofull prison contented liue threescore yeeres fiue transitory life worth desiring death die life desire liue threescore thousand yeeres emperour augustus octauian saide alter men liued fiftie yeeres either owne ought dye else force cause themselues bee killed time haue humaine felicitie best liue aboue age passe day grieuous torment death child losse good importunitie sonne lawes maintaining process discharging debt fighing past bewayling present dissembling iniuries hearing woful newes infinite trauels much better haue eye shut graue heart body aliue suffer man neuer happy till death much miserable life god take miserable life end fiftie yeeres quitted misery life time hee weake crooked hee goeth rowlleth stumbleth falleth lord marke knowest thou way whereby goeth death death cometh knowest thou like manner yeers life hath fled death another time asmuch death goeth seeking thy life death going illiria left great plague thou departing fro thy pallace ye two haue met hungarie knowest thou thou leapedst thy mother intrailes gouerne land immediately death leaped graue seeke thy life thou hast alwayes presumed onely bee honored also honorable bee since thou honouredst embassador prince send profite thy seruice dost thou honor thy messenger god hast cutte flesh opilation thou hast layd oyntments right veines thou didst let bloud thou hast yet touched wound cause griefe meane thou oughtest haue entred mee haue knowne griefe better sighes another time sharpe necessary thereby meane good heare much lesse wee learne euill wee know behoueth v necessitie requireth counsell emperour sonne comodus counsell thee sonne word sixtie two year haue learned science experience since thou art yet young reason thou beleeue aged since wee prince mirrour euery man doth behold v wee doe behold selues day morrow thou shalt enherite romane empire thinke inheriting thou shalt bee lord world yet thou knewest many care peril commaunding bringeth sweare vnto thee thou wouldest rather choose obey command one thou thinkest sonne leaue thee great lord leaue thee empire haue neede thee thou alone hast neede thou thinkest leaue thee much treasure leauing thee great reuenues empire also little though prince haue treasure aboundance yet hee want friend hee hath great want treasure thou thinkest also sonne leaue thee bee obeyed none dare againe say thee truly ought bee meete prince deserueth preserue life augment honour bee conformable desire bee agreeable thou sonne knowest truth lye grieue thee much thou knowest rest broyles motion people shall vex thee thou knowest friend meane thou shalt esteeme little haue enemy thou wert patient reposed true louing man thou wouldest onely refuse empire rome also thou wouldst curse father would leaue thee inheritance would know thou knowest leauing thee empire doe leaue thee rich pouerty rest trauel peace war friend enemy pleasure displeasure finally peace leaue thee alwayes thou shalt haue somwhat bewayle though thou wouldest thou shalt laugh aduertise admonish also exhort thee son think leaue thee vanity lightnes folly disguised mockery thou beleeuest mockry henceforth know thou art deceiued haue liued longer thou haue read pain haue gon thou end find selfe mocked hopest thou liue surely escape without fraude thou shalt think haue empire rest shall arise prouince africa asia losse come great damage recouer great charge wold ensue thou thinkest recouer friend shall strange enimies inuade thee flattering reioycing friendes wee keepe flying reiecting wee cannot defend selues thou shalt thinke greatest ioy shall care oppresse thy hart prince haue possesse much newes giue pleasure seldome thing annoy come hourely thou shalt thinke haue libertie doe thou wilt shalt thou bee restrayned good well ordered prince ought goe whither wanton desire moueth whither lawfull decent honour estate thou shalt thinke none dare reproue thee thou art word cannot doe treason emperour oughtst thou beware dare threaten euill prince wordes haue hardinesse sell treason dare punish dare murmour cannot bee friend doe procure bee enemy finally lay hand person let tongue runne large prate renowme thou shalt thinke haue satisfied thy seruaunts demaund recompence seruices olde custome among courtyers spend freely couet greedily therefore thou dost credite thing knowe foolish enheritance desireth sorrow admit man come empire without comparison rest worth fmpyre taketh pleasure giueth empyre rome well corrected ordered olde time accustomed though great paine gouerne yet honour keepe rooted vice many tyrant entred therein would take wise iudge mockery embrace honour thou knewst rome worth rome hath rome may rome sweare vnto thee thou wouldest labour much lord thereof though rome wall strongly compassed yet vertuous citizen greatly vnprouided inhabitant great vice without number finally say stone buyldings one day may counted euills sinnes populous cittie numbred therein thousand yeares cannot bee declared faith good man sweare vnto thee sonne began reigne three yeares repayred decayed walles rome fallen one onely streete liue well twenty yeares could reforme diuine plato sayd verie well much ought great city glorifie haue vertuous citizen haue proud sumptuous building beware beware sonne inconstancie youth libertie thou hast possesse gouerne empire cause thee vndo thy selfe couted free liberty borne dieth libertie many haue read heard also seene borne slaues afterwards haue died free vertuous many haue seene die slaues beeing borne free onely vitious libertie remaineth noblenesse resident prince haue great realmes necessitie shall haue occasion punish many excess wherfore requisite couragious beleeue mee sonne ought take courage vpon bee mightie puissant vertuous punish excess others good life requisite great authortitie empire vertuous prince ought leaue vice vnpunished good follow good euill feare correction dare commit offence commonwealth liueth like wise man hardy giue punishment hee liueth feare dare almost speake man dare bee hardie punish selfe faulte transgression hee deserueth punished god hee iustly hated men despised let prince take assured thing shall neuer haue loue people libertie commonwealth order house contentation friendes subiection enemy obedience people manie teares shed earth manie prowess person vertuous prince doe render vicious prince earth doth rebell thou wilt bee vertuous heare thing vertue vertue castle neuer taken riuer passed ouer sea sayled fire neuer quenched treasure neuer wasted armie neuer ouerthrowne chaunge neuer wearieth spye euer returneth signe beguyleth man way straight friend succoureth necessity surgion immediately healeth renowne neuer perisheth thou knewest sonne thing good thou wouldst best world vicious man much hee intangled vice vice intangleth vicious vertue cleaneth vertuous much man vertuous much vertues cleaueth thou wilt bee vertuous thou shalt doe seruice god thou shalt giue good renowme thy predecessours thy selfe thou shalt prepare perpetuall memorie thou shalt doe pleasure straungers get thee fauour thine owne people finally good honour thee loue euill serue feare hystories warres tarentines found renowmed pyrrus king epyrots afterwards vertuous onely haue founde effect thought immortall god sweare vnto thee god iupiter take holy house confirme thee sonne mine haue knowne gardner porter rome beeing vertuous occasion cast fiue rich senator senate cause make one gaine lose one would pay pot apple time hee punished tooke apple poore man hee beat downe rich man house haue tolde thee son vice abaseth hardy prince vertue giueth courage bashfull two thing haue alwayes kept selfe say striue open iustice contend vertuous person chap lv emperour marcus aurelius followeth purpose among wholesome counsel exhorteth son keepe wise sage men giue counsel al affayrs hitherto haue spoken thee generally wil speake vnto thee particularly immortall god coniure thee thou bee attentiue say talking thee aged father reason thou heare mee obedient childe thou wilt enioy long life obserue well doctrine god condiscend thy heart desire vnlesse thou receyue wholesome counsel disobedience child vndoing disobedience vnfaithfulnesse child haue father vndoing oftentimes god pardon offence done vnto pardon disobedience child bare father doe require thee sonne thou giue mee money since thou art poore doe demaund thou trauell since thou art tender doe demaund reuengement mine enemy since haue none doe demaund thou serue since dye doe demaund empire since leaue vnto thee onely demaund thou gouerne thy selfe well common wealth memory house bee lost thee thou esteeme much leaue vnto thee many realm thinke better leaue thee many good counsel wherewith thou mayest preserue thy selfe sustaine thy person maintaine thine honour thou hast presumption profite counsell trust thine owne mind flesh eaten wormes thou shalt ouercome thy enemy sonne haue beene young light bold vnshamefast proud enuious couetous adulterer furious glutton slothfull ambitious haue fallen great excess therfore giue thee good aduise man youth hath beene worldly age proceedeth ripe counsell vntill time haue counselled thee ripe counsell proceedeth aged death counsell thee desire least thou proue doe thee harme leaue doe thee good vse medicine bitter sicke doth refuse take thereby hee thinke hee may bee healed pray thee exhort thee aduise thee sonne thy youth beleeue age thy ignorance beleeue knowledge thy sleepe beleeue watch dimnesse thy eye beleeue clearenesse sight thy imagination beleeue vertue thy suspition beleeue experience otherwise one day thou shalt see thy selfe distresse small time thou shalt haue repent none finde remedy thou mayest say vnto sonne since haue beene young let thee bee young thou shalt bee aged thou wilt amend aunswere thee thou wilt liue young yet least gouerne thy selfe olde prince gouerneth co mon wealth well many misery dissembled person euen mighty affayres ripe counsel necessary endure trouble empire person needeth recreation bowstring alwaies stretched either lengthneth breaketh whether prince young old nothing pastime prince seeke iust recreation themselues seeke honest pastime without cause say bee honest sometimes accompany dishonest person vnthrifty spend good lose honour weary person occupied affaire common wealth thy youth leaue thee child great lord thou maiest passe time away without cause haue prouided thee haue brought vp thy infancy thou camest man estate inheriting good perchance thou wouldest accompany thy self yong men thou shouldst find well learned thy war leaue thee valiant captain though indeed thing war begunn wisedome yet end issue falleth fortune steward thy treasurs leaue thee faithful men without cause say faithfull oftentimes greater theeues receiuers treasurer doe rob among people leaue thee sonne expert ancient men thou maiest take counsell thou maiest communicat thy trouble bee fourmed honest thing prince vnlesse hee hath company auncient prince accompanie ancient men men giue grauitie person authoritie pallace inuent theater sish pond chase wilde beast forrests runne field let thy haukes flye exercise weapon al thing denie thee yong man thou yong mayest reioice thy selfe thou oughtest also haue respect ordaine armes inuent warres follow victory accept truce confirm peace raise bruites make lawes promote one put others punish euill first reward good counsell thing ought bee taken cleare iudgements person experience white head thinkest thou possible passe time yong counsell old wife discreet prince thing haue time enough know well measure beware sonne note thee vse great extremity end occasion speake thou shouldst know thou knowest vndecent thing prince vnder colour granitie bee ruled gouerned wholie olde men vnder semblance pastime alwaies accompanie himselfe yong generall rule young men light old men sage thou must according aduise case vse thus old young men light olde men sage man lose grauity age expulse thee thou finde young men sage despise counsell bee doe drawe honey tender flower hard leaues condemne aged doe commend young shall bee well done alwayes thou choose vertuous truth company worlde euill ordered mean liue without suspition young euill solly olde worse couetousnesse againe returne aduertise thee sonne wise thou vse extremitie thou beleeue none young corrupt thy manner lightnesse thou beleeue none old depraue thy iustice couetousnesse thing bee monstrous prince commaundeth suffer commaunded one alone beleeue sonne case gouernements many seldome time gouerned well prince rule many must take counsell many head one alone prince hath rule gouerne many ought take aduise counsell many great inconuenience thou beeing lord many realmes shouldst haue one gate wherein doe enter doe businesse thee perchance shall thy familiar owne nature good mine enemy yet would afraid hee friend mine enemy though hate doe euill yet afraide loue another cease good remember annalles pompeius found little booke memory great pompeius bare wherein many thing reade good counsel diuers part world lerned among wordes gouernour commonwealth committeth gouernment old men deserueth little hee trusteth young light hee gouerneth himselfe alone beyond himselfe himselfe others doth gouerne wise prince know whether sentence pompeius hee gathered book philosopher told friend giuen meane written hand truly weighty affayres dispatched counsell deserued bee written letter gold thy affayres shall bee waighty see thou dispatch alwayes counsell affaire determined counsell many fault shall diuided among thou shalt finde truth sonne thou take counsell many one tel inconuenience perill feare damage profite remedy finally debate thy affayrs plainly thou shalt know good see danger thereof aduertise thee son thou takest counsel thou behold thy eye inconuenience well remedy shall offer vnto thee true counsell consisteth tell ought doe declare thereof like succeede thou shalt enterprise son great weighty affayres much oughtest thou regard little dammages cutte time great mishap remedy oftenttmes chanceth negligence taking vp gutter whole house falleth ground notwithstanding tell thee thou take counsell meane thou oughtest curious euery trifle cal thy counsell many thinges quality would bee immediately put execution doe endammage themselues attending counsell thine authority thou mayest dispatch without dammage commonwealth referre person herein thou shalt iust shalt doe iustice conformable considering thy seruice dependeth onely reward ought haue ought depend onely thee remember marius consull came warres numedia diuided treasure hee brought among souldiers putting one jewell common treasurie hereof hee accused demaunded licence senat answered iust take counsell others giue recompence haue taken opinion others serue thou shalt find sonne kind men hard money exceeding prodigal counsell also diuers lender without demaunding doe offer giue like whose cou sell refused men thou shalt haue counsell neuer looke thou good counsell man whose counsell tendeth preiudice another offereth word thy seruice trauelleth thy businesse owne profite god gaue long life thing haue great thereof wee may well say therefore touching matter well may wee take true friend giueth good counsell hee doeth v great pleasure seruice according opinion good emperor marcus aurelius saide secretarie panutius man one pay may make full satisfaction recompence many pleasure good turn shewed requite good counsell diuers thankes infinite seruices requisite credite ancient hystoriographers wee shall exceede thy empire dignity much must thou endeauour thy selfe surmount others vertue worthinesse hee vnworthy rule multitude chiefe himselfe vertues therefore court prince beare office authoritie auarice ouercome many time chanceth men would least giue themselues acquaintance come bee knowne make least account themselues cometh occasion make reputed winne honor despise good honour rich world continually gape seeke therefore enuy aglaon little garden alexander great mighty asia true contentation consisteth hauing aboundance contented little hee hath mockery worthily hee deserueth laughed thinketh contentation lyeth hauing much great authoritie wayes readier make v stumble yea many time fall right safely assure v go way punishment god gaue cain murdering brother abel body continually trembled euer wandred thorough world neuer found might enhabite house might harbour albeit malediction cain first euer god ordained durst affirme notwithstanding remayneth yet vntill present day truly misery comparable courtier bound dayly lye others house hauing none owne goe onely may bee called happy putteth himselfe danger serue others iulius caesar beeing counselled wayre vpon consull sylla end seruing hee might doe himselfe greate good might bee profitable answered thus sweare immortall god neuer serue hope worth greater sure liberty exiled might power preuaile forsaketh owne countrey liued ease health place hee knowne beloued neighbour hee visited friend whome hee serued parent whome hee honoured good wherewith maintained himselfe wife child thousand pleasure consolation commeth serue dye court cannot say otherwise foole hee commeth doe penance notable crime hee hath committed therefore without great cause name courte tong signifieth short name court adhibited pallace prince adhibited pallace prince indeed thing short enuy malice excepted continue long onely desireth courtier yet hath tasted sweetnesse pleasure owne house hath yet proued seene trouble pain court hee knoweth figheth called court weepeth kept long haue studyed time past vniuersities preached court praying religion dwel vpon bishopricke teaching instructing diocesians dare say foure state recited none streight painfull follow court studyed vniuersity free bee wiser onely court spent time worth greatest time consumed religion say prayer bewayle grieuous sinnes court onely gaue selfe sufficeth obey one court hee must serue religion also apparrelled lesse cost charge greater contentation person court poore gentleman courtier bound haue change sutes apparrell falcon feather religious person goe alwayes dinner finde meate table ready prepared without thought taken part shall haue fine courtier many time rise bed without euer penny purse albeit religious person life take great paine rising midnight serue god yet haue great hope death heauenly rest comfort poore courtier ala say hard life perillous death greater danger truly putteth himselfe becommeth courtier nasica gee serpent king dauid philistine southsayers euah hercules antheon theseus minocaure king menelaus wilde bore corebus monster marish perseus monstrous whale sea euery one valiant afraid one miserable courtier standeth feare court seeing neere kinsman deerest friend fauour credit himselfe richer wisheth friendes death least procureth meanes shall equall goe euen credite reputation one worst thing consider see courtier loose much time profite little many courtier spends time thing wherein spend dayes hestow night part speake ill better excel vertues vndoe equal companion flatter beloued among inferiour sort murmur one alwayes sigh lament time past nothing prouoketh courtier complaine dayly desire haue see sundry new alteration time little weigh ruine common weale may enlarge exalt owne estate also thing course court reiected fauourlesse courtier meete together murmuring prince backbiting councellers officer saying vndoe realme bring nought al presupposed like fauour estimation beareth office rule commonweale therefore commeth question courtier aduaunce himselfe come credit court one gourtier scarsly euer trust side mee thinketh life court life deede rather open penance therefore opinion wee reckon courtier aliue rather dead buried life courtier euer findeth himselfe plunged death extream passious hee perceyueth life courtier open penance preferred called ala great pitty see haplesse vnfortunate courtier hee seely soule awaketh thousand time night tosseth side side bed sometime vpright hee lyeth lamenting yron happe sigheth natiue soyle sorroweth lost honour maner spendeth whole night watch care imagining himselfe wayes hee come credite fauour againe may attaine wealth preferment others maketh mee thinke paine cruell torment seruice tribute euer body poore miserable courtier abideth despite wretched heart doth beare law court euery courtier bound serue king accompany beloued court visite noble men wayte vpon prince elbow giue vshers present auditor entertaine warden captaines port currey fauour harbinger flatter treasurer trauell speake friendes dissemble amongst enemy legges able doe thing force sufficient abide brunt heart able endure moreouer purse great inough supply deuises opinion neuer foolish marchant couetons hath solde himselfe fayre exchangde himselfe marchandize vnhappy courtier goeth court sell liberty litle winde vaine smoake court graunt courtier may haue court plenty golde siluer sumptuous apparrell fauour cresite authoritie yet withall aboundance yee cannot deny poore liberty rich substance credite therefore dare boldly say word againe one time courtier hath desire court thousand time enforce accomplish others desire neyther please like courtier abridged liberty surely commeth base vile minde lesse cowardly man lightly esteeme liberty fondly embrace bondage subiection others commaundement courtier would aunswere mee though hee serue yet least hee prince fauour would replye thus though hee bee fauour prince yet notwithstanding slaue officer courtier sell horse moyle cloke sworde like whatsoeuer hee shall haue ready money sauing liberty hee liberally bestoweth nothing hee seemeth make estimation sword appaarrell hee selleth doth liberty hee giueth man bound trauell make himselfe master others pleaseth recouer liberty maintaine bound dye thousand death speake thing haue read bookes haue seene mine eye science experiennce neuer knew courtier yet content court much lesse enioying iot liberty much esteeme al men sufficient know knew well vse would neuer treasure earth forgoe neyther gage lendi neuer precious yet court besides kind trouble haue yet touched small oft time thither commeth friend straungers necessitie honesty sake courtier must lodge home court beeing already full pestered happeneth oft time poore courtyer hath neither lodging owne lodge happily six penny purse welcome themwithall would would tell mee also griefe sorrowe poore courtyer feeleth heart hee lodgeth blinde narrowelane eateth borrowed table sleepeth hyred bedde perhaps chamber hauing doore yea part apparell armor euen sworde gage friend commeth countrey lye hee poore also stranger man house possible accept companie others perhaps needie hee sometimes better rather beare friend cost charge altogether vnable yea finde necessary shift euer made suffer friend straunger come home house knowe see miserie liueth honest heart good nature ashamed grieued discouer misery suffer abide commonly courtyer alone honest hart greeued shew misery suffer content litle couch one mattresse quilt one flockbed one pillowe one paire sheet one couerlet one fryingpan one gridyron one spit one kettle one basine one candlesticke one pot cannot doe stranger friend come hee must reputationsake hang chamber dresse vp bed furnish better must also prouide thousand trifle standeth need fall host goodman house lend thing perhaps hath chaunceth oft shalbe compelled borrow vppon pawne hyre others wheras alone owne people hee would right well contented small ordinarie stranger commeth see must greater cost charge shall spend one dinner supper hee done three dayes therefore doubtles courtyers charge friendes come see themselues honourable worthie courtyers rather fast time shewe himselfe pinch needie harde bee mocked acquaintance oh many men world waste spend one day haue trauelled get together many esteem good desire keepe onely little vain glory get name freeharted liberall man dealing honestly among friend also great trouble poore courtyer courte remoueth courtyer subiect much occasion oft time bee angrie carter muletters loding much little coming late lodging many time also must ryde noonedayes greatest heat somtimes raine dew tempest il weather whatsoeuer carter carrier loose iourney admit may easily carried therefore reasonable meete poore courtier spend one voyage remouing epences courtier court profite spare hee hath made six moneths shall wee say also stuffe moueables poore courtier necessity must buy euery place court remayneth chaires table formes stool water pot platter dish small trash would cost carriage buying anew conclude thing pertayning court painefull vnpleasant chargeable poore courtier carrie alwayes thing bee necessary need carriage broken marde left behind hazard stollen lost bee continuall courtier must bolde stout courage hee shall forced hourely leaue owne desire please content others changing shifting diuers place strange lodging oft time seruants new family dayly encreasing charge expence truely gotten gained court worth much much doth exceede spent court expences rather lauish moderate disordered well spent effect courtier spend stranger receyue lodging doe ordinary seruants keepe albeit courtier lose leaue behind euery remouing court bee small account importance yet notwithstanding griefe displeasure indeede house richly furnished replenished moueables lord master house chafe see dish glasse broken spoyled yet discommodity remouing court som courtier poore want hardly follow court others also rich compelled beare many charge company way rude ill brought vp rather beare charge iourney againe haue company godsname shall wee say yet wretched courtier whose coffer horse arrested departing debt truely lye saw courtier moile solde prouender shee eaten money sufficient pay host courtier remaining yet debter ouerplus poore man stripped euen cappe gloues satisfaction rest also sort needy courtier troublesom importune neuer cease trouble friend borrow money acquaintance finde themselues apparrell themselues others pay debt others play others giue present remouing day haue nothing wherwith pay content creditor sued lawe arrested lodging misery courtier subiect vnto creditor many time satisfied good doe take execution also body laying fast prison till bee payde satisfied whole debte oh follie may bee thought cannot moderate expences according abilitie say vprightly hee cut garment according cloth measure expences reuenues following affection desire gentleman courtyers ought order expences courtier ende hath meane commodiitie spende countreyman hath liueth home else countrey spendeth commodity hee brings house courtier consumeth court owne alone also others therefore courte elsewhere let euery wise man bee diligent bring affayres ende yet let moderate vse expences hee shall neede driuen morgage gage hee hath hee feasteth rowteth others purse lent cannot choose ende must breake deceyue creditours therfore worthiemen loue honour feare reproache ought rather suffer hunger colde thyrst care paine sorrow checkeroule ryotous prodigall spender trustlesse theyr promise suspected wordes yet another great trouble court prince exceeding dearth victualls vnreasonable want house great price much treason dishonestie courtyer fall loue hostesse hee doe husband much wrong defame wife offend friendes neighbor vtterly vndo himselfe suetonius tranquillus reciteth iulius caesar caused captaine beheaded onely slaundering defaming hostesse tarying complaint husband accusation emperour aurelianus seeing one men windowe one day pulling hostosse sleeue caused hand bee striken immediately althogh hostesse swore ieast intent plutarch booke de matrimonio saith law among licaonians stranger onely talke hostesse toung bee cut head hee passed loose head macrobius also saturnales reciteth amongst romaine reputed great infamie man came praysed beautie manner mistresse house lodged praising hee let vnderstand knew knowing spake speaking opened heart hee planely defamed made euill reported aulus gellius writeth like punishment inflicted carnall participation vestall virgines selfe also executed procured infamie hostesse lodged punishment eyther cut middest quartred foure partes else bee stoned death aliue good courtyer must also haue care courtier ought haue apparell great regarde commaund seruants looke well rydingapparell lent courtyers weare otherwhiles see kept clean wellbrushed aboue safely deliuered borrowed commonly horskeepers haue horse lowsingcloathes theyr maisters footecloath neate cleanly groomes page chamber haue apparrell proceeds great sloth negligence truely passeth bound shamefast degree yea commeth much charge courtyers conscience smal account hath let garment apparrell moueables bee spoyled lost happeneth oft negligence page seruants throweth chamber dragges vppon ground sweepes house full dust tattred torne piece hose seamrent shooes broken poore man come afterwards buye sell againe rather pitie see giue courage buye wherfore courtyer ought bee carelesse rather thinke vppon owne thing haue eye vnto goe day stable see horse kept looked hee may likewise also take another day weeke hee may finde leysure see wardroppe apparell lyeth pacience must poor man take lendeth implemets apparrell courtier neuer layeth abroad sunning beate dust neuer layeth water wash white neuer foule albeit bed implement lent courtier bee great value yet fitte throwne tayle kept filthily charily daintily doth poore labouring hus bandman keepe woollen coverlet setteth much doth iolly courtier quilt ouerpaine silke chanceth oft time also though neede poore man bed costeth lesse money rich man bed costeth yet doth serue better rich costly bed serueth gentleman nobleman true see experience poore husbandman citizen sleepeth commonly quietly case poore bedde cabben sheetes towe doth lord rich courtier lying hanged chamber bed sickenesse wrapped finest holland sheetes still sigheth complaineth finally wee conclude court remoueth courtier departeth lodging lay hee must courtesie thanke good man courtier demeane himselfe departure lodging good wife house good lodging courteous intertainment hee hath must sticke also giue somewhat remembrance besides giue certaine reward among maides men seruants house according ability may recompence past winne fauour come chap iiii courtier must doe win prince fauour diodorus siculus saith honour reuerence egyptian vsed ordinarily prince great seemed rather worship serue could neuer speake must first haue licence giuen hapned subiect egypt haue suite prince put supplication kneeling sayde word soueraigne lorde mightie prince may stand highnesse fauour pleasure boldly speake presume hold peace selfe reuerence custom towards god moses aaron tobias dauid salomon father egypt making like intercessio spake god saying domine mi rex si inueni gratiam oculis tuis loquar ad dominummeum lord king haue found fauour thy sight speake vnto thee keepe perpetuall silence seruice ill gratefull acceptable done contrary none good pleaseth party serued serueth master fauor serueth may wel take paine vndoing without hope good wil recompence wherfore touching haue said inferre hee goeth dwell abide court must aboue endeuour himselfe hee obtaine prince fauour obtaining hee must study keepe fauour little preuaile courtier bee beloued otherr prince onely misliked therefore alcamidas grecian aduertised friend athenian greatly thirst death theban desired life hee answered thus athens thirst death thebe likewise desiring life bee sorry lament howbeit yet k philip soueraigne lord master must doe thousand manner seruices cause hate dislike v least displeasure world sufficeth therefore paine trouble fauour court troble fauour court great great hee offend bee displeasure albeit prince pardon fault yet neuer returneth fauor againe conclude hee onely incurreth indignation hee may make iust reckoning neuer maruellous hardly receyued againe fauour therefore sayeth diuine plato bookes shewed friend like maner go visite come chamber receiue v bidding v come chamber sit downe standing talke v without curtesie entertainement wee may easily perceyue manner entertainement hee giueth v good honest leaue depart wise fine courtier easily finde vnderstand signes hee doe somtimes word also courtier must take great discretion courtyer vse curtesie heede seeming vse courtesie hee happen make foolish countenance pulling cappe making courtesie comming hall taking stoole sitte downe lest hee bee therefore marked mocked stander noted proud presumptuous stay let trifle man rather getteth downe together must aske body doth whether house merry good health thing wee must first procure owne priuate commodity secondly desire friend also courtyers visitation hee may curious inquisitiue newes neyther ouerbusie tell newes friend aduertized truth might lightly hee would thanke comming commend courtesie notwithstanding blame newes count lyar happen finde party visite sad comfortles necessitie although hee friend yet hee christian wee ought comfort word seeke also helpe relieue somewhat lycurgus lawes made ordained lawfull man come see prisoner help deliuer poore man relieue sicke diseased person shold helpe comfort able power truly thinkes lycurgus great reason make law since one gyft necessitie better thousand word see experience man minde one onely thing giuen better contented satisfied thousand word speake vnto house goe visite hee dwelleth bee owne inheritance feesimple hee hath lease purchase hee hath builded ground haue repaired new coated courtyer must pray let see hee hath seene hee must greatly commend mortall men haue commonfault humour must praised doings reproued theyr fault visite sicke person must remember speake little vnto softelie pleasaunt matter c otherwise seeme wil also beleeue came see rather aggrauate sicknes comfort wee must euer make short visitation onely sicke diseased whole found good courtier must take leaue hee euen pleasant discourse end may intreateth tarry longer tarry till seeme licence outwarde signes ceremony hee shall goe visite another let take heed hee bee long tedious talke person hee visiteth doe rise plaine token hee wearie company long tarrying sith rose giue ocasion depart wife hee visiteth bee sister kinswoma courtier visites bee familiar acquintance together hee seeme aske much lesse desire see scipio sayth man trust see wife two thing trust proue sword also custome vsed among courtier goe man house see light horse send know whether within courtier taketh leaue hath visited hee must suffer gentleman bring chamber accompany much lesse come downe stayres hee vse manner shall bee bound thanke comming shall commend ciuility happen wee goe visite noble man beloued court lodging comming hee ready com house ride abroad fieldes take ayre ride vnto courte solicite affayres ride abroade towne pleasure diligent courtier must willingly accompany offer seruice hee hee shall deserue double thankes one comming gentle offer company visite prince seruants manner alwaies occupied prince seruice neyther shall haue time leysure haue haue time commodious see home owne house yet least good courtier must needes accompany time goe abroade reason esteemed courtier make accompanieth importunate troublesome chap vii good countenance modesty courtier haue behauing himselfe prince noble man table time meale abiding still prince custome wherein courtier may lauish hia reputation court must case goe seldome abroade others table alwayes keepe owne courtier runneth table table eate others cost haue meate free sparing purse hee prodigall lauish good reputation therefore eschines philosopher demaunded one day man counted good answered thus become perfect greeke must go church willingly good deuotion warres necessity feast banquet neyther necessity vnlesse doe honour pleasure doe inuite thee suetonius tranquillus writeth emperour augustus prohibited rome man enuite feast banquet friend would honour come feast send home house meat hee haue ad feast banquet house asked certain friend meant make law gaue answere cause moued mee good friend forbidd playes banquet rome play man kept himselfe swearing terrible blaspheming name god banquet euery man giuen de ect defame neighbour cicero recounteth cato censor lying death bed mercy god say word foure thing remember haue done life wherein haue rather shewed selfe voluptuous negligent barbarian wise good romane citizen find selfe sore grieued first spent whole day forgot serue god profite common wealth thing neuer haue done great dishonor philosopher counted idle negligent person noble heart bee counted ranke coward second safely might haue gone land perillously wise man may put himselfe perill hazarded selfe vpon water thing well haue let alone neuer wise man euer haue put perill vnlesse seruice god increase honour defence country third opened great secret matter importance woman ought lesse haue done rest graue matter thing counsel woman capable giue counsell much lesse take least keepe secret fourth another time contented ouercome friend mine earnestly inuited house dinner thereupon went haue done say truth neuer famous worthie person went eate man house hee diminished liberty hazarding also grauity reputation rumour brute others wordes wisely spoken prudent cato well worthy bee noted carried away much drawing last home euen last breathing hower hee onely spake foure thing whereof although hee romane yet shewed v repenting mind woe mee albeit doe beare name christian yea indeed yet last day nature summons mee feare belieue assuredly shall haue cause repent foure thing thing heretofore recyted wee may easily coniecture albeit wee contented entreated requested many thing yet onely goe others table feast strange house bee intreated rather compelled will courtyer forced importunacie accept bidding hee bidde feast may purchase thak bidder without offering himselfe hee deserueth great thankes bidder comming bidding seeme rather dinner staungers trauell way nobleman gentleman come court day courtyer graunteth dyne man day hee bindeth himselfe beholding bid although come good yet acquite courtesie done hee bound necessitie also small reputation worthy great reproche courtyer make boast hath eaten table officer bordes court man say hee hath beene dinner supper owne house truly remember knew courtyer might dispende aboue two hundred ducates yeare told mee assured neuer bought sticke wood warme within chamber pot seeth meate neither spit roast euer hee cater prouision saue made register many nobleman bords amongst equally deuided dinner supper meanes whereof hee saued charge saue onely men boordewages vilenesse discurtesie could equall miserie shame carelesse courtyer sure meanest poorest slaue world liueth hire deserueth compared ende wee desire rich vnto ende desire wee good world may honored relieue parent kinsman thereby also win v new friend state condition soeuer bee warie incomming nobleman table hee doe much commend fare ordinarie complaine men table hath sed demeane visite noble mean table kinde treason defame slaunder whose house wont visite oft hee set meat others house graunt fit lawfull young courtier runne wel leape farre throw barre iron daunce well ride horse well manage giue carrere well turne well handle weapon well breake staffe well otherwise helpe himselfe manner weapon one defie another drinkking great sacriledge courtier scithiens ratifieth trogus pompeins sober modest eating drinking meales foule fault among breake winde belch therefore dayes wee finde scithiens many drinker depart feast sull fraught immediatly come home vnlode charged stomacke lay open haue eaten drunken wherefore hee vseth drinke cleane pure water liberty drinke wine simply without compound excessiue drinking wine doth alone trouble distemper braine iudgement drinker discouereth great horrible vice therfore yet touching matter say againe fond dispute argument proue wine best pleasant sweetest oldest newest sharpe harde soft sweet clearest darkest best tast quickest sauour iudge taste wine know goodnes perfection rather say truely belongeth tauerner vintner rightly honest courtier fitter decent also talke arm chiualry deale discourse bacchus feast mockery foolish nicenesse drink water alone also cannot drinke cuppe hath beene wine filled shall also bee circumspect bidden stragers house hee drinke deepe draught hee leaue nothing cuppe neyther drinke long hee hath breath water stand eye againe graue sober courtier neuer drinke till hee might till none lest hee table hee enter argument dispute neyther hee bee obstinat opinion much lesse vse vncomly talke must also bridle nature much cry laughing doe like soundeth reproch noted glutton drunkard like case far worse foole iester also preuaileth litle courtier bee moderat honest eating hee talke bee vsed table dishonest insolent talke many time hapneth noble men table take pleasure see eate drinke well heare tell lie pleasant boorde therefore haue sayde wise courtier praise commend hee seeth serued another man table lawfull dislike disprayse hee fedd man charge must inforce himselfe alwayes presence company vertuous noble men shall conferre graue wise honest gentleman court vsing way hee shall binde reason dayly accesse shall purchase himselfe good opinion behaue themselus recommend charge ouersight deare especiall friend reproue fault doe amisse say better lay yrons foot send bedlam like house mad men bee kept bee bound yrons bring wittes againe make wise send court loose liberty without guide next way make fooles worse madde men assuring greater daunger iniury bee done young man sent court committed charge one shold take care looke straightly himselfe vitious ill disposed person honest wise courteous amongst hee shall put vpon certaine graue stayed modesty fitting himselfe onely company also apt disposed honest vertuous exercise decent right gentleman vertuous courtier shuning best policy light foolish vaine toyes others yet notwithstanding intent meaning seeme perswade teach become hypocrite onely bee courteous honest well beloued dumme among talke wisely graue matter belieue hee accounted trim courtyer take book hand pray others take ball play goe honest recreation pastime exercise bodie would rather take foole hypocrite vertuous honest young man good reason childe vse pleasure pastime childe young men disportes actes youth olde men also graue wise recreation fit end doe best wee cannot flye motion flesh wherein wee vice young courtyer eschew borne world young gentlemencourtyers must take heede become troublesome importunate quarreller filchers lyars vacabonds slaunderers way giuen vice thing would seemeto take pastime pleasure may vse discretion thing lawfull irreprouable obseruing time houres conuenient therewitall accompanie themselues fellowes companion also young courtyer commeth newly court must necessitie well apparelled according degree calling seruants follow well appointed courte men regarde onely house familie hee commeth marke also apparell seruants follow mislike one thing much court doe rather honour reuerence man braue sumptuous apparell vitious doe man graue wise vertuousand yet neuerthelesse courtyer may assure himselfe esteeme eyther hee vertouus nobly borne hee also sumptuously apparelled well accompanied onely euery man account esteeme wherefore durst take vpon mee sweare possible take oath bodyes would sweare needed much lesse desire large compassed gown euery puffe winde might swell sayles ship neyther long trayling ground gather dust cast eye howbeit thinke nowadayes fine men weare large wide woman long traynes vpon ground court elsewhere man make reckning spendeth orderly onely vpon necessary goe cleanly withall set prodigall excessiue superfluous doings apparell moderate proceedeth wisely holde court miserable couetous man contrarily hee prodigall lauish meane ought vsed apparell expence count noble worthy person albeit courtyer come noble house yong yeares rich wealthie yet would like better hee vse rather certain mean measure apparell wearing comely gentlemanlike others coste worship like would count foole wearing could pay likewise would thinke simple hee ware become might easily come apparrell agreeable yeares say holy dayes richer brauer worke dayes winter hotest furres summer light garment sattin damaske ride others lesser price durable wisdome man knowne speaking discretion decerned apparrell let poore courtier study weare deuise new strange fashioned garment humour shall quickly vndoe himselfe giue others occasion also follow light vaine inuention dayes found many strange wayes dresse meate many fashion pattern apparrell haue vniuersities taylers cooke greater vanity lightnes suffer mother gown made fit daughter saying olde fashion vse new kinde apparrell attire farre old manner notwithstanding gownes bee manner new good whole cleane rich well made without weme yet daughter must needes haue new gownes whence new fashion apparrell proceede marriage may aptly say new folly seekes alwayes new gowne namely light person without wit discretion pray goodly sight court see foolish courtier weare demy cappe scant couer crowne heade haue beard merquizotted payre perfumed gloues hand shooes cut best fashion little curted cappe hose fayre pulled doublet sleeues brauely cut pinct rapier dagger guilded side side pestilence penny hath purse blesse besides deepe marchants booke thing hee hath taken vp credit nagges foote clothes would litle narrow seeme fryer hood neyther great large foot cloth bishop moyles also courtier must see footcloth good whole cleane without spot tattered seame rent speake miserable courtier haue may bee rightly termed courtier footclothes threed bare broken seeme rent foule durty narrow digged full hole spurres therefore man deserueth called right courtier vnlesse hee fine neate apparrell hee weareth also courteous ciuill word entertainement yet touching rest furniture horse gelding harnesse trappes must bee kept blacke cleane must looke reines bridle bee broke vnsowed speak without cause number courtier primero sticke set vp iest crown yet think much giue poore horsekeepers penny buy payre reynes truly courtier iudgement content tye horse vntagged point see fire smoke hee warme ride broken reines cut meate table rusty knife would thinke base borne rudely brought vp courtier ride horse let looke euer hee take backe haue furniture fitte maine tayle finely combed good order great noties stirroppes bright glistering stirrops leather strong saddle well stuffed aboue let sit vpright seate carry body euen swaruing neyther side holding legges still keepe stirrop name bee called chiuallier signifieth tongue rider horse came first hee could ride manage horse well would stirre legges spurre horse let beware hee stoupe forwardes body doth spurre horse let spurre low hie flankes whether runne stand still horse let alwayes haue eye vpon reines case raines goe hand giuing horse carere let writhe body bee busie beating spurring horse oft carere know spurre giue head pull backe againe stoppe haue seene many take vpon indeed euer skilfull coulde well courtier mounted horse moyle without rapier side seemeth rather physitian goeth visite sicke patient gentleman court pleasure disport rideth abroad throgh street chance intreated noble man accopany ride behind throgh street euery honest courtier ought doe vnasked ready offer himselfe waite vpon goe willingly let fine courtier beware giuing hand gentlewoman hee gloued bee horsebacke hee talke bare headed doe honour shee ride behinde chance discourse together let neuer looke backe vpon behold rude manner token ill education one common courtesie among courtier talke lady gentlewoman entertaining suffer raigne ouer bee ouercommed argument holde good manner doe seruice haue occasion offered serue shal accompany gentlewoman goe visitation talke abroad pleasure streetes must ride fayre softly happen keepe long talke till alight good courtier must beare courteously make good countenance thogh grieued nothing sith wee know almost end woman talke well woman beginne talke impossible tomake end vnlesse bee ouerta ken night preuented om accident hee bee courter must weare shooes blacke cleane hose straight legges garment without plight wrincle sword fayre varnished shirt finely wrought cappe standing good grace chiefest thing court noble men bee rich apparrell right courtier bee fine cleanly decent man weare slipper long corke seene garment till torne surre till bare shyrtes till worne cap till turffe greasie coate till threedbare girdle till halfebroken courtyer may onely weare garment content himselfe also like others shall behold hee determined goe courte hee must suppose goe thither well apparelled else sure wil account right courtyer case excuse pouertie may alleadged thinke rather miserable poore courtyers good courtyer may spare courtier spare spend court spend afterwards home must pinch home liberall afterwards court yet againe returne recite courtyer come prince fauour hee may way bee sparing miserable rather honestly liberall bountifull seldomtimes concurre two thing together miserable yet miserie attaine prince fauour remember saw friende mine courte weare ierkin faced coller marten bare greasy certaine portingale courte pleasaunt companyon came gentleman asked properly faire furres ware necke gentleman answered martin martin syr saith portingale think ore rather like surres ashwendesday shrouetuesday finely portingale compared mardi tuesday martin furres likewise martin furres mardi sure hee great reason praise greatly rebuke honour worship haue coller ierken lined faire white lamme old stale dyrtie sweatie martin bruch courtyer must weare cappe must rich excellently well wrought deuse motto hee haue curious though euery man may reade yet shall vnderstand meanes deuises euer lightly grounded vaine fonde toyes therefore bee much secrete obscure sure faulte great enough man deuise though hee doe bewray also seruaunts waytes vpon must needes goe handsomely apparelled fine neat courtier seruant bee apparrelled cloathing small honour master well apparelled let seruants goe beggarly many courtyers haue men following thred bare clokes torn cote foule shirt broken hose rent shoe poore seruingmen one moneth weare master giueth three moneths weare proper flesh wise man part meere folly keepe greater traine able courtier hath alwayes many seruants wayting going tattered torn hauing good thing put backes least haue meane simple shall sooner winne name broker preferreth men seruice master keepeth seruants himselfe good courtier must giue vnto seruants serue eyther apparrell wage seruant serueth onely house bare meate drinke shall neuer serue truely doth serue therefore let courtyer looke well hee entertaine man seruice first agree standing wage vnles bee hee nephew kinsman deere friend else ende nobleman vnlesse doe hee shall finde yeares ende hee shall spend hee gaue ordinary wage besides bee contented although greater charge also let consider well happen hee hath neede seruaunts wayte vpon brother neighbour childe offered vnto whether shal receiue hath receiued house eyther hee shall compelled beare faultes disorder shall doe else desirous rebuke reforme send home againe shall winne anger displeasure father proper kinsfolk surely courtyers take kinde men seruice haue great deale pain trouble truly great crueltie courtyer shold driuen beare dishonestie man serues whe owne father could away condition father much blinded besotted fatherly affection difficulte besides please contented courtyer hath receyued sonne seruice entreat hee owne kinsman would haue courtyer maister beare sawcie deshonesties leawdnes cannot frame young man theyr minde would haue yet least would haue maister pittie hee butyoung hath knowledge wincke faultes good hope better amendment courtier may onely see men well apparrell must prouide also haue meate enough put belly seruants starued meat wont small seruice besides complaine much let beware also doe take seruice lewde person busie body vnquiet men cutpurse ruffian quarreller whoremonger hee finde hee hath house let turne seruice straight keeping mate house house shall neuer wel ordered shall euer quarrelling swearing amongst besides neighbor common people shall bee offended let good courtier foresee haue cardes dice house occupie seruants thriftles seruants giuen play beginne first play afterwardes learne steale let courtier well aduised also chideth seruants hee bee lowde voyce may bee heard abroad hostes innekeepers beeing lowde hee bee dishonoured blamed ill word giueth man let take heed also hee doe call seruants drunkard theeues villaines iewes like name reproch like vncurteous wordes small correction add yet bring displeasure disdaine inough courtier cannot giue bountifully pleasure officer seruants aboute yet least howsoeuer world go let behind paying whole wage due might lightly happen seruats would begin make complaint vnhappily end might come die misery enemy hand enemy world cruell much feared seruant contented master theefe house knoweth hee well peece master harnesse wanting body set hee would place haue arrow token therefore soone commeth courtier eares seruants complaine eyther let giue al would haue put house immediately doe let assured seruant neuer leaue till hee haue put discord friend defame others aboue thing haue spoken yet courtier must chiefely looke man trusted honour case many wont onely deceiued also many time scorned many put good hand trust man honour thing greatest weight importance sooner commit trust young foolish simple page wise stayed man therefore much busines weight importance much lesse reueled secresie boy hee doe otherwise assure hee shall sooner spoken euery man hee shall haue businesse dispatched courtier must also haue chamber wel hanged finely kept cleane house family good order euery man quiet cleannesse house ciuility seruants great token witnesse nobility master courtier chamber hee lyeth bed must first bee made cloth dore let downe chamber swept hanging stuffe good order perfume sweet odor laugh vpon man come court filthy ill furnished hanging stuffe man come see chamber seeme rather sheepe coates courtier chamber chap ix wise manner courtier haue serue honour lady gentlewoman also satisfie please vshers porter king house let good courtier good caueat courtier bee alwayes circumspect hee seeke fauour iustices hand lawfull eyther hee bee denyed shall returne shame graunted hee shall leaue conscience gage sutes controuersies betweene men religion spirituall court let case deale first shew seeme easie iudge come vnripping matter iudge matter great charge conscience manie tower ierusalem diuell might haue brought iesvs christ haue perswaded tempted haue thrown himselfe howbeit would bring pinacle church let v vnderstand therby tooke pleasure one sinne done church holy person tenne committed world worldling notwithstanding courtyer doth see reason side recommended hee neede neuer passe entreate charge owne proper conscience example man intreat speake iudge write letter manie time wee see iudges make custome many iudges much account one word letter fauor estimation prince religion iustice another man alwayes write forme right worshipfull honourable letter fauour shall requested c wordes iudge may know requested besought seem write affection otherwise shall write satisfie others thinke doe eyther reason dutie hee performe letter like consideration modestie good prince haue hee doeth commaund like selfesame shold esteemed fauoured court obserue request maketh many time request beloued courte celeritie performed commission prince accomplished let courtyer alwayes haue minde also hee meete nobleman knight way hee doe condition return keepe companie although nobleman knight striue haue got backe yet let suffer himselfe ouercome let men knowe notwithstanding nobleman knight passe degree apparrell yet shall exceede curtesie ciuilitie courtly company vnderstood offered knight rideth citie pleasure goeth alone sheweth forhead vnpleasaunt countenance troubled minde yet courtyer neuertheles must offer himselfe accompanie hee doe accept hee may withstand importune doe thinke bee accounted courteous would repute troublesom man courtyer shall accompany nobleman court let contention place accompanying noble man seeme contende courtyers place honour presence behinde another strife comming nobleman eare whome accompanie might easily happen companie came wayte vpon doe honour seruice seeme dishonour offend little knoweth honor meaneth trifle hee seeketh wise courteous courtyer hath seeke honour rideth cheeke cheeke also beloued prince nobleman accompanyed hee come hard court courtyers bee readie alight horse quickely hee shall likewise take horse againe ready take horse backe thus shall bee neare hee lighteth horse afterwards helpe hee mounteth horse againe perhaps comming chamber lordes seruants want consideration remember holde open cloth ouer dore good diligent courtier sodenly put himselfe lift hold vp many time great honour courtier accounted one good maner bringing vp court court reputed great famous captaine war since courtier determined accompany noble man court hee also bound lawes court wayte vpon home againe hee doe noble man shall bee beholding attendance hee hath giuen vpon co pany ride come speake courtier equall degree point ood man bee obserued aring eaking ur superiours meaner calling condition himselfe one first chiefest point ciuility good manner suffer open lip speake hee haue cappe head one talke commonly cappe hand great authority reuerence duty subiect prince seruant master good courtier must euer speake againe speaketh reuerence doeth reuerence put cappe putteth hee must doe without respect hee friend foe effect good maners man ought much bee enemie enmitie breake boundes curtesie humanity rather fit common person courtlike gentleman meane thing shewe enmitie say truely good courtyer shewe enmitie heart putting pulling cap taking sworde hand reuenge quarrell courtyer church court chappell prince set gentleman happely commeth place must doe curtesie giue place seat pray sit downe yea place fit gentleman sit curtesie also hee would offer iniurie accept yet least let courtyer doe hee may make take peece stoole parting seate may also come part heart set hard courtyer begun talke secrete together hee ill taught listneth men speaking secret rise thence goe little aside court wil say ill taught brought vp wanteth ciuilitie good manner seeme harken bodyes tale secret courtyers must haue frienship also porter open courtgates kept fast chained contented suffer moyle footclothnagge enter vppon yet hee may bee angrie courtyer must needes imploy whole person good seruing hee loues courtyer marryed surely fit loue woman wife neyther honest woman serued married courtyer manner loues ende spoken would wish seeme know much lesse angrie withall giue distastfull word reporter thereof choller ouerpaste euill word hee hath spoken anger may turne displeasure hath done hurt caused speake word therefore surely bridle tongue rather diuine humane vertue chiefly instant heart maistered subdued chollericke passion afterwards happeneth many time quiet againe mindes sorry wee haue spoken anger yea haue angred v courtyer weigh euery worde spoken esteeme euery thing done purchase himselfe continuall sorrowfull life yea measure troublesome vnpleasant sith prince court euer full serpentstongues venomous hart lyeth man power let heart men hate v tongue speake ill v would aduise courtyer take ill spoken sporte mirth anger seneca sayde wisely spoken greater reuenge punish iniurious word worthy saying seneca seeme laugh thing naturall proper woman men desire take reuenge wordes like word againe sith noble heart esteemeth honour must haue handes tongue tongue hand many haue seene court court respect reuenge one onely silly word touched much would put themselus good fame perill yet end reuenge desired rather redoubled themselues loosing fond vaine attempt therefore conclude bee great fauour estimation prince court also fauour credite prince desire continue perseuer fauour still must make account wordes spoken offence done fauour haue neede suffer occasion report till present day adicted loue affect nature bindeth see also many young courtier though vertuous noble hauing inherited succeeded nobilitie bloud ancestor meanes whereof honoured reuerenced possessing also greatnesse
