thing wee haue spoken follow owne inuentions imagination ancestor knowing would haue fled hate mislike doubtlesse aliue would haue followed therefore rather token lightnesse good one leaue helpe relieue owne friend kinsfolk succour doe good stranger others hee neuer knew tell assure one greatest loss mishap come noble house haue new friendshippe parciality stranger men vnknowne gentleman giueth himselfe follow one pleaseth fantasie best leaueth leaue ancestor heretofore loued liked shall see old friend onely leaue forsake cleane giue ouer shortly shall finde substance faculty consume waste away besides honour house bee brought vtter decay obliuion haue spoken onely aduise prince officer haue credite authoritie doe fauour support ayde partiall sect namely concerneth state body commonwealth esteemed prince easily lesse occasion doe vndoo themselues lose credite haue wonne reason partialiteis faction maintaine doe daily benefites suit importune prince wherefore seruants officer king house although bee good fauour prince please like well yet may hardly support doe hurt others absolutely lord prince themselues albeit pleaseth king call honour enrich good possession yet king cannot like shall bee suborner faction quarels amongst subiects commonwealth yet neuerthelesse happeneth many time see themselues onely fauour aboue others presume doe violence wrong others trusting great fauour shall suffice cloke hide fault shall commit neuer ought think yet respect world doe vnhaply might crime doe commit although prince power doe great thing yet could time honor excuse offence seeme protect lewdnesse without great murmour discontentation subiects know well court mindes affection opinion courtier diuers variable notwithstanding beloued prince endeauour himselfe hee possible please content euery man court yet impossibility thing impossible euer attaine winne men good willes neuerthelesse hee must trimly wisely behaue himselfe doings least cannot pollicy deuice make friend haue yet iust occasion giuen bee enemy see meane reason deuice pollicy man fauour negligence defend honoured esteemed court detraction enuy therefore boldly giue aduice matter iustice publike affayres beare himselfe vpright notwithstadding repine authoritie credite yet haue cause offered complayne courtyer forced complaine owne familiar companyons fellowseruants first acquainted king otherwise might happen like fortune brought high estate hee pride might ouerthrow againe bring low hee haue saide truely great deale saying would haue made fall downe right beeing propertie fortune suffer baser sort hath caled honour onely returne meane estate calling first neuer leaue fauored prince men aucthoritie neuer satisfied till shee hath throwne downe headlong extreame misery neuer rise againe agathocles first sonne potter afterwards made king scicilia whilst hee liued hee euer vsed manner treasurie iewell house yea also table amongst cup dish gold siluer hee also earth amongst beeing asked occasion great treasurie masse golde siluer vile base thing earth hee aunswered thus drinke golden cup eate earthen dyshes giue thankes vnto god potterssonne brought mee royall estate worthy speech agathocles k scicilia mighty king also haue euer cause bee humble lowly flye pryde easier thing likelyer king become potter potter attain greatnes state king wordes agathocles euer worthie bee noted nory since see plainly giue man fall little stone sufficeth make v stumble fall ground rayse v vp againe wee must needes helpe v power handes foot may well braue courtier fauoured court hee came degree honour meane house b fuly borne besides esteemed nobilitie bloud vnknowne countrey poore parent small substance better otherwise fauoured fortune birth linage thing hath cause ashamed rather glory praise god hee shall euer bee esteemed court wel thoght remember whence hee came regarde first estate hee shall waxe glorious high minded reason fauour present vtterly forgetting first rising titus liuius reciteth renowmed romane quintus cincinnatus came bee made captaine rome hee taken field labouring man plowing tilling ground noble person beeing occupied great affayres common weale eyther prouisions munition expedition warre wont sigh captaines say ala could tell newes beefes doe graunge sheepe mountaines whether seruauntes haue prouided hay pasture keepe next yeare surely thought whosoeuer speakes wordes mouth must needes haue little pride heart vndoubtedly hee proued word true shewed hee spake hee thought good earnest without intent iest since afterwards returned home againe follow plough plant vine see owne thinges gouerned leauing behinde perpetuall testimony noble worthy doings common weale also greatly enriched famous act saul king israel taken fot god annointed samuel father poore husbandman countrey hee youth brought vp trade holde plough yet hee king neuer disdayned plough ground sow oates driue beast pasture home againe good king glory day holde plough morrow fight sword fortune therfore sheweth selfe enemy great dignity high calling shee ouerthroweth bringeth low meane estate hath good cause complain fortune cruelty bewayle wretched happe ashamed see lothsome misery shee worketh contrarily mean estate brings great honour credite must needes great honor glory therefore say let beware beare rule authority court proud glorious high minded neither otherwise detected kinde vice though neuer much fauour estimation sith fortune sheweth spight proud disdainefull heart rather humble meeke stop enemyes mouth foole wee see fauoured court offended one another wee say heate wee see eate much wee say good stomacke rise late excuse say late ere went bed hee wearie watching play oft say doth pastime hee carefull keeping hee hath together hee wi pollitike hee speake much hee pleasaunt man giuen merrie speake little wise modest hee spend much liberall bountifull glorious proude shall man say honest meanes pride fault inexcusable wee excuse surely let others looke knowe truely faultes error men may honestly excused saue onely pride though many time commit offence frailty offend pride commeth great folly want discretion contrarie lowly curteous condition courtyers onely depresse refist detraction murmuring enemy doth inforce willes say well god doeth suffer many time peruerse nature condition one subdued ouercome good gentle vsage another therefore beloued courte take great heed shew themselues prowd word much lesse ceremony vse court going vp stayres entring dores taking stoole sit downe also putting cap c though perhappes hee shall reade aduertisementes thinke rather precept child men yet answer neuerthelesse verie necessary fauour court courtier without vse may happily nourish venernous serpent brest therefore without great reason wee haue spoken haue little heed taking sometimes may follow great trouble fauoured courtier many time murmur putting cappe hee courteously saluted doe deny fauour requested one courtier leaue doe curtesie another say hee doth hee beareth ill want bringing vp hee bee great king say want good maners proude say truly vnhappy degree euer wee bee sundry diuers thrals mishap yet none neere neighbour highest authority greatest fauor prince many shootes hitte downe white fauour put vp againe restore place liue contented life man neede want nothing neyther haue occasion trouble thing trouble v vale misery many aboundance thinges contrarily rare come wee neede want wee may iustly account life wofull miserable aboue others sure farre greater grieues displeasure wee receyue one onely thing wee want pleasure great wee haue hundred others whereof haue aboundance besides familiar prince cannot thinke themselues mighty fortunate man may presume call blessed happie serue honor others persecute house haue flatter make much want court others murmur speake ill haue cause somtimes reioyce fauour haue likewise continuall trouble feare shall fall bee put fauour glory haue great treasure sorrow also haue enemy seruices company haue doe delight continuall businesse haue vex wee may say plastering house neuer fayre become blacke spotte time wormes vermine doe eate wast bee none dare admonish great men authority tell faultes wordes mouth yet take vpon mee doe writing say speake nothing noted step treade seene euery morsell meate eate marked accused pleasure take thinges haue obserued pleasure done registred ill know published finally conclude fauourites court compared game table fauoured prince game table whereat euery man playeth cardes dice serpent tongue therefore haue sayde againe returne say accepted prince must liue continually wisely aduisedly doings true true euery man tongue runnes much time opportunity like defame tongue would offende hand wee doe speake much looke defend life foresee may preserue honour good perill giue precept good occasion looke put disgrace king dayes life vtter vndoing ouerthrowe king neede onely giue eare attention enemy chap xvi author admonisheth fauour great prince take heede deceipts world learne liue dye honourably leaue court age ouertake king aldericke kept seuerine romane consull prisoner otherwise named boetius consull complained much fortune saying ala fortune hast thou forsaken mee age since thou diddest fauour mee much youth serued thee many yeares hast thou left diseourse betwixt fortune consul seuerius hand mine enemy complaint fortune made answere thus thou art vnthankeful mee seuerius sith haue vsed thinges thee manner neuer vsed like romane true tell thee consider seuerius made thee whole sicke man woman excellent witte vnderstanding grosse rude rich poore wise foolish free bound senator plebeian noble valiant cowardly romane barbarian stranger borne great meane estate graue man light vaine person fortunate vnlucky worthy fame obliuion conclude say gaue thee part common weale thou haddest good cause haue pittie others others cause haue spight enuie thee againe replyed seuerius answere saide oh cruell spightfull fortune liberall thou art thing thou speakest resolute thinges thou disposest sith alwayes thou doest thou wilt seldome thou oughtest thou knowest mishappe remember man hath beene rich fortunate time see himselfe broght extreame miserie heare fortune thou oughtst know thou knowest hee neuer rich scant knoweth pouertie ala pittie rich pleasure ease doth sorrow much present extreamitie bewayleth forepassed felicitie tell thee also thou oughtest belieue wee repute happy thou neuer exaltest gauest honor vnto thou hast called high honour afterwardes hast ouerthrowne brought lower worser state mee oh fortune tell thee truely thinke man fortunate neuer knew goodfortune meant discourse betwixt fortune consull seuerius wee may perceiue comprehend truly none may thought vnfortunate miserable haue great honour reputation cannot thoght abased state countenaunce prosperitie fauoured fortune may well say neuer man world free neuer suffered fortune enter gate haue desirous tell thing fauor credit prince shold reckon much fauour neyther fauour sorie whit great authoritie credite man hath court mortall life ende nothing else little worm apple wizell corne magot pea without seem good within rotten eaten prince authoritie aboue others supream subiect censor iudges reproue wordes saying neither magistrate render vp account doings whereof proceedes haue freewill loue haue free libertie hate absolute power punish therefore fauor court shall read suddenly fauours prince change wrytings mine must well consider meane thing haue spoken whereby shall easily know prince lesse apte hate day loued yesterday loue morrowe hated day first chiefest point courtyer ought obserue feare god aboue follow profession life good christian ende liue court safety hauing good pure conscience great credite fauour haue therfore let euery courtyer belieue well fauor faour best surest way obtaine good world also preseruation soules esteeme make account holie scripture god commandements hee doe otherwise shall happen many time vnto dispatch weyghtiest affaire needefull businessos euen hee shall thinke matter brought prosperous ende without doubt dispatch step crooked fortune wonted poison either make manner beginne suite new againe least ouerthrow quite prince court many time certaine suite haue good better end looked contrarily many others point dispatching yet sinister accident clean ouerthrowne succeeding contrary assured expectation yet notwithstanding seemeth suiter cause hereof commeth eyther soliciters negligence default litle care follow else malice ill fauoured court tooke vpon suite yet neyther one cause disorder onely diuine prouidence god admonish v action doings little preuayleth v moue king officer matter doe deserue god hand obtaine therefore sayde diuine plato timeon haue honour prosperity life haue worthie saying plato much neede good counsell poore afflicted creature haue help remedy surely wisely profoundly spoken neede misery wretched life bringeth men despayre likewise see prosperity induce men forget themselues state haue hitherto spoken hope yet speak none vnderstand conceiue time nauigation fortunate prosperous winde afterwardes turning contrary euen shore side haue cast rockes vtterly perished end reading wrytings may yet lament mourne pittie others onely reade goe compare put together rich poore sorrowfull merry fortunate vnfortunate fauoured banished vertuous noble vicious defamed wee shall finde without doubt number farre greater could rise againe beeing downe taken fall keepe themselues authoritie fauour fortune brought haue saide fewe time euery moment would returne say againe trayterous worlde doings deceytfull fortune shee promiseth doubtful make belieue make rich beloued raise high estate doe honour afterwards contrarily spinne thousand deceipts trumperyes make sooner fall ground surely haue seene fewe remember haue read none vnto fortune euer shewed herselfe benigne curteous euer put man chiefest toppe prosperitie fauour fewe dayes tooke life least ende iourney shee made runne secret disgrace mishappe therefore would courtyer obtayneth fauour court rich commonwealth reckon esteeme lent giuen gouerne thing fortune hee would man hee trusted worthy saving seneca seneca saith man afflicted fortune hee onely trusteth without feare suspect courtyers great fauor authority ought know like deepest sea soonest perish shippes highest mountain sunne hath alwayes least force power greenest bough soonest hidden fowler little net catch silly byrdes fullest bayts meate fish soonest taken great force wind doth blow highest tree prowd stately building earthquake doth hurt soonest ouerthrow euen meane fortune neuer stroue throw downe anie made great honour fauour doe take great good lacke though thing succede fauoured court better hee looked see brought friend great estate honour albeeit fortune time dissemble hath forgoten afterwards giue greater punishment maruell speake euen proceedes nothing else wanting wit capacitie vnderstand greater sicknes world health greater pouertie neuer haue neede thing greater temptation neuer tempted greater sadnesse alwayes merry greater daunger neuer danger many time happeneth man thinketh passe ouer dangerous floud safe enough horse falleth ouer head eares drowneth master hee escapeth hardly socrates one day demaunded true saying socrates sure certaine thing life aunswered thus nothing certain life account thing vncertaine hee hath among rich greater haue life health life bee doubtfull vnquyet suretie certaintie may bee found surely none king agesilaus beeing requested certaine grecian captain go see olympiade mount olympus philosopher assemble dispute rich men countrey came buy sell thing answered mount olympus solde exchanged sorrow mirth sicknesse health honour infamy life death would onely goe see would also spend speech king agesilaus worth haue since buyer mortall thing also hee buyeth condemned death buye nothing life since carrie mee graue yet another deceipt poore courtyers fall daylie liuing many yeares think assuredly belieue ende light time hope haue ease rest mockery thinke extreame madnesse hope year grow ounce ounce sorrowes trouble encrease pound denie milke kept many dayes doth corrupt becommeth sower sharpe yea garment olde haue beene long worne without euer moth doth touch doth ende also become rag dust therefore doe inferre certain thing young men dye quickly much olde men assured haue long time liue many court prince also finde themselues laden sinnes wickednesse thinke assuredly changing age time fortune shall onely leaue vice shall discharged also manie grieues trouble see afterwardes happen contrary way plaine world ascent discent v goe vp toppe riuer v passe ouer terrible mountaine feare crooked illfauoured way loose v caue hole fall also thinke certainely sunne cannot lose light moone eclipsed starres may darkened earth shall cease bring forth sea flow water runne fire burne winter cold let also bee assured man cannot bee excused suffer abide much sure impossible hee passe one day without trouble sinister hap fortune greatest trumpery deceite courtier part abused waxe yeares enter dayly greater affayres businesse vaine hope assurance haue dispatch bring end list desire afterwards come follie olde courtier looke matter wil god desert procure poore old men find thinke goe home house see death approach neare afterwardes carried buried graues many court become aged men long seruing court vaine hope afterwards age depart court repose aged yeares owne house quyet tranquilitie abuseth much may bee called christian name thoughtes right worldling courtyers doings therefore many time reproued diuers olde courtyers friendes leaue court might haue left honour commoditie tellling time depart courte seeing age grauitie stollen vpon could tell aunswere say would within shorte time goe home house deliberation intent take ease home better health person till seclude doings saue onely morning hee riseth goe church serue god thence go vnto hospitalls visite sicke diseased seeke poore orphanes widowes amongst neighbour make peace neighbour neighbour relieue poore albeit haue tolde tale many time ofte yet neuer sawe put execution good saw honorable rich courtyer olde age hee neuer blacke haire head teeth foolish opinion olde courtier mouth neyther child sonnes daughter inherite good notwithstanding foolish phantasticall opinion brought kinde madnesse sinnes sware vnto discharge conscience onely hee would neuer leaue giue vp office hee courte chaunge seruile trade course life obtaine quyet rest home thinking assuredly enjoying rest home owne house hee might easily damned abyding paine seruice court hee belieued vndoubtedly hee saued surely wee may aptly say olde courtyer dotard hee marred call conscience since hee belieued charge conscience depart court ambition much couetousnesse haue much maketh miserable courtyers belieue haue yet time ynough liue repent themselues court thinking liue two yeares onely age good men liue fiftie three score yeares naughty wicked person plutarch apothegmes sayth eudonius captain greekes seeing zenocrates reading worthy saying plutarch one day vniuersitie athens hee age eightie fiue yeares asked old man answered one philosopher greece followed vertue serched know wherein true philosophie consisted whereupon answered xenocrates philosopher tell mee hee eightie fiue yeares old goeth seek vertue age would thou shouldest also tell time hee haue left bee vertuous hee sayde moreouer yeares philosopher reason see doe vertuous thing age goe seeke truely may say like new courtier eudonius sayde xenocrates philosopher hee looke threescore yeares threescore ten good time remaine proue shew goodnesse maruell olde courtier forget natiue countrey bringing vp father begate friendes shewed fauour seruants serued doe onely wonder also giueth mee cause suspect see forget themselues neuer know consider haue doe till come afterwardes would courtier prince court haue beene rich noble authority would counsell least beleeue writing shold depart thence time haue long time consider death least death vnawares suddenly came take execution liues happy thrice happy may call esteemed courtier god hath giuen much witte knowledge himselfe hee depart court fortune good caueat courtier hath touched dishonour laid cruell handes vpon neuer saw courtier end complain court ill life ledde court yet neuer know person would leaue scruple consciece remain peraduenture depart court respect altogether say eyther fauour credite diminished money fayled hath done wrong court hee driuen court denyed fauour side faction helde fall hee sicke gette health hee went countrey may say hee rather went angrie displeased himselfe hee lament sin aske priuately euery courtier shall finde none say discontented court eyther poore afflicted enuied ill willed fauour hee sweare resweare againe desireth nothing world dismissed courtier trauell painefull life afterwards perchance little winde fauour stirring entrey chamber dore sodenly blow away good former thought mind yet make mee wonder vnconstant courtier vnstable braines see many build goodly stately house countrey yet neyther dwell keepe hospitality graffe set tree plant fruites make good garden orchard yet neuer goe enioye purchase great landes possession neuer goe see haue office dignity giuen countryes neuer goe exercise haue friend parent yet neuer goe talke rather slaues drudge court lord ruler countrey may iustly say many courtier poore rich stranger owne house pilgrimes countrey banished kindred wee see part courtier backbite murmure complaine abhorre vice see daily committed court dare assure discontentation dislyking proceeds vice error see committed spight enuie haue daylie see enemyes growe fauour credite prince passe little vice court may fauour others plutarch book de exilio sheweth law amongst thebanes man fiftie yeares age fell sicke bee holpen physitians say man arriued vnto age desire liue longer rather hasten iourneys ende example wee may know infancie till vii yeares childhood xiiii yeares youth xxv yeares manhood till xl age threescoreyeares passed threescore think rather time make cleane nettes content theselues fish haue till go put net order againe fish grant court prince may saued yet man deny mee prince court mo occasion damned saued cato censor saith apt occasion bring men desire yll though good themselues although take vpon determine leade godly holie life shew themselus great hypocrite yet assured notwithstanding cannot keepe tongue fro murmuring hart enuying cause hereof proceedeth ther follow court long onely enter credit afterwards vaxe rich growe great authoritie cannot bee without bearing little secret hate enuy doe passe fauour authority without suspect feare others equal companion good counsell haue court prince till old gray headed determine liue rest yeares good christian passe courtier though haue giuen world meale yet end giue brain iesus christ know euery man desireth liue prince court yet promise dye court since mee thinkes great folly presumption men desire liue long state would dye golde world haue liued court manie yeares present haue forsaken quite wherefore dare boldly say man come enioy qui life reposed rest assured would euer hate dislike courtier longer like senseles courtier remember life come onely account theyr vaine courtly life present reputing blessed happie god seeing theyr folly fond addicted minde vanitie court plague scourge withall withtheir owne rodde doth great better rest onely enioy prince court feedes owne humour therefore truely sayde rest contentation neuer endeth house worthy noble courtier blessed fauoured courtier remember yea againe remember presume cut pull winges time since neyther shall appoloneus thianeus borne without pain griefe mother travell god spake eare hee raysed deade life healed sicke knew thought men diuined thing come hee serued prince honoured people followed philosopher yet make great wonder thing spoken hee neuer married moreouer neuer detected knowledge woman liuing much lesse suspected whilest carthage enuironed siege side virgine numidia taken prisoner presented scipio fayre scipio notwithstanding would onely deflower set liberty married honourably act apprised roman writer conquest numedia restoring rome liberty destruction carthage succour reliefe giuen asia enobling common wealth enterprise hee still fought others effect flesh hee fought himselfe therefore hee must needes maruellous wise good iudgement subdue desire motion flesh wee doe much couet follow carnall desire wee apt meate wee hungry cruell bitter assaultes flesh spirite wonderful paine spirite abideth resist motion meanes ouercome eschewing occasion thereof brideling desire punishing flesh liuing spare dyet increasing learning giuing himselfe tear altogether shutting gate desire vice flesh came aboundance heate rage bloud might soon remedy letting selues bloud sicknesse heart cured interiour medicine liuer wee would refresh ointment melancholy humour wee would wash away al opilations choler wee would procure easie purge ala disease farre pitty misliketh wee call physitians cannot abide wee offer remedy cannot bee denyed ciuill warre grieuous dangerous commonwealth much perillous home betwixt husband wife ieoperdious man hath within himselfe wee cannot reckon enemy owne desire remember saw written courties house wordes truely deserued bee written golden letter word dreadefull warves ala sustaine worthy sentence worthy engrauen euery man heart blinde desire becomes mighty foe selfe perforce selfe doth straine wreckfull god vouchsafe doe surely hee wrote word wee thinke hee foole euill christian sith hee neither sought money sleight witte procured deceiue beguile neither called friendes helpe withstand enemy craued remedy vnhonest vain desire vndoubtedly reason man may easily absent himselfe impossible thing therfore think thing lamented written see multitude corporall enemy cannot vanuquish v yet notwithstanding wee alone thinke nothing vice flesh dooth alone make v stumble fal downe groud neither becom religious frier dwell church shut vp cloysters sequester selues world yet chaunge state condition say see none al thing helpe v mortall men defende v vice sinne seeke flye daunger finde fall albeit auoyd vice sinnes shall suffice v bee admonished yet alone flesh behoueth v bee armed sinne world meanes men auoyd excepted flesh wherewith wee ouercome taken prisonners proue true apparant thus raigneth pride amongst potentate enuie amongst equalls anger amongst impacient gluttony amongst gourmand auarice amongst rich slouth amongst ydle yet sinne flesh generally reigneth sinnes flesh goeth beyond men therefore resisting abhominable vice haue seen king lose kingdom nobleman land possession marryed wiues auowd faith religious nunnes professed virginitie wee may compare sinne nature condition venemous serpent aliue sting v hee dead offendeth v noysome stinke example dauid wisedome could preuaile sinne salomon al great knowledge absolon diuine beautie sampson mighty force notwithstading great fame renowmed vertues yet defect lost accompanying harlot licentious woman shameful felowship fell also holofernes haniball ptholomeus pyrpirrhus inlius caesar augustus marcus antonius seuerus theodorius many great prince aboue recited part haue seene depriued crownes afterwards themselues haue come vtter shame dishonour knces yeelde themselues mercy infamed louers crauing pardon forgiuenesse many graue writer grecian say ambassadours lidia comming one day chamber hercules vpon suddaine speake found lying curtesans lappe pulling ring finger hee dressed head womanly attire exchnnge bedect royall crowne write also denis syracusian albeit nature hee cruell wild beast yet became end tractable pleasant meanes curtezan friend called mirta confirme prouisions depeches affayres weale publike onely ordaine appoint history written gothes deceyne v wee finde antenaricus famous king gothes triumphed italy hee made himselfe lord europe hee became farre loue louer called pincia whilest shee combed head hee made cleane slipper also themistocles famous captaine greekes enamoured woman hee taken warres epirns shee beeing afterwardes sicke shee purged selfe hee would also bee purged shee let bloud hee would also bee let bloud yet worst bee liked hee washed face bloud came arme might truly say though shee prisoner yet hee also slaue subiect king demetrius taken rhodes broght faire gentlewoman cittie made friend loue loue betwixt time grewe great shewing selfe vpon time angry demetrius refusing sit neare table also lye demetrius vtterly forgetting himselfe royall estate onely knee pray pardon also imbracing conueighed armes chamber myronides grecian albeit hee made subiect kingdom boetia yet hee notwithstanding made subiect beautie numidia louer hee enflamed thus loue likewise strucken couetous desire good fine agreed shold giue spoyle wonne warres boetia let lye hir house onely one night hanniball made warres xvii yeares romaine time neuer vanquished till hee ouercome loue young mayden cittie capua proued bitter loue sith thereby happened whereas hee many yeares kept subiection italie hee made subiect home owne countrey plutarch booke de republica writeth phalaris tyraunt would neuer graunt man thing desired neyther euer denyed plutark de repub thing dissolute woman requested small great disorder happened commonweale rome occasion emperour caligula gaue sexterces onely repayre wall rome gaue otherwise furring one one gowne alone lemmans sexterces example aboue recited wee may easily vnderstand daungerous thing courtier haue friendshippe acquaintance woman vile facultie woman like quality knot tyed corde easily tyed sundry knot hardly afterwards bee vndone againe heretofore wee haue besought courtier fauoured prince bee liberall commaunding againe wee pray beware fornication adultery albeeit sinne flesh greatest fault yet daungerous fame king prelate knight world vicious dishonest impossible courtier liueth disordinately continue fauour prince life would glad haue honest vertuous well conditioned seruants impossible therefore fauoured courtier liuing dishonestlie continue long time fauour prince wee haue seene many prince court common weales also haue lost honour fauour rich pride shewed themselues enuy treasure rich robbed euil word speake neither treason committed onely euill fame went haunting company naughty woman woman right nature hedgehog without seeing knowing haue heart notwithstanding drawe bloude v prickes let man deceyue himselfe hoping hee commit fault flesh shal kept prince care shall bee blazed abroad court sinne qualitie though may bee hidden within curtaines yet cannot bee kept silent tongue wise slie soeuer woman bee yet time shee giueth eare vnto men request euen prosent shee resolueth impart whole friend woman doe glory bee friend courtier bee true wife vnto husband haue selfe seene prince courtes many humble courteous pittifull patient charitable wise deuout otherwise maruellous honest yet amongst neuer found one secret therefore man haue published world let tell woman e secret come wee woman carry head forrest hayres coyre hood gimm hanging eares partlets vpon shoulder smockes body petti kertles hose clokes hatts chaynes braslets ring p umes offethers hand many trinket named al carry lightly vpon thinke burthen yet cannot abide case keepe carry one secret brest ala pitty see affected courtier meanes vse win lady fauour pleasaunt purpose discourse put forth vnto bitter signes let fall seruice offer iewels giue castle ayre promise sorrowes fayne lye make belieue silly woman nature proud foolish gift ouercome fewe flattering wordes beguiled let courtier lady continue mutuall friendship betweene one two three foure fiue yeares though perhappes fully yeares compleate neyther many monethes also shall see end vndoubtedly maruellous breach hate betwixt amorous courtier dearely seemed loue lady make court fresh others dislike heretofore loued flie erst hee followed abhorring hee delighted misliking taste meat sweet pleasant cannot abide face whose image hee engrauen minde spent yeares seruice making mistresse spendeth yeares courtier must beware dishonest woman forgotting therefore noble courtier beloued prince must beware make young dishonest loues common euery place sweete fragrant rose seeke gather continueth scantly one houre prickes plague pearsing thorne resteth hidden flesh whole life time man erreth nothing world taking charge dishonest woman hee bring court shee shall shame put vnreasonable charge besides burthen conscience afterwards hee would put away wil depart thing would compel ere shee departe court ouer thing haue past betwixt two alone secret shall afterwardes knowne euery man abroade therefore haue causelesse tolde must need maruellous expence courtyer bring louer court must alwayes charge keepe page maide gentlewoman wayte vpon must content hostesse house lodge secretly please marshall seeme knowe harbinger hee prepare good lodging page hee diligent hand selfe also must haue liue withall expence charge hee shall must need farre exceede benefites commodity hath court besides hee may assure himselfe leawde fonde loue cannot long endure neyther care also selfe kept secret eyther hostesse lodged bawde procureth theyr meeting page bringeth commendation message betwixt neighbor see frequent house seruant shall suspect mother solde vnto ende bewray secret practise friendship whereof springeth afterwards disdaine disdain defame extreame louers first afterwards become mortall enemyes therefore wiuell hurtfull corne locust oates wormes vine maggot fruit moth garment woman man friende become enemie like time loue robbed spoyled good likewise time hatred deuoureth good fame reputation shall wee say man contenteth himselfe one friend alone like vnsatiable leacher taketh vpon keep another truly cannot tell say man beene better neuer borne haue kept company vile common woman shall neuer appease first neyther anger flattery humble present expell hatred promise neyther please cherishing much lesse shall ouercome threat ocean sea daungerous sword tyrant cruell neyther lightning suddaine earthquake horrible fearefull serpent venemous dager followeth courtier keepeth leawd woman harlot doth suspect friend loueth another beside selfe shee ceaseth defame follow raise slander amongst neighbour complaine friend bewray matter iustice quarrell officer alwayes haue spyes euery place hee one mortall enemy oh would god courtyer would esteeme much conscience louer maketh account person happie hee dare assure know shee spyeth place hee goeth counteth euery morsell meate eateth becommeth iealous hee doeth whose companie hee frequenteth yea deuiseth imagineth hee thinketh seeketh cruell reuenge enemy cannot doe better perswade induce loue one wellconditioned gentlewoman let thinke hath great warres euill hap hath made enemie heretofore hee entirely loued man esteemeth honour reputation doth rather feare euill tongue woman sword enemy honest man striue contend woman quality eue much hee would take vpon wash ass head therefore hee may seeme make account iniuries done euill word shee hath spoken woman naturally desire enioy person loue without let interruption pursue death hate would wish therefore fauoured prince haue office dignity court beware incurre like error fitting men honour great prince seeme haue liberty vice neyther respect ought beloued prince dare keepe company much lesse haue friendshippe common defamed woman sith least euill come cannot auoided least hee must charge conscience trouble friend waste good consume person lose good fame ioining withall also concubine bee mortall enemy woman liuing hath measure louing end hating oh warily ought men liue specially court prince many woman vnder colour authority office go ofttimes seeke chamber onely humble suiters solicite cause also liberally offer person colour conclude practises deuises decision co clusion proces faine solicite shall goe demaunds good rather desire person spoyle theyr honour prince officer must seeke pure cleane al practises commo strumpet much suters haue matter highly offend god commit great treason king sende woman sued vnto rather dishonored defamed honestly dispatched businesse therefore bindeth himselfe maruellous inconuenience falleth loue woman suter euen instant hee hath receiued sweet delight loue euen present hee bindeth dispatch quickly end suite without great griefe speake word many woman come court prince make vnreasonable dishonest sutes end notwithstanding obtaine desire right reason haue saue onely haue obtained fauour credite haue wonne fauoured courtier one beloued wee see happen many time vniust furnication made suit iust reasonable lye doe selfe wrong thinkes passe ouer silence thing hapned emperours court touching matter went one day one prince chiefe officer best beloued solicit matter importace hostes mine haue fauoured courtier great officer hee hearde men whole discourse matter full resolution hee asked mee shee yong fayre aunswered shee reasonable fayre good fauour well sayth bid come mee doe best dispatch matter speede assure neuer came fayre woman handes shee businesse quickly dispatcht hand haue knowne also many woman court dishonest contented follow owne matter would also deale others affayres gaine feliciting theyr cause theyr fine wordes franke offer person obtayned many time men honour great authority denyed therefore great officer fauoured prince ought haue great respect onely conuersation haue woman also honest order ought obserue hearing cause bee done sort whatsoeuer say vnto may bee secret prouided also place speake bee open suiters like case chap xviii noble beloued prince exceede superfluous fare bee sumptuous meates notable chapter vse much delicacy superfluitie greatest care regard nature laide vpon selfe men could liue without sustinance long wee see man eate yea thousande yeares wee might bee bolde say hee certainely aliue hee hath alone layde burden vpon men bruite beast also wee see experience feedeth grasse fieldes liues ayre eating flyes others vpon wormes carring others finde vnder water finally beast liueth afterwardes wormes feede v onely reasonable men brute beast liue eating tree nourished thereby wee see thus stead meate receiue nutriture heate sunne temperature ayre moisture earth dewe heauen sustenance men called meate plant tree increase beeing true therefore wee haue spoken must needes confesse liue wee must eate yet withall wee must vnderstand sin gluttony consisteth wee eate necessity eaten disordinate appetite desire sure dayes men vse eate content nature please licorous dainty mouthes hee giueth selfe ouer desire throate doth onely offend stomacke distemper body hurteth also conscience glutton drunkard child brother sinne speake little say mouth sinne c sin germanes together effect operation thinketh knit combined together father sonne sith burning leacherie acknowledgeth none mother onely infatiable gurmand throate diuersity meates continuall importunate awaking dishonest thought doe reade hierome albeit hee remained wildernesse burned sunne face dryed vp wrinkled bare footed also bare headed clothed sackcloth body scourged bitter stripe watching night fasting hungering day continually exercising pen heart contemplation yet grieuous penance selfe confessed sleepe hee dreamed thought among curtezans rome paul apostle man rare exquisite knowledge deserued see secretes paradise neuer fore seene trauelling vocation apostle get liuing painefull trauel industry saint paul owne hand also went foote preaching world bringing infinite barbarous people faith christ beaten day time others hee christian night time hee beat himselfe sinner punishing flesh make subiect spirit yet neuerthelesse layth himselfe coulde defend himselfe dishonest thought euer let preach pray quiet minde saint austen reciteth himselfe booke de consessionibus inhabited desert hee eate little wrote much prayed oft sharpely chastised body continuall fast grieuous discipline yet perceyuing notwithstanding dishonest thoughtes suppressed holy desire began crye lowde voyce thorough desert rocky hils saying lord god thou commaundest chast fraile accursed flesh neuer keepe therefore humbly beseech thee first indue mee thy grace doe thou wilt haue commaund shall please thee otherwise shall neuer doe therefore glorious saint continual fast contemplation extreame punishing body could defend themselues burning motion flesh shal beleeue company drunkard glutton doe neuer linne bibbing eating wee may bee assured lesse pamper feede body delicacy idlenes morewe shall haue obedient subiect willes though wee see fire neuer great flaming yet quickely wasteth brought ash wee leaue put wood vnto excesse onely vnlawfull body also occasion thousand disease body soule say truth wee haue seene rich men die excesse poore men necessity mine opinion mee thinkes sinne gluttonie need otherwise punished diuine iustice seeing selfe bringeth pennaunce ynough proue true let v require glutton tell v vpon oathes finde themselues temper full paunched confesse without art great mystery nature gaue v two feete two hand two eares two eye yet one tongue whereby shee shewed v going feeling smelling hearing seeing may bee long speaking wee sparing scant could bee alleadging nature suffered v goe open barefaced eye eares hand feete partes bodie bare also excepting tongue shee hath enuironned jawes empaled teeth also shut vp lip shee giue v vnderstand ther nothing present life hath neede guarde defence hath vnbrydeled tongue therefore sayde pythachus phylosopher man tongue made like yron poynt lance yet daungerous poynt lance hurte flesh tongue pierceth heart surely true saying philosopher know man vertuous pacient euer think lesse hurt bloudie sword pierce flesh touched honour venemous poynt serpentinetongue cruell soeuer wound time doth heale maketh wel againe defame infamie neyther late neuer amended see men refuse goe water feare drowning come neer fire feare burning goe warres feare killing eate ill meates beeing sicke climbe vp high feare falling goe darke feare stumbling auoyde yll ayre raine feare rewmes yet see none beware detractor ill tongue true tell doe thinke thing man perill daunger liueth accompanyed men dishonest theyr dooings vile naught tongue haue also read touching matter aformius phylosopher asked meant spend part time amongst desart mountaines hazard euery houre deuoured wilde beast answered thus wild beast haue weapon hurt mee theyr horne nayles theyr teeth deuoure mee men neuer cease hurte offend mee whole member true behold pray looke mee eye spurne mee feete torment mee hand hate mee heart defame alexander touch honour thy tongue thou shouldst thy sword ouercome example wee may gather much wee ought hate detraction ill speaking since see enemy themselues cannot abide heare enemy euill spoken presence alwayes obserued honourable graue wise men noble mindes sure noble heart disdaineth bee reuenged enemy tongue iniuries done hee cannot reuenged sword fitting generall modest honest speech much due embraceth fauour credite prince profession doe good helpe euery man speake ill man haue centinels spy vpon continually officer court prince marke speake treading awry little soeuer bee straight blowne prince eares perhaps accused neuer thoght delighting taking great pleasure tell openly heard say therefore dayly courtier attending vppon behauiour belongeth courtier prince fauour must meane continue fauour credite gentle courteous wordes bountifull stand need also esteemed courtyer must beware hee doe speake yll man also great talker commonly great talker besides esteemed bee deedes although oft time great talker men full word bee noble byrth worship wealthie possession otherwise authoritie estimation yet neuerthelesse time spende speaking much others heare occupie deryding scorning beseech consider greater reproach could courtyer haue counted babbler prater tongue lyer hee think euery man attentiue listening quite contrarie euen instant laugh scorne yet nothing shame doe vnto afterwards talke whilst thus babbling pot mouthes behind backe nod head holdes downe theyr eye soothes hee sayes praise commend merry afterwards matter together sport note heare one great talker man talke warre liberall science hunting husbandrie hee streight leape matter althogh vtterly ignorant thing proponed taking vppon reason matter hee skilfull master faculty make hearer belieue true saith hee bringeth example saying hath seene read heard perhaps starke lye hee neyther sawe reade heard onely deuised owne head sudden vnder colour truth forge make false lye acaticus phylosopher beeing one day feast hee neyther spake offered speake asked dinner occasion silence answered thus better man know wise saying acaticus philosopher time speake knowe speake speake well giuen v nature chuse fit time speake proceedeth wisdome epimenides painter hee dwelt long time asia returned rhodes whence hee first departed none rhodians euer hearde speake thing eyther hee seene done asia maruelled much earnestly prayed discourse vnto part seen suffered asia whome hee made aunswere two yeares sulked sea abyding perills water ten yeares resident asia learn perfection paynters art sixe yeares studyed greece accustome selfe silent nowe would feede tale newes rhodians come mee motion come house buy picture heare newes albeit many yeares farre strange country could epimenides seene many thing worthy bee recounted also pleasant heare yet hee would neuer tell shew sure herein like good philosopher answered like wise graue person telling strange thing diuers country beleeue many stand doubt whether true therefore touching matter also pythagoras philosopher one day asked vpon occasion made scholers vse great silence colledge two yeares entered might speake answered thus philosopher schooles teach disciple speake mine taught nothing holde peace whole world better higher speech pythagoras philosophy know bridle tongue maruellous thing see time beard haires head become white face withered eares deafe leg swoln breath stinke spleene stopte body faint feeble age part thereof consumed saue onely heart tongue neuer see waxe olde manner aged impotent soeuer bee rather dayly become greene worst euill wretched hart thinketh crooked miserable age doth accursed tongue celerity vtter companie courtier court presume bee eloquent well spoken courtly entertainement talke pleasant matter must first tell lye surely kind courtier wee may better call detractor others ciuill entertainer accursed bee hee preiudice neighbour maketh profession bee courtly entertainener shall hardly see none recited courtier iest haue secret spunne thread weaue great cloth malice yet wee doe men great honour reuerence good beare wee afraid ill tongue althogh dissemble graue wise man part yet wee may iudge ill since wee see best man honour credite commonly greater lesse malignant person shal seeme vse tongue speake remember court time noble man noble birth person whome reproued diuers time familiar friend prodigall liuing ill speaking made answere truely sir report speake ill themselues follow therein nothing else bee witnesse seeke impugne saying sure selfe neuer vttered deuised word might bee preiudice euill causeth hee speaketh ill another onely offendeth beginneth hee assisteth much heareth publisheth aboue hee telleth abroade addeth hee heard fauoured prince must also thinke though prohibited speake much yet courtyer ought ue secretarie fitte decent bee true faithfull secretary thing prince priseth secret breast fauoured courtier therefore say without cause ought bee secret secret esteemed courtier must haue better consideration prince secret committed vnto benefites receyued sure small great necessary vertue man bee close fewe word secret deede make countenance tolde priuily neuer heard spoke know kinde people proane speake yll cannot keepe secret theyr owne faultes much lesse others fault publishing euery corner cecilius metellus beeing asked one day centurion meant doe next day following aunswered thus thinke centurion thing determined doe hand shall lightly discouer minde knewe shyrt knowledge doe tomorrow would put throw straight fire see burned face alike trust put money one man handes trust commit secretes breast another true see plainly prince deliuereth good treasure custodie manie secret hee committeth onely one fauoured prince ought secrete whatsoeuer see prince doe say presence diuers tolde many yet ought acknowne indeede prince speaketh many thing comonly pleasure reported againe fauoured courtyer wil thought true certain therefore speaking generally matter say surely friendes greatly bound keepe secretes friend day discouer intent selfesame make lord libertie therefore let man thinke hath wonne maruellous treasure hath secrete friend without doubt matter importance keepe treasure safely locked vp chest commit trust secretes vnto heart another plutarche writeth athenian hauing warres king philip bound secret wold reueale secret others notwithstanding mortall enemy k philip therefore would neyther see read openly diodorus siculus sayth also among egyptian criminal act man bewray secret another proued true example priest temple goddesse isi defloured virgine trusting fidelitie another priest making loue knowne vnto euen venus sweete delight hee regarding longer secret ipso facto exclaimed cryed thereupon conuict apprehended iustice poore louers miserably executed spightful vnfortunate priest condignely banished banished priest complaining vniust sentence saying reuealed fauour religion behoose common wealth iudge aunswered thus thou haddest knowne offence thy selfe without notice giuen thee thou haddest reason haue complained sentence since trusted thee doings thou gauest thy word promise secret thou hadst called minde bonde thou werte bound thy selfe freely without compulsion submit thy selfe vnto thou wouldest dared haue published fact thou hast done plutarch booke de exilio sayeth man athens demaunded egyptian disciple philosopher hee vnder cloke aunswered thus truely thou hast studyed little borne away lesse although thou art athenian borne sith thou seest carry secretly thou demaundest thou none shoulde know yet thou askest selfe carry anasillus captaine athenian taken lacedemonians put torture tell hee knew king agesilaus lord master whome hee gaue answere lacedemonians haue liberty dismember hewe mee piece haue reueale lord master secret worthy answere anasillus athens wee vse rather dye bewray secret friend king lisimachus entreated philosopher euill president found house antigonus time registred also gently thereof admonished banished vnto isle scicilie long time shold please senate like sumptuous goodly building one stone falleth without shaking another chaunceth likewise men commonly one mischaunce commeth alone another immediately followeth speake purpose antigonus onely depriued honour good countrey also earthquake house fell downe ground slewe dearely beloued daughter whilest mischaunces hapned meane monster scicily banishment antigonus rome marke emperour warres argonantes hee receiued letter antigonus banishment whereof emperour maruellous sorrie appeareth aunswere hee sent comfort chap iii marcus aurelius sought wealth people people loued second yeare marke elected emperour xlv age hee returned conquest germanes argonants whence hee brought great rich treasure romane empire rest himselfe appoint men lay salon vntill time romanes prepared thinges conuenient glorious triumph one thing done neuer seene rome day letter written hand happe good thy loue would permit speak thee would hope sight speech winne suspect letter loose reason whereof thou shalt reade rude reason letter thou sawest thou shouldest see bitter teares wold offer thee vnhappy life oh mouth could publish cruell paine heart feeleth sweare vnto thee lady macrine woefull plaintes would styrre vppe thy small care thy beautie hath made thee thyne owne true knowledge thy griefes make thee mine desire thou wouldest regarde beginning therewith note ende truth day thou imprisonedst hart window dungeon desire lesse weaknesse ouercome thou haddest strength enforce greater thy power take selfe reason put mee thee ladie macrine doe aske mercie thee may declare mindes together case wilt thou say vnto thee thou hast much power ouer mee little liberty though would heart must needes bee thine beeing thine thou wilt shew thy selfe mine sith may life must bee condemned thy seruice bee thou sure faith doubtfull thy goodwill shall haue greater honour lost thy sake win treasure haue say vnto thee thou haue respect perdition drawe life death turne teares ioye holde faith neuer despaire thy hope send thee x little ring gold x ring alexandria immortall god conjure thee thou puttest thy finger thou receyuest loue thy heart marcus thy louer wrote owne hand chap xi p letter emperour sent ladie macrine wherein hee expresseth fieryflames soonest consume gentlehearts marke thy neighbour rome thee macrine sweete enemie call thee sweete iust dye thee enemy thou ceassest kill cannot tell sith feast ianus hitherto haue written three letter vnto thee answer wherof would haue contented haue receiued two thee would serue thee thou wilt bee serued speak thee thou wilt answer behold thee thou wilt looke mee call thee thou answer visite thee thou wilt see write vnto thee thou wilt make answer worst others shew thee grief thou takest mockerie oh much knowledge complaine thee thou hast power ease plaint wisdome lesse praised amongst wise thy beautie among fooles beseech thee hartily haue respect rudenes reason regard faith teares offer thee witnes know profite may come harme gayne losse thou mayest hope haue surety perill thou maist attaine pleasure paine thou mayest haue aunswere messenger without reading letter thine hand thou didst rent peeces ought suffice thinke manie person tormented pleased ladie macrine haue read line haue perceyued inwardly tormented yee woman extreame misaduenture one man woman complaine men generall yee shew crueltie one particular cause openly yee pardon men liues secretly ye procure death account nothing ladie macrine thou hast done lament thou causest thy neighbour valerius say one thing would thou shouldest remember forget sith libertie small thy power great beeing wholly mine turned thine iniury thou dost thou hurtest thy selfe since thee dye thou dost liue peruerse opinio abide maist thou hazard life v thou burist thy good name destroyest health end thou must come physicke pardon lady macrine say ought may offend thee know ye woman desire one thing greatly haue souerainty v yet seeme much thought wish thou haddest fame gentle nature though indeede thou wert yet thou haddest fame therof ancient good name ought lost new vnkindnesse thou knowest contrary ingratitude vertue vertuous house thou canst called vertuous thou curteous greater ingratitude loue againe though visite thee thou nothing though remember thee thou forgettest mee nothing thogh weepe thou laugh nothing though craue thee thou denie nothing thogh thou owest mee pay mee nothing loue thee thou mee great thing eye neither dissemble heart suffer vice mortall men pardoned offend naturally saue discurtesy woman vngentlenes men counted malice diuers seruices mee done thee good willes haue heretofore borne thee thou onely lady macrine one thing reward pray thee slacke helpe offer mee perill thou sayest patroclus thy husband hath property thee least yet receiue vpon proofe pretend possession thee wise vainglory thine shall hide hurt mine thou makest mee maruell little small rewarde thou wilt suffer great importunity certainly grant many thing importunate man wee denie temperate man thou lady macrine hopest ouercom behold yeeld mee vanquished thou wilt loose mee holde mee lost thou wilt kill mee holde dead gesture make thy gate secrete sighes fetch house thou mayst know greatly minde rest thy braue assault rather building nourish death comfort life thou wilt escape danger denie remedie shalbe greater dishonour slay shame saue iust thing small gaine lose faithfull friend wote make thee debter make thee pay mee worst knowe say determine borne mine owne wealth faithfull thy seruices sith thou knowest whome thou hast trusted thy message trust open letter answer secret send thee jewell pearle peece golde pray god make thee receyue willingly doe freely send marke orator inexorable macrine chap xii p letter emperour marcus aurelius sent vnto ladie lyuia wherein reproueth loue naturall part phylosophers wise men haue loue ouercome marke full sorrow thee carelesse lyuia thy little care lodge sorrowes harboured thee thou shouldest see little quarrell make vnto thee respect torment suffer flame issue fire doeth burne mee within heauens perish smoake earth make imbers thou doest well remember first time saw thee temple virgine vestal thou beeing diddest alwayes pray god thy selfe vpon knee prayed thee mee thou knowest doe thou diddest offer oyle honnie god offer vnto thee teares sighes iust thou giue vnto offered heart draweth mony purse haue determined write vnto thee letter whereby thou mayest perceiue thou art serued arrowes mine eye shot white thy seruice oh vnhappy feare least present calme doth threaten mee tempest come say discurtesie thee causeth doubtfull hope mee beholde misaduenture lost letter turning temple seeke found letter importance almost lost selfe greatest thing considering small reward see mine eye ladder hope set high wall lesse certaine fell clyming doubtfull thou bending downe thy harnesse thy high desert putting mee poynt continuall seruice sufferest mee enioy fruite giue vnto thou wilt leaues immortall god sweare vnto thee maruell little thought temple virginvestals temptation could haue comen vnto man contrary true experience finde woman easylier ouercome watched hath honest libertie bodily disease bee first ere knowne knowne ere seene seene ere felt felt ere tasted thing except dart loue first feele stroke thereof knowe way commeth lightning commeth sudden knowne thunder wall falleth suddenly first stone fall downe colde commeth fast small shiuering seene loue felt vntill hath power entrailes let know ignorant thou lady lyuia thou wilt know loue sleepeth waken waketh sleepe laugheth wee weepe weepeth wee laugh assureth taking taketh assuring speaketh wee bee still still wee speake finally hath condition giue v desire causeth v liue paine sweare vnto became thy seruant thy beautie made thee mistris temple found thee neyther thou thy prayer diddest minde mee vnhappie man thinke thee oh vnhappy heart mine whole thou art diuided health thou art hurt aliue thou art killed mine thou art stolne worste thou helping life consentest death assault mee considering manie time lady liuia selfe thoughtes high fortune base would haue separated selfe thee vpon better hope knowing trauells well employed thy seruice say though might would wish bee separated thee denie one thing cursed loue taketh away taste thing thing giueth v pleasure greatly profite proofe loueth heartily one frowne hee loueth doeth grieue delight rest life please deeme ladie lyuia thou art abashed see mee openly phylosopher know secretly louer beseech thee hartily discouer god graunt mee long life young foole yet age wise god know desire force doeth enforce mee thereunto flesh weake hart tender occasion manie vertues fewe world deceitfull people malicious passe springtime flowres hope haruest shall haue fruite thinkest thou lady lyuia philosopher bee neuer wise touched sharpe dart loue vnder course cloathes softe flesh white certainly amongst hard bone nourished soft flesh within pricking huskes growe chessnut say vnder simple attyre faithfull loue denie fraile nature doeth withstand vertues denie wanton desire repressed vertuous mindes denie rashnes youth restrayned reynes reason denie many time wisdome doeth withstand flesh procureth yet confesse hee amorous foole doest thou know although wise leaue therefore men doest thou know euer wee learne life sufficeth gouerne flesh one houre doest thou know wise men case hath fallen many errours doest thou knowe hath bin manie maisters vertues much hath bin follower vice doest thou make wonder onely mee say without trueth neuer iudgement good perfite cupid blewe winde mee wing neuer man vntill time accounted wise first hee intangled cupid snare gratian loue tamira solon salaminus giuer law enamoured one gretian pittachus mytelenus left owne wife loue bondwoman hee brought warres cleobolus hee fourescore yeares elde read phylosophie sixtiefiue yeares climbing vp ladder scale neighbour wall fell bruise dyed periander prince achaya chiefe philosopher greece instance louers slew wife anacharsis philosopher scythian father greeke mother side loued dearely woman thebe hee taught knew much sicke bed shee read schooles epimenides creete slept yeares without waking although hee great worshipper god yet banished athens yeares louing woman architus tarentinus master plato scholler pythagoras occupyed minde inuent newe kindes loue employ study vertue learning gorgias leontinus borne scicile mo concubine house bookes studie wise men knew wise yet ende ouercome flesh therefore blame alone haue tolde thee fewe could whole armey trueth ought haue many thing bee accounted curious louer must haue eye displayed hee loueth vnderstanding much altered hee thinketh tongue troubled speake seeing blinde thinking dismaid speaking troubled ladie lyuia louing mockerie passeth mockery true loue griefe mockery true loue spitteth poyson cruell cupid fixeth arrowes vp feather eye weepe heart sigheth flesh trembleth sinewes doe shrinke vnderstanding grosse reason falleth earth finally heauie louer abyding himselfe holdeth nothing himselfe say want knowledge make mee louer yet sure workes faile effect thy seruice though mishap saw thee yet good chaunce knew thee aske nothing thee thou loue faithfully sith loue thee vnfainedly thou hearest sicke hart desire thee doe good sith thee helpe reason thou onely doe seeke remedie greatly comforted fulius carlotus desired thy behalfe doe pleasure incontinent thou desiredst intent thou another day shouldest doe franckly desire thee beholde faire ladie lyuia woman serued seruices great reason within sued vnto prayer though strength cannot open gate purpose agreeing thy demand yet labor slacke vphold thy renowne pray thee discouer one beguile thou seest graunting remedy hoping comfort promise deceiuable delaying perillous entertayning bindeth see well hearty demaund requireth long answere wold thou shouldst doe loue thee loue mee desire thee graunt thou mee say againe thine nothing mine owne note lady lyuia much honour thee profitable mee thou chaunge thy desire put order thy disordered thou seest much better heale shortly toolate fayling thy purpose woman obserue euill opinion yee neuer receiue councell although bee giuen neuer weightie case bee thou art esteemed beautifull bee likewise honoured taking good councell sort though losse much thy patience little yet shall account wise giuing counsell happie follow one thing say vnto thee pardon mee therein woman bee much defamed take counsell doe assure renowme much iudgement others condemne well thinke good like thee would thou wilt thou shouldest doe haue counselled thee say lady lyuia present vnto thee vnfortunate trouble sighes desperate man seruice thy seruant troubled griefes wordes phylosophie teares louer send thee heere gyrstle gold condition thou alwayes sixe thine eye thy heart mee pray god giue mee thee thee mee marke open phylosopher wrote great finis
